name: African Music
description: All forms with roots in Africa.

children.name: African Folk Music
children.description: Indigenous music of Africa that is passed down orally from generation to generation, the authors of the songs are usually unknown.

children.name: Ambasse bey
children.description: African Folk Music developed by the Yabassi people of Cameroon.

children.name: Apala
children.description: Yoruba Music developed by Muslims during the late 1930s and early 1940s in the Ijebu region of Yorubaland, the current Ogun state.

children.name: Batuque
children.description: Tradition from Cape Verde, unusual among the islands' music due to its lack of polyphonic singing and its usage of polyrhythms.

children.name: Dagomba Music
children.description: Music of the Dagomba people of northern Ghana.

children.name: Gnawa
children.description: Mixture of Sub-Saharan African, Arabic, and Amazigh Music, created by the Gnawa, an ethnic minority group in North Africa, mainly Morocco.

children.name: Kabye Folk Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of the Kabye people of northern Togo, including some of the most singular styles that can be found in West Africa.

children.name: Kilapanga
children.description: Tradition of the Bakongo people from Angola and Congo that has influenced contemporary styles such as Kuduro.

children.name: Malagasy Folk Music
children.description: Melodic, chordophone-dominated sound; based on the Austronesian Traditional Music of the first settlers that arrived on the island from Borneo.

children.name: Mbenga-Mbuti Music
children.description: Music of the Mbenga and Mbuti people, Pygmy ethnic groups in Central Africa.

children.name: Moutya
children.description: Tradition that originated in Seychelles among Creole slaves, similar to Séga, although rawer and played only on large flat drums made from goatskin.

children.name: Ngoma
children.description: Played in Swahili-speaking African countries; primarily focused on rhythm.

children.name: Unyago
children.description: Traditional music from Zanzibar, traditionally played at women's initiation rituals and weddings.

children.name: Semba
children.description: Style from Angola featuring danceable percussion, lyrics often taking the form of a story, and sometimes accompaniment from a guitar.

children.name: Southern African Folk Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of southern Africa.

children.name: Afrikaner Folk Music
children.description: Musical traditions developed by the Afrikaner community in southern Africa.

children.name: Khoisan Folk Music
children.description: Encompasses traditions of the Khoisan ethnic family groups.

children.name: Nguni Folk Music
children.description: Traditions of the Nguni ethnic family groups, a southern Bantu ethnicity.

children.name: Shona Mbira Music
children.description: Traditional style of the Shona people from Zimbabwe, based on a simple melodic pattern played on the mbira, from which long instrumental parts are improvised.

children.name: Sotho-Tswana Folk Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of the Sotho-Tswana ethnic family groups from southern Africa.

children.name: Tchinkoumé
children.description: Tradition from the central region of Benin around Savalou, played with water percussion.

children.name: Traditional Maloya
children.description: Derived from Traditional Séga, this is the original dance music of La Réunion.

children.name: Traditional Séga
children.description: Séga dance music born in the 18th century, before its later adoption of Western pop elements.

children.name: Zinli
children.description: Traditional rhythmic chanting and percussion adapted to multiple West African contexts in the 20th century.

children.name: Afro-Jazz
children.description: African-styled percussion and rhythms.

children.name: Cape Verdean Music
children.description: Music developed in the archipelago of Cape Verde.

children.name: Batuque
children.description: Tradition from Cape Verde, unusual among the islands' music due to its lack of polyphonic singing and its usage of polyrhythms.

children.name: Coladeira
children.description: Originated as a more uptempo and lively form of Morna before bringing in outside influences.

children.name: Funaná
children.description: Upbeat Cape Verdean style which developed on the island of Santiago, based around the diatonic accordion and rhythm provided by the ferrinho.

children.name: Morna
children.description: Slow tempo, monotonality, and the use of the violão, the Cape Verdean classical guitar, as the main instrumental accompaniment.

children.name: Central African Music
children.description: Music of the areas speaking Adamawa-Eastern languages and many Bantu languages, through most of the Democratic Republic of the Congo, all of Gabon, Equatorial Guinea, the islands of São Tomé and Príncipe, Republic of the Congo, most of the Central African Republic, and large parts of Cameroon, Angola, and the northern parts of Zambia.

children.name: Ambasse bey
children.description: African Folk Music developed by the Yabassi people of Cameroon.

children.name: Assiko
children.description: Music and dance of the Bassa people of southern Cameroon, which features a singer accompanied by a guitarist and improvised percussion.

children.name: Banda Music
children.description: Music of the Banda people, a Central African ethnic group mostly residing in the Central African Republic and its neighboring countries.

children.name: Bend-skin
children.description: Most closely linked to the Bamileke people of the Western Province of Cameroon; drums and improvised maracas are the sole instrumentation backing up a vocalist who alternates between rapping and singing.

children.name: Bikutsi
children.description: Developed from the Traditional Folk Music of the Ewondo people in Cameroon, with a name translating as "let's beat the earth" that comes from the stomping dance style that often accompanies it.

children.name: Congolese Rumba
children.description: Originated when Congolese musical acts started to play music influenced by Cuban Music (specifically Son cubano), with it's heyday period being between the 1940s to early 1970s.

children.name: Kalindula
children.description: Features multiple rumba-like lead guitars and quick steady basslines, while mixing together elements of other percussion-heavy Zambian styles.

children.name: Kilapanga
children.description: Tradition of the Bakongo people from Angola and Congo that has influenced contemporary styles such as Kuduro.

children.name: Kizomba
children.description: Combines elements of Angolan Semba and French Caribbean Zouk.

children.name: Tarraxinha
children.description: Heavy-hitting beats and electronic bass, putting less emphasis on melodies and vocals.

children.name: Kuduro
children.description: Angolan music combining traditional Kilapanga and Semba with Techno and House.

children.name: Batida
children.description: Initially developed in the late '80s in Luanda, Angola, as a mixture of Soca- and Zouk-based percussion samples.

children.name: Makossa
children.description: Similar to Soukous, but makes more use of a horn section and bass rhythm.

children.name: Mbenga-Mbuti Music
children.description: Music of the Mbenga and Mbuti people, Pygmy ethnic groups in Central Africa.

children.name: Puxa
children.description: Energetic dance style that combines solid bass lines with subtle melodies and harmonies of São Toméan music.

children.name: Semba
children.description: Style from Angola featuring danceable percussion, lyrics often taking the form of a story, and sometimes accompaniment from a guitar.

children.name: Soukous
children.description: Danceable, guitar-based style from the Congo area.

children.name: Kwassa kwassa
children.description: Faster form of Soukous that was pioneered in the late 1980s and early 1990s, named after a popular dance.

children.name: Tradi-Modern
children.description: Updates traditional Congolese music with electric instrumentation.

children.name: Twa Music
children.description: Music of the Great Lakes Twa people.

children.name: Zamrock
children.description: Zambian 1970s Psychedelic Rock found mainly throughout the Copperbelt region.

children.name: East African Music
children.description: Traditions which originate from the eastern subregion of the African continent, encompassing a wide variety of cultures and styles.

children.name: Benga
children.description: Kenyan popular music based around the Traditional Folk Music of the Luo people from the area.

children.name: Bongo Flava
children.description: Tanzanian genre originating in the mid-1990s in the Dar es Salaam area, combining the influence of Rhythm & Blues, Afrobeat, and Dancehall with native Tanzanian styles like Taarab and Muziki wa dansi.

children.name: Comorian Music
children.description: Music of the Comoros Islands and Mayotte off the eastern coast of Africa, combining influences from other East African Music and Malagasy Music.

children.name: Dinka Music
children.description: Music of the Dinka people, the most populous ethnic group of South Sudan.

children.name: Genge
children.description: Combines elements of Dancehall with various traditions of Kenya.

children.name: Gengetone
children.description: Takes strong influence from Reggaetón and modern Dancehall, featuring more explicit lyrics and harder beats.

children.name: Gogo Music
children.description: Music of the Gogo People (Wagogo), who inhabit Central Tanzania.

children.name: Inkiranya
children.description: Influential drumming style originating in Burundi carried out by a percussion ensemble.

children.name: Kadongo kamu
children.description: Oldest form of mainstream music in Uganda, dating back to the early 1950s, translating to “one little guitar” from the Luganda language.

children.name: Kapuka
children.description: Includes elements from Hip Hop and Reggae, as well as Kenyan traditions.

children.name: Kidandali
children.description: Popular form of Ugandan music, originally derived from Kadongo kamu and Soukous.

children.name: Kidumbak
children.description: Centered on two small kidumbak drums, fiddle, and singer; closely related to Taarab.

children.name: Marrabenta
children.description: Fast, guitar driven, urban dance music from Mozambique that originated in Maputo in the 1950s, taking cues from Mozambican folk and a variety of foreign sounds.

children.name: Mchiriku
children.description: Pairs amplified keyboards with hectic, intricate percussion and vocals drawn from earlier Tanzanian styles.

children.name: Muziki wa dansi
children.description: Popular in Tanzania with strong connections to Soukous and often associated with Jazz, whose name means "dance music" in Swahili.

children.name: Ngoma
children.description: Played in Swahili-speaking African countries; primarily focused on rhythm.

children.name: Unyago
children.description: Traditional music from Zanzibar, traditionally played at women's initiation rituals and weddings.

children.name: Omutibo
children.description: Mid-20th century Kenyan popular music which centres around a fingerpicked acoustic guitar.

children.name: Shilluk Music
children.description: All musical forms of the Shilluk people of the Upper Nile region of South Sudan.

children.name: Singeli
children.description: Developed in Tanzania in the mid-2000s; fuses incredibly rapid beats, usually between 180-300BPM, with MCing and musical influences from older Tanzanian genres.

children.name: Taarab
children.description: Prominent violin, qanun (an Egyptian zither-like instrument), and sung Swahili poetry, often accompanied by African drums and other percussion.

children.name: Timbila
children.description: Tradition of the Chopi people of the Inhambane province of Mozambique, named for the mbila, the wooden xylophone-like instrument on which it is played.

children.name: Twa Music
children.description: Music of the Great Lakes Twa people.

children.name: Malagasy Music
children.description: Music of Madagascar, including the most distinctive genres of the whole African continent.

children.name: Kalon'ny fahiny
children.description: Fusion of music from the highlands of Madagascar and western Operetta.

children.name: Malagasy Folk Music
children.description: Melodic, chordophone-dominated sound; based on the Austronesian Traditional Music of the first settlers that arrived on the island from Borneo.

children.name: Salegy
children.description: Features rich, harmonized vocals and chiming guitar lines.

children.name: Tsapiky
children.description: Very fast and jerky rhythms, guitar duets, and polyharmonic chants.

children.name: North African Music
children.description: Music of North Africa.

children.name: Aita
children.description: Arabic Folk Music from rural Morocco with piercing singing, scratchy viola, and rollicking hand drums.

children.name: Algerian Chaabi
children.description: Originates from the capital of Algeria, Algiers and features mournful vocals over an orchestral setting of violins, mandolins, pianos, and percussion.

children.name: Amazigh Music
children.description: Music of the Amazigh people, the indigenous people of Northwest Africa (with main hubs in Morocco and Algeria) and certain parts of West Africa.

children.name: Ahwash
children.description: Associated with the Tashelhit-speaking peoples of southern and central Morocco, and performed in large groups, combining singing, poetry and drumming.

children.name: Izlan
children.description: Uses sung poetry with a focus on love themes.

children.name: Kabyle Music
children.description: Music of the Kabyle Amazigh people.

children.name: Sahrawi Music
children.description: Music of the Sahrawi people, an ethnic group who inhabit the westernmost areas of the Sahara Desert.

children.name: Staïfi
children.description: Festive Chaoui genre that mixes local rural music with the zendali rhythm and modern instruments.

children.name: Tuareg Music
children.description: Amazigh Music by the nomadic Tuareg people who live through the Saharan desert in North Africa, encompassing various types of traditions and popular styles.

children.name: Takamba
children.description: Traditionally performed with a singer only accompanied by a guitar named tehardent, handclaps as percussion, and dancers; now usually performed by a band consisting of two tehardents, bass and solo, calabashes, a singer and dancers.

children.name: Tishoumaren
children.description: Electric guitar-led North African music emerging from traditional Tuareg Music in the 1980s.

children.name: Ancient Egyptian Music
children.description: Music of ancient Egyptian civilization.

children.name: Andalusian Classical Music
children.description: Found primarily in the Andalusia region in southern Spain, generally thought to have beginnings in the Emirate of Cordoba during the period of Muslim control of the region in the 9th century.

children.name: Coptic Music
children.description: Church music specifically made for worship in the Coptic (Egyptian) Orthodox Church.

children.name: Gnawa
children.description: Mixture of Sub-Saharan African, Arabic, and Amazigh Music, created by the Gnawa, an ethnic minority group in North Africa, mainly Morocco.

children.name: Malhun
children.description: Moroccan sung poetry with instrumental accompaniment.

children.name: Moorish Music
children.description: Music of the Moors, the largest ethnic group in Mauritania.

children.name: Moroccan Chaabi
children.description: Upbeat style of Moroccan popular music played in streets, cafés, weddings, and festivals.

children.name: Raï
children.description: Originated in Algeria in the 1930s as a form of Bedoin Traditional Folk Music, blending influences from various rural and urban genres.

children.name: Pop Raï
children.description: Fuses melodic sensibilities into the traditional Raï structure, with increased utilization of synthesizers, guitars, and drum machines.

children.name: Traditional Raï
children.description: Original folk of the popular Algerian Raï, combining various rural and cabaret styles with Bedouin rhythms.

children.name: Shaabi
children.description: Developed in Northern Africa during the early 1970s, typically created by and for the urban working class with witty lyrics that reflect this.

children.name: Mahraganat
children.description: Draws elements from Hip Hop, featuring auto-tuned vocals, rapping, Electronic production, and explicit lyrics.

children.name: Trap shaabi
children.description: Combining Trap percussion and rhythms with major influences of Egyptian Shaabi, especially Mahraganat.

children.name: Northeastern African Music
children.description: Music of Northeastern Africa.

children.name: Dinka Music
children.description: Music of the Dinka people, the most populous ethnic group of South Sudan.

children.name: Ethiopic Music
children.description: Music made by people who speak Ethiopian Semitic languages.

children.name: Azmari
children.description: Ethiopian/Eritrean singer/songwriters or minstrels equivalent to the Western European bard, the West African griot or the Romanian wandering taraf.

children.name: Ethio-Jazz
children.description: Unique blend of traditional Ethiopic Music and Jazz.

children.name: Ethiopian Church Music
children.description: Sacred tradition of the Ethiopian Orthodox Tewahedo Church, sung in an ancient Semitic language called Ge'ez and credited with assembling the current Ethiopian notation system.

children.name: Manzuma
children.description: Melodic, devotional music performed by Sufi Islami communities in Ethiopia and neighboring countries

children.name: Tigrinya Music
children.description: Music of the Tigrinya, an ethnic group mainly found in Eritrea and Northern Ethiopia, the Tigray region more specifically.

children.name: Tizita
children.description: Melancholy song popular in Ethiopia and Eritrea, using the qegnet mode and tuning system.

children.name: Nubian Music
children.description: Music of Nubia, a region centered along the Nile River in northern Sudan and southern Egypt.

children.name: Nuer Music
children.description: Music of the Nuer people of Eastern South Sudan and Western Ethiopia.

children.name: Oromo Music
children.description: Music of the Oromo people, a Cushitic ethnolinguistic group, who primarily live in the Oromia region of Ethiopia and Northern Kenya.

children.name: Shilluk Music
children.description: All musical forms of the Shilluk people of the Upper Nile region of South Sudan.

children.name: Somali Music
children.description: Music developed by the Somali people.

children.name: Belwo
children.description: Somali poems characterized by themes of love and romance, characterized by brief, syncopated tunes.

children.name: Dhaanto
children.description: Song and dance that originally featured no instruments, but later transformed into a style featuring prominent rhythms and slow grooves.

children.name: Qaraami
children.description: Dates back to the 1940s and carries regional features such as the use of a pentatonic scale and having the oud as the primary instrument.

children.name: Seychelles & Mascarene Islands Music
children.description: Styles from La Réunion, Mauritius, Rodrigues, and Seychelles.

children.name: Maloya
children.description: Originated in slave communities on La Réunion; based on a call and response structure and use of traditional instruments.

children.name: Maloya élektrik
children.description: Prominent in La Réunion island from the 1970s until the 1990s; drew influences from Funk, Psychedelia, and Afrobeat.

children.name: Traditional Maloya
children.description: Derived from Traditional Séga, this is the original dance music of La Réunion.

children.name: Moutya
children.description: Tradition that originated in Seychelles among Creole slaves, similar to Séga, although rawer and played only on large flat drums made from goatskin.

children.name: Santé engagé
children.description: Emerged in Mauritius in the 1970s, blending the popular Séga style with outside influences.

children.name: Séga
children.description: Mascarene Islands and Seychelles genre featuring a distinctive 6/8 rhythm.

children.name: Seggae
children.description: Fusion of Séga and Reggae, popular on Mauritius and other Mascarene Islands.

children.name: Traditional Séga
children.description: Séga dance music born in the 18th century, before its later adoption of Western pop elements.

children.name: Southern African Music
children.description: Encompasses Southern African Folk Music and more modern genres, consisting in a specific style of a worldwide popular genre mixed with or rooted in a local traditional folk genre, through South Africa, Lesotho, Botswana, Eswatini, Namibia, southern Angola, and Matabeleland region in southern Zimbabwe.

children.name: Amapiano
children.description: House from South Africa deriving from previous popular genres including Gqom, Kwaito, and Deep House.

children.name: Afropiano
children.description: Blends the easy-going, poppy, and melodic Afrobeats sound and rhythms with major Amapiano elements, like lush, jazzy, and laid-back atmospheres often featuring light piano chords.

children.name: Bulawayo Jazz
children.description: Emerged from the city of Bulawayo, Zimbabwe in the early 1950s, led by the alto sax and accompanied by ensembles.

children.name: Cape Jazz
children.description: Developed parallel to American Jazz in the early 20th century, named for its origin in Cape Town, South Africa.

children.name: Chimurenga
children.description: Popular style from Zimbabwe based on the traditional mbira thumb piano, but with electric instrumentation as well.

children.name: Famo
children.description: Popular and danceable style from Lesotho and the surrounding Sotho-speaking region of South Africa, often featuring the accordion as the lead instrument.

children.name: Gqom
children.description: Evolved from South African House, specifically Kwaito; often described as a more minimal and raw version.

children.name: Isicathamiya
children.description: A cappella Zulu style, which takes a softer, more melodious approach, in contrast to the powerful, loud sound of the earlier Mbube style.

children.name: Jit
children.description: Guitar-driven electric pop from Zimbabwe that draws influence from Central and East African rumba, South African jive and local music.

children.name: Kwaito
children.description: Emerged from South Africa in the early 1990s, taking influence from Disco and Hip Hop.

children.name: Marabi
children.description: South African Jazz with origins in the 1920s and rooted in traditional South African music.

children.name: Kwela
children.description: Influenced by Zulu music, characterized by its happy melodies, played by pennywhistle flutes and accompanied by a banjo or a guitar.

children.name: Mbaqanga
children.description: Emerged from the traditional Marabi Jazz and Swing as well as Kwela popular South African genres.

children.name: Maskandi
children.description: Zulu style of music usually led by a fingerpicked acoustic guitar.

children.name: Mbube
children.description: A cappella Zulu genre, performed in a powerful and loud manner by an all-male choir.

children.name: Shangaan Electro
children.description: South African genre with very fast BPM (around 180) featuring MIDI keyboard sounds and marimba.

children.name: Southern African Folk Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of southern Africa.

children.name: Afrikaner Folk Music
children.description: Musical traditions developed by the Afrikaner community in southern Africa.

children.name: Khoisan Folk Music
children.description: Encompasses traditions of the Khoisan ethnic family groups.

children.name: Nguni Folk Music
children.description: Traditions of the Nguni ethnic family groups, a southern Bantu ethnicity.

children.name: Shona Mbira Music
children.description: Traditional style of the Shona people from Zimbabwe, based on a simple melodic pattern played on the mbira, from which long instrumental parts are improvised.

children.name: Sotho-Tswana Folk Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of the Sotho-Tswana ethnic family groups from southern Africa.

children.name: Sungura
children.description: Zimbabwean style combining the guitar work of Soukous with the speed and texture of Benga and the strong bass of Township Jive.

children.name: Township Bubblegum
children.description: Synth-heavy Dance-Pop style popular in the South African townships in the 1980s and early 1990s.

children.name: Township Jive
children.description: Originating in the townships of South Africa, similar to Mbaqanga but bringing in Western pop elements.

children.name: Tsonga Disco
children.description: Drum machines, synthesizers, and male vocals backed by a female choir, singing in a call and response style.

children.name: West African Music
children.description: Traditional and regional popular music from the Western portion of Sub-Saharan Africa.

children.name: Afrobeat
children.description: Merges West African styles such as traditional Yoruba Music and Highlife with elements of Funk and  Jazz, typically resulting in extended improvisatory jams with call-and-response vocals.

children.name: Afro-Funk
children.description: Strongly mixed with traditional and more modern genres in sub-Saharan West Africa.

children.name: Afro-Rock
children.description: Incorporates West African influences; initially emerged in the early 1970s.

children.name: Akan Music
children.description: Music of the Akan people of Ghana and Côte d'Ivoire, including a variety of traditional and neo-traditional styles which are based on some of the oldest traditions in West Africa.

children.name: Zoblazo
children.description: Ivorian dance music combining traditional instruments and synthesizers that emerged in the late 1980s.

children.name: Balani Show
children.description: Emerged in the late 1990s in Mali; peaks at around 170BPM and prominently features looping, cut-up balafon samples.

children.name: Dagomba Music
children.description: Music of the Dagomba people of northern Ghana.

children.name: Ewe Music
children.description: Music of the Ewe people, found in southern Togo, southeastern Ghana and southwestern Benin.

children.name: Agbadza
children.description: National dance-drumming tradition of the Ewe people in Ghana.

children.name: Agbekor
children.description: War dance of the Ewe people utilizing various percussive instruments and polyrhythms.

children.name: Fon Music
children.description: The traditions of the Fon people, originating in central and southeastern Benin as well as the southwestern region of Nigeria.

children.name: Tchinkoumé
children.description: Tradition from the central region of Benin around Savalou, played with water percussion.

children.name: Tchink System
children.description: Urban version of Tchinkoumé featuring traditional tchinkoumé rhythms, derived from zinli, and including contemporary instrumentation from the influence of R&B, Pop and Rock.

children.name: Zinli
children.description: Traditional rhythmic chanting and percussion adapted to multiple West African contexts in the 20th century.

children.name: Fula Music
children.description: Music of the Fula, Fulani, or Fulɓe people, one of the largest ethnic groups in the Sahel region, present from the far West African countries of Senegal and Mauritania to Central African Cameroon with the biggest population located in Nigeria.

children.name: Griot Music
children.description: Type of hereditary professional caste in West African Music culture that preserves tradition.

children.name: Gumbe
children.description: Vocal and percussive tradition from Guinea-Bissau developed in the 1970s as a fusion of various traditional genres in the country; sometimes used as a catch-all term for the music of Guinea-Bissau in general.

children.name: Hausa Music
children.description: Hausa are one of the largest ethnic groups in Africa, living mainly in northern Nigeria and southern Niger in west Africa.

children.name: Highlife
children.description: Originally began along the Ghanaian coast in the 1920s as a blend of western brass band instrumentation and rhythms with traditional Akan Music and Dagomba Music.

children.name: Burger-Highlife
children.description: Created by Ghanian immigrants to Germany in the late 1970s, generally employing synthesizers and Western post-production techniques alongside guitar-driven highlife instrumentation.

children.name: Hipco
children.description: Developed in Liberia, often featuring conscious and political lyrics and influences from local dance styles.

children.name: Hiplife
children.description: Fusion of Ghanaian Highlife with Hip Hop.

children.name: Igbo Music
children.description: Music of the Igbo people, who live mainly in a region of southeastern Nigeria often known as "Igboland".

children.name: Kabye Folk Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of the Kabye people of northern Togo, including some of the most singular styles that can be found in West Africa.

children.name: Kru Music
children.description: Music of the Kru peoples indigenous to Liberia and Ivory Coast.

children.name: Alloukou
children.description: Created by the Bété people of Côte d'Ivoire, featuring a distinctive rhythm that uses polyrhythms and triplets.

children.name: Palm Wine Music
children.description: Fusion of the African Folk Music of the region with imported Caribbean Calypso.

children.name: Ziglibithy
children.description: Ivorian mid-1970s dance music created after the country's independence, influenced by post-colonial trends in African Music.

children.name: Mande Music
children.description: Encompasses the diverse forms of the Mande peoples, a group of West African ethnic groups who speak any of the Mande languages.

children.name: Mossi Music
children.description: Music of the Mossi people of Burkina Faso.

children.name: Songhai Music
children.description: Music of the Songhai people of Mali, who descend from the ancient Songhai Empire which once ruled most of interior West Africa.

children.name: Wassoulou
children.description: Traditionally sung by women and containing lyrics relating to women's issues such as childbearing and fertility.

children.name: Wolof Music
children.description: Music of the Wolof people of Senegal and The Gambia comprising a wide variety of West African Music traditions influenced by nearby cultures.

children.name: Mbalax
children.description: Rooted in njuup, a Serer ritual tradition incorporating influences from Cuban, Congolese, and American popular music.

children.name: Tassu
children.description: Rhythmic poetry that has been a part of Senegalese culture since ancient times.

children.name: Yoruba Music
children.description: Music of the Yoruba people of southwestern Nigeria and Benin, comprising a variety of ancient and modern traditions crucial to West African Music.

children.name: Apala
children.description: Yoruba Music developed by Muslims during the late 1930s and early 1940s in the Ijebu region of Yorubaland, the current Ogun state.

children.name: Fuji
children.description: Combines the ajisaari/wéré tradition of improvisational music performed during Ramadan with other Islamic styles like Apala and sakara.

children.name: Jùjú
children.description: Yoruba Music that emerged during the 1920s in urban settings across Nigeria, especially in Lagos.

children.name: Santería Music
children.description: Afro-Cuban genre played in religious rituals, combining traditions from both the Cuban and the Yorùbá people.

children.name: Waka
children.description: Islamic Yoruba Music originally rooted in Hausa traditions and adopted by the Yoruba in the early 19th century.

children.name: Yoruba Folk Opera
children.description: Musical play involving traditional and popular music.

children.name: Zouglou
children.description: Ivorian dance music that began in the early 1990s, with socially conscious lyrics and driving rhythms.

children.name: Coupé-décalé
children.description: Bass-heavy and minimal style of Ivorian popular dance music, drawing heavily from Zouglou and Congolese rhythms.

name: Ancient Music
description: Umbrella term encompassing all the genres coming after the Prehistoric Music and before the Medieval music eras from ancient civilizations, roughly before 500 CE, following the Western Classical Music point of view with the date of the Roman Empire fall (476 CE).

children.name: Ancient Chinese Music
children.description: Covers a very large era of creation from approximately 2100 BCE to 200 CE.

children.name: Ancient Egyptian Music
children.description: Music of ancient Egyptian civilization.

children.name: Ancient Greek Music
children.description: Music of ancient Greek civilization.

children.name: Ancient Levitical Music
children.description: Reconstruction of Jerusalem temple music.

children.name: Ancient Roman Music
children.description: Music of ancient Roman civilization.

children.name: Hyang-ak
children.description: One of the most common and oldest surviving forms of Korean court music.

children.name: Mesopotamian Music
children.description: Music of Mesopotamia, a historical region situated in West Asia within the Tigris–Euphrates river system, comprises the heritage of Sumerians and Akkadians.

name: Arabic Music
description: Originating with and primarily performed by the Arabic people.

children.name: Algerian Chaabi
children.description: Originates from the capital of Algeria, Algiers and features mournful vocals over an orchestral setting of violins, mandolins, pianos, and percussion.

children.name: Arabic Classical Music
children.description: Arabic Classical Music tradition, whose guidelines for modulation, rhythm, and tuning were set down in treatises in the 8th and 9th centuries, based around Islamic Modal Music.

children.name: Andalusian Classical Music
children.description: Found primarily in the Andalusia region in southern Spain, generally thought to have beginnings in the Emirate of Cordoba during the period of Muslim control of the region in the 9th century.

children.name: Iraqi Maqam
children.description: Highly structured but semi-improvised and rhythmically complex compositions built around set structures which consist of specific maqam modes.

children.name: Sawt
children.description: Poetic vocal form with complex rhythms, emotive singing, and distinctive lute-backed melodies commonly found in the Gulf region and based on a maqam system.

children.name: Arabic Folk Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of the Arabic people.

children.name: Aita
children.description: Arabic Folk Music from rural Morocco with piercing singing, scratchy viola, and rollicking hand drums.

children.name: Arabic Bellydance Music
children.description: Accompaniment to traditional belly dances.

children.name: Fijiri
children.description: Deeply rooted in the Persian Gulf pearl diving culture, and sung during weekly gatherings combining solo and choral sections with minimal percussion.

children.name: Arabic Jazz
children.description: Blending of Arabic Music and Jazz.

children.name: Arabic Pop
children.description: Synthesis of Arabic Music with Western Pop melodies, almost always sung in Arabic and typically performed with Arabic instruments, alongside some Western instruments like the guitar.

children.name: Al Jeel
children.description: Emerged in the 1970s as an alternative to Shaabi, taking influence from foreign Pop and incorporating rhythms of Reggae while retaining a distinctly Egyptian sound.

children.name: Bedouin Music
children.description: Music made by the Bedouin, nomadic Arab tribes that have historically inhabited desert regions all across the Arab world.

children.name: Levantine Arabic Music
children.description: The musical traditions of the Levantine Arabs, roughly covering the Arabic people of the modern countries of Israel, Jordan, Lebanon, Palestine, and Syria.

children.name: Dabke
children.description: Fast-paced dance and music style, most commonly performed in the Levant.

children.name: Druze Music
children.description: Musical traditions of the Druze people.

children.name: Orkes gambus
children.description: Indonesian songs based on Arabic hits, adapted for a small ensemble featuring the gambus lute, percussion, and electric instruments.

children.name: Raï
children.description: Originated in Algeria in the 1930s as a form of Bedoin Traditional Folk Music, blending influences from various rural and urban genres.

children.name: Pop Raï
children.description: Fuses melodic sensibilities into the traditional Raï structure, with increased utilization of synthesizers, guitars, and drum machines.

children.name: Traditional Raï
children.description: Original folk of the popular Algerian Raï, combining various rural and cabaret styles with Bedouin rhythms.

children.name: Shaabi
children.description: Developed in Northern Africa during the early 1970s, typically created by and for the urban working class with witty lyrics that reflect this.

children.name: Mahraganat
children.description: Draws elements from Hip Hop, featuring auto-tuned vocals, rapping, Electronic production, and explicit lyrics.

children.name: Traditional Arabic Pop
children.description: Popular music of the Arab world from the first half of the 20th century, with little Western influence; melodic lines are taken from Arabic Folk Music and Arabic Classical Music, and strong emphasis is placed on vocal abilities; single works often include long stretches of singing accompanied by large symphonic string ensembles.

children.name: Trap shaabi
children.description: Combining Trap percussion and rhythms with major influences of Egyptian Shaabi, especially Mahraganat.

name: Asian Music
description: Rooted in the traditions of Asian peoples.

children.name: Central Asian Music
children.description: Music of the former Soviet Central Asian republics, Mongolia, Western China and related neighbouring peoples.

children.name: Altai Traditional Music
children.description: Traditions of the Altai people, an ethnic group who live in central Russia near the border of Mongolia and Kazakhstan.

children.name: Balochi Music
children.description: Music of the Baloch people.

children.name: Bashkir Folk Music
children.description: Traditional folk of the Bashkir people, a Turkic ethnic group inhabiting the Republic of Bashkortostan (Bashkiria), a federal subject of the Russian Federation, and its neighboring areas on both sides of the Ural mountains.

children.name: Burushaski Folk Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of the Burusho people of northern Pakistan.

children.name: Buryat Folk Music
children.description: Traditional music of the Buryat people, a Mongolic ethnic group inhabiting the Republic of Buryatia, a federal subject of the Russian Far East region.

children.name: Central Asian Throat Singing
children.description: Shared polyphonic vocal tradition of Mongolia and southern Siberia characterised by complex manipulation of harmonics.

children.name: Mongolian Throat Singing
children.description: Traditional music from Mongolia characterized by many throat singing techniques.

children.name: Tuvan Throat Singing
children.description: Traditional style of singing found in Tuva, an autonomous region of the Russian Federation situated in southern Siberia.

children.name: Hazara Folk Music
children.description: Folk music of the Hazara people, mainly native to central Afghanistan.

children.name: Karakalpak Traditional Music
children.description: Traditions of the Karakalpak people, located in northwestern Uzbekistan.

children.name: Kazakh Music
children.description: Music of the Kazakhs.

children.name: Khakas Traditional Music
children.description: Traditions of the Khakas Republic (part of the Russian Federation), a form of Turkic music related to the musics of neighboring Tuva, Altai and Mongolia.

children.name: Kyrgyz Traditional Music
children.description: Traditions of Kyrgyzstan, a mountainous nation in Central Asia.

children.name: Mongolian Music
children.description: Music of the Mongols.

children.name: Bogino duu
children.description: Mongolian Music with tuneful composition and simple structure.

children.name: Kalmyk Music
children.description: Music of the Kalmyks, a Mongol Buddhist ethnic group inhabiting the Republic of Kalmykia, a federal subject of the Russian Federation.

children.name: Mongolian Throat Singing
children.description: Traditional music from Mongolia characterized by many throat singing techniques.

children.name: Urtiin duu
children.description: Mongolian tradition in which sung syllables are extended into long, meditational, vibrato notes called shuranhai; accompanied by traditional Mongolian instruments such as the morin khuur and limbe.

children.name: Zohioliin duu
children.description: Mixes modern Pop with Mongolian Music, using local and western instruments.

children.name: Pamiri Music
children.description: Music of the Pamiri people native to the Badakhshan region in the Pamir Mountains.

children.name: Falak
children.description: Songs that reflect the state of living for those indigenous to the Pamir mountains ranges, often sung in high registers.

children.name: Pashto Folk Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of the Pashtun people of southern Afghanistan and north-western Pakistan.

children.name: Shashmaqam
children.description: Modal suite that brings together lyrical and instrumental songs, poetry, and dance shared by Tajik Music and Uzbek Music.

children.name: Sufiana kalam
children.description: Classical music of the Kashmir region, the northernmost part of the Indian subcontinent.

children.name: Tajik Music
children.description: Music of the Tajik people.

children.name: Tibetan Music
children.description: Traditional and modern music of the Tibetan peoples, mainly produced in Tibet and also practiced in Bhutan, Nepal, and northern India, and influential on the traditions of Burma.

children.name: Zhabdro gorgom
children.description: Lively, rhythmic and informal Bhutanese folk music of Tibetan origin.

children.name: Turkmen Music
children.description: Music of the Turkmen people.

children.name: Uyghur Music
children.description: Music of the Uyghur people native to Xinjiang in western China.

children.name: Uzbek Music
children.description: Music of the Uzbek people.

children.name: East Asian Music
children.description: Covers the different forms of music with origins in Japan, Korea, China, Taiwan, and Vietnam.

children.name: Ainu Music
children.description: Music of the Ainu people from Hokkaidō, the Kuril Islands, and part of Sakhalin.

children.name: Upopo
children.description: Ainu everyday traditional song (as opposed to Yukar's sacred leanings).

children.name: Yukar
children.description: Oral literature pertaining to Ainu culture and mythology.

children.name: Chinese Music
children.description: Music of the Chinese people, which is primarily derived from the culture of the Han Chinese.

children.name: Ancient Chinese Music
children.description: Covers a very large era of creation from approximately 2100 BCE to 200 CE.

children.name: Campus Folk
children.description: Born in Taiwan in the mid-1970s, this movement originated with university students creating their own modern-style songs in the wake of international tensions like Taiwan's isolation from the United Nations and the United States' embrace of the PRC as a diplomatic partner.

children.name: Chinese Classical Music
children.description: Classical Music of China, encompassing royal court music as well as the Chinese Opera musical theatre traditions.

children.name: Baisha xiyue
children.description: Mainly performed for funeral ceremonies of the Naxi ethnic group in the Yunnan province in China.

children.name: Chinese Opera
children.description: Traditional Chinese theatre, existing in several regional variations, combining traditional instruments and vocals along with other art forms like Poetry, dance, acrobatics, and martial arts.

children.name: Cantonese Opera
children.description: Chinese Opera that are sung in Cantonese.

children.name: Henan Opera
children.description: Originated in the central Chinese province of Henan, known for its fast-paced, easy to understand dialogue, high pitched singing and strong rhythm.

children.name: Peking Opera
children.description: Distinguishable from most types of Chinese opera by its instrumentation, 2 distinct types of melodies, and alternative Chinese pronunciation.

children.name: Korean Revolutionary Opera
children.description: Heavily influenced by Chinese Revolutionary Opera and supported by the North Korean government.

children.name: Revolutionary Opera
children.description: Popular during China's Cultural Revolution and upholds China's working class and the People's Liberation Army as the forces that brought socialism to China.

children.name: Shaoxing Opera
children.description: Exclusively performed by women in modern times with a focus on lyricism.

children.name: Yangzhou Opera
children.description: Originated in Yangzhou, and popular in some parts of Jiangsu and Anhui province, as well as Shanghai.

children.name: Dongjing
children.description: Chinese Taoist ritual music from the Nakhi (Naxi) people, historically performed around Yunnan and Sichuan.

children.name: Yayue
children.description: Incorporates folk and religious traditions of Chinese Music; literally translated as 'elegant music'.

children.name: Chinese Folk Music
children.description: Traditional folk of the Chinese people.

children.name: Han Folk Music
children.description: Chinese folk form often played at weddings and funerals, using the Suona (a form of oboe) and Chuigushou (a specific type of percussive ensemble), together with heterophony.

children.name: Jiangnan sizhu
children.description: Played by a varying ensemble of several different types of stringed instruments, flutes, small percussion instruments, and mouth organs.

children.name: Shan’ge
children.description: Work Songs sung by Chinese agricultural workers.

children.name: Minyue
children.description: Modernized composition for Chinese instruments on the basis of Chinese Folk Music, incorporating aspects of Western Classical Music.

children.name: Quyi
children.description: Category of traditional Chinese storytelling, featuring a narrative structure and a combination of speaking and singing.

children.name: Shidaiqu
children.description: Fusion of Chinese popular music and Jazz that began in the 1920s in Shanghai.

children.name: Xinyao
children.description: Singaporean Mandarin-language style, generally featuring harmonised group vocals and backed mainly by acoustic guitar.

children.name: Zhongguo feng
children.description: Inspired by traditional elements of Chinese Music with lyrical themes constantly revolving around Chinese culture and tales.

children.name: East Asian Classical Music
children.description: Covers all the forms of pan-East Asian Classical Music sharing origins in Chinese Classical Music.

children.name: Japanese Classical Music
children.description: Classical music of Japan.

children.name: Gagaku
children.description: One of the oldest forms of Japanese Classical Music, based on the pentatonic Yo scale, characterized by an elegant sound that is typically solemn, slow-paced, and resonant.

children.name: Heikyoku
children.description: Semi-classical bardic tradition in Japan analogous to the troubadour music of medieval Europe.

children.name: Honkyoku
children.description: Japanese Classical Music performed solo on a bamboo flute shakuhachi.

children.name: Jiuta
children.description: Originally created by solo performers singing and playing shamisen, but since the late 18th century increasingly often performed by sankyoku ensembles (shamisen, koto and shakuhachi or kokyu).

children.name: Jōruri
children.description: Consists of a singing narrator (tayū) with shamisen accompaniment.

children.name: Meiji shinkyoku
children.description: Meiji-era compositions, using a distinctive, brighter scale, usually performed with two kotos.

children.name: Nagauta
children.description: Japanese Classical Music used in Kabuki, a form of theatre oriented to dance-drama.

children.name: Noh
children.description: Played by an hayashi ensemble, consisting of a fue (flute), a kotsuzumi (shoulder drum), a ōtsuzumi (hip drum), and a taiko (stick drum).

children.name: Shōmyō
children.description: Japanese Buddhist chant that utilizes the yō scale.

children.name: Sōkyoku
children.description: Gained popularity during the Edo period, played with a koto or a guzheng and sometimes accompanied by shamisen and/or shakuhachi.

children.name: Danmono
children.description: Sōkyoku composed for koto, a thirteen-string traditional instrument.

children.name: Kumiuta
children.description: Typically performed by a single singer playing koto or less often shamisen for accompaniment, often with lyrics adapted from classical poetry.

children.name: Korean Classical Music
children.description: Classical Music of Korea.

children.name: Aak
children.description: Korean Classical Music that dates back to the early 12th century.

children.name: Dang-ak
children.description: Korean Classical Music that dates back to the Later Silla period of 668–935.

children.name: Hyang-ak
children.description: One of the most common and oldest surviving forms of Korean court music.

children.name: Jeong-ak
children.description: Also known as proper music; dates back to the Later Silla period of 668–935.

children.name: Gagok
children.description: Vocal songs derived from Korean Classical Music backed by a small orchestra of Jeong-ak ("aristocratic or proper music").

children.name: Vietnamese Classical Music
children.description: Traditional court music of Vietnam, often performed by a twelve-instrument ensemble (for Dai Nhac music) or a fourteen-instrument ensemble (for Nha Nhac music).

children.name: Ca trù
children.description: Sung poetry from northern Vietnam, performed by a female vocalist to the accompaniment of a three-stringed lute and percussion.

children.name: Vietnamese Opera
children.description: Classical musical theatre and its associated form of Vietnamese Classical Music, related strongly to Chinese Opera.

children.name: East Asian Folk Music
children.description: All the forms of Traditional Folk Music from East Asia, including Japanese Folk Music, Chinese Folk Music, and Korean Folk Music.

children.description: Tradition from the Amami Islands, located in southern Japan.

children.description: Semi-classical bardic tradition in Japan analogous to the troubadour music of medieval Europe.

children.name: Kagura
children.description: Performed at Shinto shrines for ceremonies and rituals.

children.name: Kouta
children.description: Kouta, which literally means "little" or "short" song, is one type of the many varieties of Japanese folk songs that is distinguished by its briefness and wittiness.

children.name: Min'yō
children.description: Form of Japanese Folk Music which literally translates to "folk song".

children.name: Ondō
children.description: Originally referred to the type of call-and-response form of Gagaku, but later became to be known for and distinguished by a swung 2/2 rhythm and storytelling.

children.name: Rōkyoku
children.description: Storytelling usually accompanied by a shamisen.

children.name: Taiko
children.description: Modern style of ensemble drumming, sometimes called kumi-daiko.

children.name: Tsugaru shamisen
children.description: Shamisen playing originating in the Tsugaru Peninsula of Aomori prefecture, recognizable in its percussive quality and special, slightly larger instrument.

children.name: Korean Folk Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of the Korean people.

children.name: Pansori
children.description: Korean style of storytelling characterized by over-the-top, passionate singing from a solo vocalist accompanied by minimal drumming.

children.name: Pungmul
children.description: Consists of drumming, dancing, and singing, and is a tradition deeply ingrained in South Korean culture.

children.name: Sanjo
children.description: Traditional instrumental Korean Folk Music that focuses on a wide variety of rhythmic changes with many different classical Korean instruments.

children.name: Sinawi
children.description: Improvisational genre traditionally serving as an accompaniment to Korean shamanic rituals.

children.name: Vietnamese Folk Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of the Vietnamese people, with traditions influenced by both Chinese Music and Austronesian culture through the Cham people.

children.name: Chèo
children.description: Northern Vietnamese folk musical theatre, characterized by minimal set design and satirical content.

children.name: Quan họ
children.description: Tradition of the Northern Vietnamese provinces of Bắc Ninh and Bắc Giang, originally consisting of harmonic, a cappella singing from two competing duos.

children.name: Xẩm
children.description: Developed in Northern Vietnam, traditionally sung by blind bards accompanied by a đàn bầu or đàn nhị.

children.description: Japanese meta-genre covers all forms of music, traditional or contemporary, rooted in Japanese Folk Music.

children.name: Burushaski Folk Music

children.name: Gujarati Folk Music

children.description: Traditional Folk Music of the Kannada people, a large ethnolinguistic group who mainly inhabit the state of Karnataka in southwestern India.

children.name: Kirtan
children.description: Call-and-response chanting that involves the singing of devotional mantras and hymns in a bhakti devotional style, occasionally accompanied with traditional folk instrumentation.

children.name: Shabad kirtan
children.description: Religious Sikh Hymns backed by specially selected ragas and taal.

children.name: Malayali Folk Music

children.name: Balinese Gamelan
children.description: Broad classification grouping various forms of Gamelan with native roots in Bali.

children.name: Gamelan angklung
children.description: Takes its name from the angklung, an instrument made of bamboo tubes.

children.name: Gamelan beleganjur
children.description: Loud, chaotic, highly percussive, and with heavy tempo changes.

children.name: Gamelan gender wayang
children.description: Performed with two/four metallophones made out of bronze keys with suspended bamboo tube resonators connected to them.

children.name: Gamelan gong gede
children.description: Ceremonial style characterized by a simpler and more melodic approach with clearer and more stable progressions compared to other Balinese orchestras.

children.name: Gamelan gong kebyar
children.description: Free compositional techniques and rapidly changing dynamics.

children.name: Gamelan jegog
children.description: Played entirely on marimba-like instruments made from bamboo which widely differ in size.

children.name: Gamelan selonding
children.description: Ensemble consists of four to six musicians playing metallophones made out of iron in a seven-tone scale.

children.name: Gamelan semar pegulingan
children.description: Originated in the 16th-17th centuries; features a soft, delicate, and ethereal sound.

children.name: Javanese Music
children.description: Music of the Javanese people.
