children.description: Folk music of Ossetians, an ethnic group that mainly inhabits a region located on both sides of the Greater Caucasus Mountains.

children.name: Karachay-Balkarian Music
children.description: Music of the Karachay and Balkar peoples of the Northwestern Caucasus, who reside in the republics of Karachay-Cherkessia and Kabardino-Balkaria.

children.name: Rabiz
children.description: Elements of Armenian folk in its instrumentation, oftentimes incorporating influences from Arabic and other West Asian forms on a background of synthesizer arrangements.

children.name: Iraqi Maqam
children.description: Highly structured but semi-improvised and rhythmically complex compositions built around set structures which consist of specific maqam modes.

children.name: Levantine Arabic Music
children.description: The musical traditions of the Levantine Arabs, roughly covering the Arabic people of the modern countries of Israel, Jordan, Lebanon, Palestine, and Syria.

children.name: Dabke
children.description: Fast-paced dance and music style, most commonly performed in the Levant.

children.name: Druze Music
children.description: Musical traditions of the Druze people.

children.name: Maftirim
children.description: Paraliturgical songs of Sephardi Jews who lived in Ottoman Empire.

children.name: Mesopotamian Music
children.description: Music of Mesopotamia, a historical region situated in West Asia within the Tigris–Euphrates river system, comprises the heritage of Sumerians and Akkadians.

children.name: Muzika mizrahit
children.description: Middle Eastern-flavored Israeli popular music, usually performed by Mizrahi Jews, and combining aspects of the music of the North African, Middle Eastern, and Central Asian countries from which they descended.

children.name: Persian Music
children.description: Music of the Persian people.

children.name: Bandari
children.description: Iranian dance music, often festive and energetic and set in 6/8, that traditionally makes primary use of Iranian bagpipes (ney-anbān).

children.name: Persian Classical Music
children.description: Traditional art music of the Persian civilization.

children.name: Persian Folk Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of the Persian people.

children.name: Persian Pop
children.description: Hybrid of Iranian and Persian-language popular music with Western instruments such as the guitar, drum kit, and synthesizer.

children.name: Turkish Music
children.description: Traditions developed by the Turkish people.

children.name: Anatolian Rock
children.description: Turkish Rock with elements of Turkish Folk Music.

children.name: Arabesk
children.description: Arabic-style productions by Turkish musicians, who also draw influence from their native forms, including Turkish Folk Music, Balkan Music, and Byzantine Music.

children.name: Fantezi
children.description: Incorporates influences from Turkish Classical Music and Turkish Folk Music within a more accessible, commercial, and unorthodox context.

children.name: Kanto
children.description: Songs performed at the Tuluat Theaters of İstanbul in the late 19th century.

children.name: Ottoman Military Music
children.description: Considered the oldest military marching band in the world; instruments used are cymbals, trumpet, kös drum, kettle drum, naqareh, bells, and cevgen.

children.name: Özgün Müzik
children.description: Expansion of Turkish Folk Music with overtones from contemporary genres.

children.name: Turkish Classical Music
children.description: Classical music of Turkey, which uses the makam modal system, with the primary emphasis often being on the singers, who are accompanied by small ensembles.

children.name: Turkish Mevlevi Music
children.description: Traditional music performed among Turkish practitioners of the Mevlevi order of Sufism.

children.name: Turkish Folk Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of Turkish people combines the distinct cultural heritages and traditions of Anatolian civilisations and former Ottoman territories.

children.name: Turkish Black Sea Region Folk Music
children.description: Folk of the Turkish people who inhabit the northern region by the Black Sea.

children.name: Uzun Hava
children.description: Semi-improvisational melodic structure in Turkish Folk Music.

children.name: Zeybek
children.description: Turkish Folk Music music and dance that originated with the Zeybek people during the Ottoman Empire period, with slow and asymmetrical rhythms.

children.name: Turkish Pop
children.description: Started in the late 1950s, when Turkish artists started to write their own lyrics to Western popular tunes.

children.name: West Asian Folk Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of West Asia, a region that covers much of what is commonly known in English as the Middle East (alternatively Southwestern Asia), includes the distinct but interconnected traditions of numerous ethnic groups.

children.name: Alevi Folk Music
children.description: Anatolian folk pioneered by Turkish poets and bards, connected to the Alevist heterodox Islamic tradition.

children.name: Armenian Folk Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of the Armenians, which is attested in historic Armenia since antiquity, with unique regional dialects unified by general melodic structure.

children.name: Kef Music
children.description: Dance-oriented Armenian American music with prominent presence of Anatolian instruments and folkloric melodies (often in the 10/8 meter) paired with novel lyrics relating to a variety of topics.

children.name: Assyrian Folk Music
children.description: Folk of the Assyrian or Syriac people, who are indigenous to the Upper Mesopotamian region roughly corresponding to ancient Assyria (which includes modern-day northern Iraq, northwestern Iran, northeastern Syria, and southeastern Turkey).

children.name: Fijiri
children.description: Deeply rooted in the Persian Gulf pearl diving culture, and sung during weekly gatherings combining solo and choral sections with minimal percussion.

children.name: Israeli Folk Music
children.description: Folk of the Jewish settlers of Eretz Yisra'el.

children.name: Kurdish Folk Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of the Kurds, an Iranian people who traditionally inhabit the mountainous region of the Middle East comprising southeastern Turkey, northern Iraq, northwestern Iran, and northeastern Syria.

children.name: Luri Folk Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of the Luri people of southwestern Iran.

children.name: Meyxana
children.description: Azerbaijani folk recitative genre.

children.name: Persian Folk Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of the Persian people.

children.name: Turkish Folk Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of Turkish people combines the distinct cultural heritages and traditions of Anatolian civilisations and former Ottoman territories.

children.name: Turkish Black Sea Region Folk Music
children.description: Folk of the Turkish people who inhabit the northern region by the Black Sea.

children.name: Uzun Hava
children.description: Semi-improvisational melodic structure in Turkish Folk Music.

children.name: Zeybek
children.description: Turkish Folk Music music and dance that originated with the Zeybek people during the Ottoman Empire period, with slow and asymmetrical rhythms.

name: Caribbean Music
description: Meta-genre covering all forms with roots in the Caribbean region.

children.name: Bachata
children.description: Romantic dance and accompanying music originating in the Dominican Republic, featuring arpeggiated chords in the melody.

children.name: Brukdown
children.description: Belizean Creole genre typified by the use of accordion, banjo, and a distinctive percussion section.

children.name: Bullerengue
children.description: Afro-Colombian popular genre which features a strong emphasis on rhythm and improvisation and a call-and-response format.

children.name: Calypso
children.description: Genre from Trinidad and Tobago featuring a brass section and percussion.

children.name: Calipso venezolano
children.description: Derived from Trinidadian Calypso, popular in the eastern region of Venezuela and associated with Carnival.

children.name: Spouge
children.description: Fusion of Calypso and Ska originating in Barbados during the 1960s and 70s.

children.name: Caribbean Folk Music
children.description: Meta-genre that covers the different forms of Traditional Folk Music from the Caribbean.

children.name: Bele
children.description: Drum-based folkdance with a strong Afro-influence, conducted by duos of dancers and accompanied by call-and-response singing, particularly popular in Martinique, Dominica and Trinidad and Tobago.

children.name: Benna
children.description: Traditional music of Antigua & Barbuda, using call-and-response and bawdy lyrics.

children.name: Bomba
children.description: Percussive style from Puerto Rico, generally considered to be derived from West Africa.

children.name: Fungi
children.description: Traditional Folk Music native to the Virgin Islands, named after a local dish which features a "mixed-up" flavor that can be compared to the style that combines Western instruments with local ones.

children.name: Garifuna Folk Music
children.description: Folk of Garifunas, Caribbean people born from escaped African slaves and local Caribbean natives.

children.name: Haitian Vodou Drumming
children.description: Form of rhythmic performance by Haitian Vodou practitioners, played at associated ceremonies.

children.name: Jibaro
children.description: Traditions of the mountain-dwelling jibaro people that live primarily in Puerto Rico.

children.name: Kitchen Dance Music
children.description: Cayman Islands music played during kitchen dance parties, centered around fiddle and percussion (handmade or kitchen grater) playing.

children.name: Mento
children.description: Jamaican folk originating in the late 19th century which brought together African and European elements, going on to influence the rhythm in Reggae.

children.name: Méringue
children.description: Haitian genre that dates back to the early 19th century; the roots of Compas.

children.name: Plena
children.description: Folk genre from Puerto Rico played with hand drums called panderetas.

children.name: Ripsaw
children.description: Indigenous style of the Turks and Caicos Islands, featuring a handsaw as the primary instrument.

children.name: Trinidadian Cariso
children.description: Trinidadian folk considered to be the precursor of Calypso, led by (mostly female) singers called chantwells, who sing derogatory lyrics to the sound of drums and guitars in a call-and-response manner in order to rebel against slaveowners.

children.name: Tumba
children.description: African-style percussion alongside Latin influences and often explicit lyrics.

children.name: Virgin Islander Cariso
children.description: Folk of the Virgin Islands, sung exclusively by women to the beat of one or two drums.

children.name: Champeta
children.description: Colombian genre heavily influenced by the traditional music of San Basilio de Palenque as well as modern Caribbean and African sensibilities.

children.name: Cuban Music
children.description: Encompasses the wide variety of traditions from the island of Cuba.

children.name: Chachachá
children.description: Ballroom dance music derived from Danzón.

children.name: Changüí
children.description: One of the oldest popular Cuban styles, originating in the 19th century with slaves that worked in sugar refineries near Baracoa who combined elements of Spanish popular songs with Bantu traditions.

children.name: Conga
children.description: Evolved alongside Rumba cubana in the late 19th century, featuring large and heterogenous percussion sections performing simple and syncopated rhythms alongside a small wind section.

children.name: Cuban Charanga
children.description: Played by traditional Cuban ensembles, influenced by Son cubano but performed on European instruments such as piano, bass, violins, and flutes.

children.name: Cubaton
children.description: Vocal delivery is often heavily auto-tuned and layered with adlibs, rhythm is syncopated, and Caribbean and African instrumentation is incorporated.

children.name: Danzón
children.description: Development on Habanera in 2/4 time, featuring African influence through complex cross-rhythms, that would become the most popular style of dance music in Cuba during the late 19th century and early 20th century.

children.name: Descarga
children.description: Cuban genre consisting of improvised jam sessions incorporating elements of Jazz and Afro-Cuban music.

children.name: Filin
children.description: Emotional style that appeared in La Habana during the late 1940s, deeply influenced by the melodic and expressive style of Vocal Jazz.

children.name: Guajira
children.description: Originally developed in Cuba between the 18th and 19th Century as a narrative style influenced by Tonada chilena.

children.name: Guaracha
children.description: Humorous song with short notes and a fast tempo that commonly alternates a short fourth line verse with a repeated fourth line chorus.

children.name: Habanera
children.description: Based around the Habanera rhythm, where the most typical instruments used are guitars, lutes, and bandurrias.

children.name: Mambo
children.description: Dance-oriented evolution from Danzón during the late 1930s.

children.name: Mozambique
children.description: Cuban genre featuring energetic, African-influenced percussion.

children.name: Pachanga
children.description: Combination of Merengue, Conga, Rumba cubana, and Cumbia; fast, festive, and playful.

children.name: Pilón
children.description: Featuring rhythms described as mimicking those created while pounding sugarcane with African baton-like tools.

children.name: Rumba cubana
children.description: Folkloric manifestation of Afro-Cuban music that encompasses dance, voice, and drums.

children.name: Guaguancó
children.description: Emerged after the abolition of slavery in Cuba in 1886; usually features a lead singer, accompanied by three large drums, known as tumbadoras or congas, and a call-and-response chorus.

children.name: Santería Music
children.description: Afro-Cuban genre played in religious rituals, combining traditions from both the Cuban and the Yorùbá people.

children.name: Son cubano
children.description: Cuban style popular from the 1920s to the 1950s that combines the structure of Spanish song-oriented styles with African rhythms and percussion.

children.name: Bolero son
children.description: Blend of Bolero and Son cubano that appeared during the 1920s.

children.name: Songo
children.description: Cuban style originating in the 1970s, combining elements from Rumba cubana and Son cubano with Jazz and Funk.

children.name: Timba
children.description: Combines Salsa with other genres such as Hip Hop, Disco, Funk, Jazz and Rock.

children.name: Trova
children.description: One of the most ancient expressions of Cuban Music, based around lone singer/songwriters who use nothing but a guitar as their preferred accompaniment and place emphasis on lyrics.

children.name: Nueva trova
children.description: Found inspiration in the 1950s Cuban Revolution and had the intention of introducing new musical ideas to the original Trova.

children.name: Tumba francesa
children.description: Combination of traditional music from Benin with French ballroom dancing that originates in the Oriente province (formerly Santiago de Cuba Province) in Cuba.

children.name: Dembow
children.description: Originated in the Dominican Republic during the early 1990s, featuring rapping indebted to Hip Hop and a style drawing on Dancehall, particularly the "Dem Bow" riddim.

children.name: French Caribbean Music
children.description: Music from the French Antilles (Martinique, Guadeloupe, Dominica, Saint Lucia) and from Haiti.

children.name: Biguine
children.description: Dating back to the 19th century; originating as a fusion of traditional Bele music with Polka.

children.name: Bouyon
children.description: With a name translating to "broth", this fast-paced genre from Dominica originated as a blend of various traditional and modern Caribbean styles.

children.name: Cadence Lypso
children.description: Caribbean genre originating in the 1970s, combining elements of Haiti's Cadence rampa and Compas with Trinidad's Calypso.

children.name: Dennery Segment
children.description: Developed in Saint Lucia in the early 2010s; heavily influenced by Angolan Kuduro, as well as incorporating elements of Zouk and Lucian drums alongside suggestive lyrics usually sung in Kwéyòl (Saint Lucian Creole).

children.name: Gwo Ka
children.description: Developed in the island of Guadeloupe; driven by a group of gwo ka drums.

children.name: Haitian Music
children.description: Encompasses the styles of music developed by the Haitian people.

children.name: Cadence rampa
children.description: Developed in parallel with Compas, based on Méringue with a stronger Cuban influence.

children.name: Compas
children.description: Popular genre from Haiti, updating the older Méringue style with influences from Mambo and Jazz.

children.name: Haitian Vodou Drumming
children.description: Form of rhythmic performance by Haitian Vodou practitioners, played at associated ceremonies.

children.name: Méringue
children.description: Haitian genre that dates back to the early 19th century; the roots of Compas.

children.name: Rabòday
children.description: Fast-paced rhythm inspired by Rara, with Electronic instrumentation and humorous sexual and political lyrics.

children.name: Rara
children.description: Derived from the Haitian Vodou Drumming tradition, often played at street festivals and carnivals and usually having celebratory or political lyrics.

children.name: Rasin
children.description: Blends the highly rhythmic drumming of traditional Haitian Vodou music with Rock-influenced electric instrumentation such as guitar, keyboard, and bass.

children.name: Tumbélé
children.description: Combines Haitian Compas, Soukous and Cuban Guaguancó with the local style of Biguine.

children.name: Zouk
children.description: Fast-paced danceable pop that began in early 1980s French Antilles, merging and updating more traditional local genres.

children.name: Cabo-Zouk
children.description: Popular in Cape Verde and the Cape Verdean diaspora in Europe and North America, with a slow and sensuous tempo, and favoring more sophisticated studio productions.

children.name: Zouk Love
children.description: More sentimental form of Zouk which emerged in the mid-1980s.

children.name: Goombay
children.description: Bahamian music centered around the drum known as the goombay, a sort of membranophone.

children.name: Indo-Caribbean Music
children.description: Music of the Indo-Caribbean diaspora.

children.name: Baithak gana
children.description: Indo-Caribbean genre from Suriname, consisting of Bhojpuri Folk Music with local Caribbean influence.

children.name: Chutney
children.description: Indo-Caribbean genre developing as a fusion of Bhojpuri Folk Music with traditional Caribbean songs; later influenced by Calypso, Soca and Filmi.

children.name: Chutney Soca
children.description: Mixture of Soca rhythms with Chutney's Indo-Caribbean traits and instrumentation.

children.name: Jamaican Music
children.description: Regional music of Jamaica ranges from its cultural origins in traditional and religious folk of the late 19th and early 20th centuries to the international popularity of Reggae from the 1970s onwards.

children.name: Dancehall
children.description: Developed from Reggae in the late 1970s, when Roots Reggae became more stripped-down, with an increased emphasis on pure rhythm.

children.name: Bubbling
children.description: Originating in the Netherlands in the late 1980s, fusing sped-up Dancehall with Dutch Antillean music and contemporary Dutch rave.

children.name: Digital Dancehall
children.description: First, pre-Ragga style of Dancehall to popularize Electronic rhythms that arose in the mid-1980s.

children.name: Flex Dance Music
children.description: Largely instrumental; infused with Electronic Dance Music elements.

children.name: Gommance
children.description: Emerged in Réunion, mixing Caribbean, African and Afro-Dutch influences.

children.name: Ragga
children.description: Hardcore style with a deejay (equivalent to an MC in Hip Hop) rapping over predominantly Electronic rhythms.

children.name: Shatta
children.description: French Caribbean Dancehall subgenre with a focus on sparse percussion, heavy basslines and lyrics revolving around partying and sensuality, often in Creole.

children.name: Zess
children.description: Trinidadian style that originated in the country's slums in the late 2010s, defined by its sexual, violent, and occasionally gang-related lyrics and its influence from Soca, as well as occasional influences from Hip Hop and Funk brasileiro.

children.name: Jamaican Ska
children.description: Originated in Jamaica with groups who combined Jazz and Rhythm & Blues with rhythms of traditional Caribbean Music like Mento and Calypso.

children.name: Mento
children.description: Jamaican folk originating in the late 19th century which brought together African and European elements, going on to influence the rhythm in Reggae.

children.name: Nyahbinghi
children.description: Performed at Rastafari religious ceremonies, consisting of tripartite hand-drumming and often accompanied by vocal chants.

children.name: Reggae
children.description: Developed in the 1960s; shuffling "bubble" and offbeat rhythms played on an organ, and staccato guitar and piano chords known as "skank."

children.name: Deejay
children.description: Reggae in which a deejay (similar to an MC in Hip Hop) talks or chants lyrics over a pre-recorded reggae rhythm.

children.name: Digital Dancehall
children.description: First, pre-Ragga style of Dancehall to popularize Electronic rhythms that arose in the mid-1980s.

children.name: Dub
children.description: Primarily instrumental Reggae which developed from the extensive use of studio techniques and effects like reverb and delay.

children.name: Novo Dub
children.description: Mixes contemporary influences (especially Electronic) with the traditional Dub sound.

children.name: Lovers Rock
children.description: Smooth, quiet Reggae beats with lyrics focusing on romance and love.

children.name: Pacific Reggae
children.description: Developed in Pacific island communities, incorporating elements from local Oceanian Music styles.

children.name: Pop Reggae
children.description: Light, commercial form of Reggae designed to crossover and break through to a more mainstream Pop audience.

children.name: Roots Reggae
children.description: Primarily defined through the political, spiritual, and socially conscious messages of its lyrics.

children.name: Dub Poetry
children.description: Performance of Poetry over Reggae and Dub rhythms, which originated in Jamaica in the 1970s.

children.name: Seggae
children.description: Fusion of Séga and Reggae, popular on Mauritius and other Mascarene Islands.

children.name: Skinhead Reggae
children.description: Rough sounding and fast-paced, using brass modestly, with lyrics reflecting views on work, football, beer, and bovver.

children.name: Rocksteady
children.description: Jamaican popular music that blossomed briefly between 1966 and 1968 as an evolution of Ska, being slower, more relaxed, and soulful.

children.name: Junkanoo
children.description: Highly rhythmic Bahamian style which traditionally accompanies the arts festival and street parade of the same name.

children.name: Kaseko
children.description: Surinamese popular music with roots in Surinamese Creole music, which was influenced by folk traditions of Africa, Europe, and the Americas.

children.name: Merengue
children.description: Dominican Republic dance genre that had a commercial boom at the end of the 1980s.

children.name: Mambo urbano
children.description: Rhythmically simpler and more eclectic style, absorbing influences from Hip Hop, Reggaetón, and other modern genres, particularly in regards to vocals.

children.name: Merecumbé
children.description: Colombian genre which combines Cumbia with Merengue.

children.name: Merengue típico
children.description: Earliest, most stripped-down form of Merengue.

children.name: Merenhouse
children.description: Popularized by Dominican-American artists of the 1990s, blending modern Merengue with electronic instrumentation and the combination of rapping/singing vocals.

children.name: Tecnomerengue
children.description: Fuses basic Merengue rhythms with influences from Cumbia and Lambada, being largely synthesized, with live instruments usually limited to percussion and brass.

children.name: Parang
children.description: Latin-Caribbean genre central to Trinidad and Tobago and Venezuela traditionally used for nighttime celebrations in Trinidadian towns.

children.name: Porro
children.description: Lively Hispanic American Music and dance style native to Colombia which gained popularity in the 1940s.

children.name: Punta
children.description: Garifuna music with influences from other Caribbean genres such as Reggae, Soca, and Zouk, as well as Hispanic American Music.

children.name: Soca
children.description: Upbeat, poppy and danceable style rooted in Calypso and Indo-Caribbean Music; developed in the late 1960s and early 1970s in Trinidad and Tobago.

children.name: Bashment Soca
children.description: Highly energetic, Dancehall-influenced form of Soca developed in Barbados featuring dancefloor-oriented lyrics delivered in an aggressive chanting style.

children.name: Chutney Soca
children.description: Mixture of Soca rhythms with Chutney's Indo-Caribbean traits and instrumentation.

children.name: Dennery Segment
children.description: Developed in Saint Lucia in the early 2010s; heavily influenced by Angolan Kuduro, as well as incorporating elements of Zouk and Lucian drums alongside suggestive lyrics usually sung in Kwéyòl (Saint Lucian Creole).

children.name: Power Soca
children.description: Often at a tempo of 160 BPM and incorporating hard, frantic rhythms, highly synthesized production, and call-and-response vocals.

children.name: Rapso
children.description: Fusion of Soca and Hip Hop unique to Trinidad and Tobago.

children.name: Tropicanibalismo
children.description: Colombian scene born in the early 2000s with the intention of reinventing Colombian coastal music, from a more current and experimental approach.

children.name: Vallenato
children.description: Accordion-led style of folk and popular music originating in Colombia's Caribbean region.

name: Christian Liturgical Music
description: Traditionally accompanies church services, as well as extra-liturgical functions such as processionals and sermons.

children.name: Anglican Chant
children.description: Simple, harmonized, English-language setting of the Christian liturgy, principally devised by the Anglican Church.

children.name: Armenian Church Music
children.description: One of the oldest branches of Christian culture, this is the predominantly vocal music of the Armenian Apostolic Church.

children.name: Byzantine Chant
children.description: Liturgical chant of Christian churches following the Orthodox rite.

children.name: Coptic Music
children.description: Church music specifically made for worship in the Coptic (Egyptian) Orthodox Church.

children.name: Ethiopian Church Music
children.description: Sacred tradition of the Ethiopian Orthodox Tewahedo Church, sung in an ancient Semitic language called Ge'ez and credited with assembling the current Ethiopian notation system.

children.name: Kyivan Chant
children.description: Chant form inspired by Znamenny Chant that's characterized by simplified melodic and rhythmic structures.

children.name: Mass
children.description: Composition for choir, with or without instrumental accompaniment, that sets to music text from the liturgy of the Eucharist, principally from the Latin rites of the Roman Catholic Church.

children.name: Requiem
children.description: Musical setting commemorating the deceased with text usually derived from the Roman Catholic mass of the dead.

children.name: Plainsong
children.description: Monophonic chanting in the context of Roman Catholic and modern Anglican liturgy.

children.name: Ambrosian Chant
children.description: Liturgical chant practiced in parts of Italy and Switzerland, characterized by stepped melodic progression.

children.name: Canto beneventano
children.description: Extinct plainchant tradition of Southern Italy characterized by lengthy melodies, extensive use of repetition, and a steady, undulating progression.

children.name: Canto mozárabe
children.description: Iberian form of plainchant that flourished roughly 550-1085 AD.

children.name: Celtic Chant
children.description: Extinct tradition of Catholic liturgical chant developed by the Celtic Christians of Britain, Ireland, and Brittany.

children.name: Gregorian Chant
children.description: Liturgical, monophonic chant that accompanied Mass and other rituals in Western Christianity.

children.name: Old Roman Chant
children.description: Plainchant tradition of Medieval Rome that was closely related to Gregorian Chant, though often more musically ornate.

children.name: Russian Orthodox Liturgical Music
children.description: Tradition of the Russian Orthodox Church, implemented with the Christianization of Kievan Rus' in 988.

children.name: Choral Concerto
children.description: Composition for unaccompanied choir, set to sacred texts of Eastern Orthodox tradition.

children.name: Znamenny Chant
children.description: Prototypical liturgical chant of the Russian Orthodox Church.

children.name: Seinn nan salm
children.description: Unaccompanied, rhythmically free-flowing psalm singing in Gaelic practiced by Presbyterian churches, which involves a call-and-response between the precentor and the congregation.

children.name: Syriac Chant
children.description: Liturgical chant repertoire practiced within Syriac Christianity, comprising the East Syrian and West Syrian liturgical rites.

name: European Music
description: Regional styles with roots in the European continent and surrounding islands.

children.name: Alpenrock
children.description: Mixes Hard Rock and Blues Rock with traditional Alpine Folk Music elements such as Yodeling and use of the accordion.

children.name: Ancient Roman Music
children.description: Music of ancient Roman civilization.

children.name: Anglican Chant
children.description: Simple, harmonized, English-language setting of the Christian liturgy, principally devised by the Anglican Church.

children.name: Ashkenazi Music
children.description: Encompasses the various traditions and genres of the Ashkenazi Jews, an ethnoreligious group that was prominent and influential in Europe throughout most of the Middle Ages and the modern period.

children.name: Klezmer
children.description: Secular Ashkenazi Music traditionally used in ceremonies such as weddings and bar and bat mitzvahs.

children.name: Yiddish Folksong
children.description: Traditional folk developed in Ashkenazi Jewish communities, particularly those of Yiddish-speaking Eastern and Central Europe.

children.name: Balkan Music
children.description: Meta-genre covering all forms developed in the Balkan Peninsula.

children.name: Balkan Folk Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of the Balkan region of Southeastern Europe.

children.name: Albanian Folk Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of Albania, including the area's traditions as well as influence from Turkish Music.

children.name: Lab Polyphony
children.description: One of several genres of iso-polyphonic music performed in southern Albania, with "iso" referring to the distinctive drone voice used.

children.name: Musika popullore
children.description: Tradition in Albania consisting of light, commercial, amplified Albanian Folk Music usually professionally arranged and manufactured in recording studios alongside video clips.

children.name: Tosk Polyphony
children.description: Polyphonic singing in the Toskëri region of southern Albania.

children.name: Aromanian Folk Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of the Aromanians.

children.name: Balkan Brass Band
children.description: Balkan Folk Music played by brass bands.

children.name: Bosnian Folk Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of the Bosnians.

children.name: Izvorna bosanska muzika
children.description: Polyphonic vocal music that developed in Bosnia in the 20th century, bearing connections to traditional Bosnian genres.

children.name: Sevdalinka
children.description: A melancholic folk song, originating from Bosnia and Herzegovina, typically love-themed and accompanied by instruments like guitar and accordion.

children.name: Bulgarian Folk Music
children.description: Consists of a variety of traditions and styles, with distinct sounds originating from current and historical regions such as Sofia, Dobrudzha, Macedonia and Thrace.

children.name: Croatian Folk Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of the Croats.

children.name: Klapa
children.description: Traditional form characteristic of the Dalmatia region of Croatia rooted in littoral church singing.

children.name: Csango Folk Music
children.description: Folk of the Csango, an ethnic minority group with Hungarian origins living primarily in the Romanian Moldavia region, but who are also found in the Transylvania, Dobruja, Moldova, the Ukrainian Chernivtsi region, and the Tolna region of Hungary.

children.name: Gagauz Folk Music
children.description: Gagauz people are a Turkic group living mostly in the southern Gagauzia region of Moldova, but also nearby areas like southwestern Ukraine and southeastern Romania.

children.name: Ganga

children.name: Volkstümliche Musik
children.description: Light Pop with borrowings from German Folk Music (volksmusik), often misleadingly labeled as being volksmusik.

children.name: Zeitoper

children.name: Grand opéra
children.description: French style characterized by its enlarged scope and sense of grandeur, with bigger orchestras and casts, and ornate sceneries and costumes.

children.name: Greek Music
children.description: Music of the Greek people.

children.name: Ancient Greek Music
children.description: Music of ancient Greek civilization.

children.name: Byzantine Music
children.description: Music from Byzantine era.

children.name: Byzantine Chant
children.description: Liturgical chant of Christian churches following the Orthodox rite.

children.name: Entechna

children.name: Entechna laika
children.description: Artistic side of Laika played mainly but not always with the basic instruments of it, the bouzouki, Greek baglama, and the jouras, sometimes with the accompaniment of orchestras.

children.name: Neo Kyma
children.description: First appeared in the middle of the 1960s, rooted in Entechna, taking major inspiration from French Chanson.

children.name: Greek Folk Music

children.name: Aegean Islands Folk Music
children.description: Music of the Greek Aegean Islands.

children.name: Cretan Folk Music
children.description: Folk of the Greek island Crete.

children.name: Rizitika

children.name: Dimotika

children.name: Ionian Islands Folk Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music from the Ionian Islands in Greece.

children.name: Rembetika
children.description: Greek tradition originating in traditional Mikrasiatiki and Smyrnaiki music with elements of other local traditional Greek genres.

children.name: Laika
children.description: Greek popular music played with local instruments like the bouzouki, Greek baglama, and the jouras.

children.name: Entechna laika
children.description: Artistic side of Laika played mainly but not always with the basic instruments of it, the bouzouki, Greek baglama, and the jouras, sometimes with the accompaniment of orchestras.

children.name: Modern Laika
children.description: Laiki music mixed with popular Western music, most notably pop and dance.

children.name: Skiladika

children.name: Irish Showband
children.description: Phenomenon lasting from the mid-1950s until the early 1980s, often performed a mixture of currently popular music and skits.

children.name: Italian Music
children.description: Music of the Italian people.

children.name: Canto beneventano

children.name: Canzone d'autore

children.name: Italian Folk Music
children.description: Folk traditions of Italy.

children.name: Canzone napoletana

children.name: Liscio
children.description: Italian popular genre characterized by the fast execution of solo instruments such as clarinet, saxophone, or the accordion.

children.name: Stornello
children.description: Italian folk poetry, generally improvised and handed down by street singers, carters or sellers.

children.name: Tarantella
children.description: Fast upbeat tempo, switching between major and minor modes while gradually increasing in speed.

children.name: Pizzica
children.description: Italian Folk dance and music from Apulia, belonging to the family of Tarantella.

children.name: Tammurriata
children.description: Italian folk from Campania, belonging to the family of Tarantella.

children.name: Trallalero
children.description: Polyphonic Traditional Folk Music originating in the Ligurian region of Genoa, in northern Italy.

children.name: Old Roman Chant
children.description: Plainchant tradition of Medieval Rome that was closely related to Gregorian Chant, though often more musically ornate.

children.name: Opera buffa

children.name: Opera semiseria

children.name: Opera seria
children.description: Italian Opera popular among European nobility and royalty throughout most of the 18th century, typified by its exaggerated dramatic flair and interspersed with dry recitative.

children.name: Madrigal

children.name: Ars antiqua

children.name: Ars nova
children.description: Period (around 1310-1380) that succeeded Ars antiqua, mixing the sacred with the secular.

children.name: Ars subtilior
children.description: Emerged in the final period of late medieval music (around 1380-1420) and continued to use the technique of isorhythms but with added complexity.

children.name: Medieval Lyric Poetry
children.description: Lyric poetry from Medieval Europe, roughly from the 11th to the 14th century, most prominently the troubadours of southern France.

children.name: Plainsong

children.name: Ambrosian Chant

children.name: Canto beneventano
children.description: Extinct plainchant tradition of Southern Italy characterized by lengthy melodies, extensive use of repetition, and a steady, undulating progression.

children.name: Canto mozárabe
children.description: Iberian form of plainchant that flourished roughly 550-1085 AD.

children.name: Celtic Chant

children.name: Gregorian Chant

children.name: Old Roman Chant
children.description: Plainchant tradition of Medieval Rome that was closely related to Gregorian Chant, though often more musically ornate.

children.description: Urban folk street band traditions of Polish cities.

children.description: Traditional Folk Music of the Kurpian people of eastern Poland.

children.name: Muzică de mahala

children.name: Rumba flamenca

children.name: Flamenco Pop

children.name: Nueva canción española
children.description: Arose in Spain in the 1960s, inspired in part by Nova cançó's reclaiming of Catalan regional identity, that spread across the country in regional variations.

children.name: Rock andaluz

children.name: Rumba catalana

children.name: Spanish Classical Music

children.name: Canto mozárabe

children.name: Sevillanas
children.description: Named after the city of Seville in Spain, typically rhythmic with a 3/4 beat and guitar accompaniment.

children.name: Aragonese Folk Music

children.name: Asturian Folk Music
children.description: Traditions of the Spanish province of Asturias.

children.name: Canarian Folk Music
children.description: Traditional folk of the Canary Islands.

children.name: Chotis madrileño
children.description: Spanish variant of schottisch, a slow version of German Polka which developed through the incorporation of regional folk influences and an association with the local castizo culture in Madrid, the capital of Spain.

children.name: Copla
children.description: Evolved from Spanish theatrical styles like Cuplé and has strong links to Flamenco.

children.name: Cuplé
children.description: Originally developed in the 19th century as a blend of old theatre Spanish styles based in short monologues (jácara and tonadilla) and French Couplet.

children.name: Galician Folk Music
children.description: Traditional music of the Galician people.

children.name: Pasodoble
children.description: Mainly instrumental Spanish style primarily associated with bullfighting and popular celebrations, believed to originate from a double-time military march from France in the 18th century.

children.description: Associated with the tramping lifestyle, typically mixing acoustic guitar driven Contemporary Folk with strong Country influences and vocal harmonies in peaceful, simple and relatively short songs.

children.name: Verismo
children.description: Developed in Italy around the turn of the 20th century and favored melodramatic realism, a rejection of bel canto standards, and declamatory singing.

children.name: Waltz
children.description: Typically in a 3/4 time signature and popular in the 18th century in central Europe, as it accompanied the ballroom dance of the same name.

children.name: Valsa brasileira
children.description: Brazillian Waltz characterized by its slow rhythms and romantic sound.

name: Hispanic Music
description: Music of Hispanic America and Spain, and the genres shared between them.

children.name: Canción melódica
children.description: Sentimental vocal music sung in Spanish with a focus on the chorus, originally developed in the first half of the 20th century from a variety of traditional Hispanic genres.

children.name: Bolero-Beat
children.description: Latin American style stemming from both Canción melódica and the British Beat Music.

children.name: Música cebolla
children.description: Chilean offshoot of Canción melódica that expresses a much more melancholic or nostalgic side.

children.name: Hispanic American Music
children.description: Includes all genres created by Hispanic Americans.

children.name: Argentine Music
children.description: Music developed by the Argentine people.

children.name: Cuarteto
children.description: Originated in the Argentinian province of Córdoba, usually with an upbeat rhythm and originally performed with a four-piece band.

children.name: Cumbia argentina
children.description: Almost always features synthesizer keyboards and electronic percussion with an upbeat rhythm.

children.name: Cumbia santafesina
children.description: Originated in the Argentinian province of Santa Fe, particularly in its capital city Santa Fe de la Vera Cruz, with lyrics that tend to be romantic and relatively clean compared to later Cumbia argentina.

children.name: Cumbia turra
children.description: Cumbia argentina heavily influenced by Reggaetón and characterized by hard-hitting bass and heavy use of samples and Auto-Tune.

children.name: Cumbia villera
children.description: Developed in the villa miserias (shanty towns) by the lower classes of Argentina in the early 2000s, featuring basic rhythms and low budget productions combined with lyrics that can be openly sexual or touch on sociopolitical issues.

children.name: Nuevo Cancionero
children.description: Musical-literary movement in Argentina that aimed to reevaluate and reinvigorate "la música popular nativa" (native popular music) and to be the voice of poor and marginalized Argentines.

children.name: Avanzada
children.description: Fusion of Polka paraguaya and Guarania with elements of Bossa nova and MPB.

children.name: Bachata
children.description: Romantic dance and accompanying music originating in the Dominican Republic, featuring arpeggiated chords in the melody.

children.name: Bailecito
children.description: Agile and lively dance derived from Zamacueca, typical of the western and central region of Bolivia.

children.name: Bolero
children.description: Ballad with a 2/4 time signature that appeared in eastern Cuba towards the end of the 19th century.

children.name: Bolero son
children.description: Blend of Bolero and Son cubano that appeared during the 1920s.

children.name: Filin
children.description: Emotional style that appeared in La Habana during the late 1940s, deeply influenced by the melodic and expressive style of Vocal Jazz.

children.name: Boogaloo
children.description: Upbeat fusion of American Rhythm & Blues and Jazz with Son cubano which originated in the early 1960s in New York City and became popular with both its Black and Latino communities.

children.name: Caporal
children.description: Bolivian neofolkloric dance music characterized by a double beat bass drum pattern that emerged in the latter half of the twentieth century.

children.name: Carnaval cruceño
children.description: Danceable genre, similar to the Polka, from the city of Santa Cruz, Bolivia, characteristic of the area’s Carnival celebrations and generally composed for brass band musicians.

children.name: Champeta
children.description: Colombian genre heavily influenced by the traditional music of San Basilio de Palenque as well as modern Caribbean and African sensibilities.

children.name: Chilean Music
children.description: Music developed by the Chilean people.

children.name: Canto a lo poeta
children.description: Sung poetry traditional to Chile and transmitted orally from one generation to another.

children.name: Chilote Music
children.description: Music of the Chiloé Archipelago.

children.name: Cumbia chilena
children.description: Incorporates Chilean Music into the traditional sound of Cumbia.

children.name: Nueva cumbia chilena
children.description: Incorporating various instruments and rhythmic components from diverse genres such as Ska, Salsa, Indigenous Andean Music, Reggae, and Bolero.

children.name: Jazz guachaca
children.description: Encompasses Jazz influences with Hispanic American Music styles such as Cueca, Bolero, Tango and Corrido.

children.name: Mambo chileno
children.description: Emerged in the early 2010s in Chile, characterized by upbeat rhythms and rapping, usually on topics of parties, dancing, and urban life.

children.name: Música cebolla
children.description: Chilean offshoot of Canción melódica that expresses a much more melancholic or nostalgic side.

children.name: Música típica chilena
children.description: Incorporation of rural folklore music to urban fields, adding vocal groups accompanied mainly by guitar and a "huaso" symbolism.

children.name: Neofolklore
children.description: Short-lived movement that reincorporated traditional Chilean folklore into modern production and styling inspired by foreign musicians.

children.name: Nueva canción chilena
children.description: Socially conscious style that sought to recover traditional Chilean folk music and fuse it with the broader musical trends of Latin America.

children.name: Tonada chilena
children.description: Traditional folk from the Chilean countryside distinguished by its prominent melody.

children.name: Chuntunqui romántico
children.description: Vibrant Bolivian genre set in 6/8 meter featuring choral refrains, harmonic progressions, and lyrics exploring the subject of romantic love.

children.name: Conjunto andino
children.description: Urban folk ensembles using musical instruments of Andean Indigenous origin or association; despite frequent association with Indigenous villages, they bear little resemblance to the Indigenous expressions of the Southern Andes.

children.name: Cuban Music
children.description: Encompasses the wide variety of traditions from the island of Cuba.

children.name: Chachachá
children.description: Ballroom dance music derived from Danzón.

children.name: Changüí
children.description: One of the oldest popular Cuban styles, originating in the 19th century with slaves that worked in sugar refineries near Baracoa who combined elements of Spanish popular songs with Bantu traditions.

children.name: Conga
children.description: Evolved alongside Rumba cubana in the late 19th century, featuring large and heterogenous percussion sections performing simple and syncopated rhythms alongside a small wind section.

children.name: Cuban Charanga
children.description: Played by traditional Cuban ensembles, influenced by Son cubano but performed on European instruments such as piano, bass, violins, and flutes.

children.name: Cubaton
children.description: Vocal delivery is often heavily auto-tuned and layered with adlibs, rhythm is syncopated, and Caribbean and African instrumentation is incorporated.

children.name: Danzón
children.description: Development on Habanera in 2/4 time, featuring African influence through complex cross-rhythms, that would become the most popular style of dance music in Cuba during the late 19th century and early 20th century.

children.name: Descarga
children.description: Cuban genre consisting of improvised jam sessions incorporating elements of Jazz and Afro-Cuban music.

children.name: Filin
children.description: Emotional style that appeared in La Habana during the late 1940s, deeply influenced by the melodic and expressive style of Vocal Jazz.

children.name: Guajira
children.description: Originally developed in Cuba between the 18th and 19th Century as a narrative style influenced by Tonada chilena.

children.name: Guaracha
children.description: Humorous song with short notes and a fast tempo that commonly alternates a short fourth line verse with a repeated fourth line chorus.

children.name: Habanera
children.description: Based around the Habanera rhythm, where the most typical instruments used are guitars, lutes, and bandurrias.

children.name: Mambo
children.description: Dance-oriented evolution from Danzón during the late 1930s.

children.name: Mozambique
children.description: Cuban genre featuring energetic, African-influenced percussion.

children.name: Pachanga
children.description: Combination of Merengue, Conga, Rumba cubana, and Cumbia; fast, festive, and playful.

children.name: Pilón
children.description: Featuring rhythms described as mimicking those created while pounding sugarcane with African baton-like tools.

children.name: Rumba cubana
children.description: Folkloric manifestation of Afro-Cuban music that encompasses dance, voice, and drums.

children.name: Guaguancó
children.description: Emerged after the abolition of slavery in Cuba in 1886; usually features a lead singer, accompanied by three large drums, known as tumbadoras or congas, and a call-and-response chorus.

children.name: Santería Music
children.description: Afro-Cuban genre played in religious rituals, combining traditions from both the Cuban and the Yorùbá people.

children.name: Son cubano
children.description: Cuban style popular from the 1920s to the 1950s that combines the structure of Spanish song-oriented styles with African rhythms and percussion.

children.name: Bolero son
children.description: Blend of Bolero and Son cubano that appeared during the 1920s.

children.name: Songo
children.description: Cuban style originating in the 1970s, combining elements from Rumba cubana and Son cubano with Jazz and Funk.

children.name: Timba
children.description: Combines Salsa with other genres such as Hip Hop, Disco, Funk, Jazz and Rock.

children.name: Trova
children.description: One of the most ancient expressions of Cuban Music, based around lone singer/songwriters who use nothing but a guitar as their preferred accompaniment and place emphasis on lyrics.

children.name: Nueva trova
children.description: Found inspiration in the 1950s Cuban Revolution and had the intention of introducing new musical ideas to the original Trova.

children.name: Tumba francesa
children.description: Combination of traditional music from Benin with French ballroom dancing that originates in the Oriente province (formerly Santiago de Cuba Province) in Cuba.

children.name: Cumbia
children.description: Danceable folk genre formed during the 19th century in Colombia and eastern Panama.

children.name: Cumbia argentina
children.description: Almost always features synthesizer keyboards and electronic percussion with an upbeat rhythm.

children.name: Cumbia santafesina
children.description: Originated in the Argentinian province of Santa Fe, particularly in its capital city Santa Fe de la Vera Cruz, with lyrics that tend to be romantic and relatively clean compared to later Cumbia argentina.

children.name: Cumbia turra
children.description: Cumbia argentina heavily influenced by Reggaetón and characterized by hard-hitting bass and heavy use of samples and Auto-Tune.

children.name: Cumbia villera
children.description: Developed in the villa miserias (shanty towns) by the lower classes of Argentina in the early 2000s, featuring basic rhythms and low budget productions combined with lyrics that can be openly sexual or touch on sociopolitical issues.

children.name: Cumbia chilena
children.description: Incorporates Chilean Music into the traditional sound of Cumbia.

children.name: Nueva cumbia chilena
children.description: Incorporating various instruments and rhythmic components from diverse genres such as Ska, Salsa, Indigenous Andean Music, Reggae, and Bolero.

children.name: Cumbia colombiana
children.description: Style that incorporates elements of Colombian traditional music, which includes and keeps influences from Spanish, African, and Indigenous cultures.

children.name: Cumbia mexicana
children.description: Incorporation of Rock & Roll, Mexican popular music, and Cuban influences, often adopting electric instruments, brass ensembles, accordion, and Cuban timbales, while retaining a beat-driven sound and traditional Colombian features.

children.name: Cumbia sonidera
children.description: Cumbia mexicana from Mexico City that developed in the 1990s as discomóviles (analogous to DJs) experimented with slowing down original cumbia to fit the popular dance tempos.

children.name: Cumbia peruana
children.description: Developed in Peru and diversified into various subgenres, each with its own regional influences.

children.name: Cumbia pop
children.description: Developed in the Río de la Plata region in the mid-2010s, featuring Latin Pop influences and lyrics related to romance, youth, and fun.

children.name: Digital Cumbia
children.description: Mixes an Electronic sound into traditional Cumbia through influences from House, Dancehall, Hyphy, and Dubstep.

children.name: Merecumbé
children.description: Colombian genre which combines Cumbia with Merengue.

children.name: Currulao
children.description: Pacific coast Afro-Colombian music and folk dance performed by a marimba/percussion ensemble with heavy use of call-and-response vocals.

children.name: Dembow
children.description: Originated in the Dominican Republic during the early 1990s, featuring rapping indebted to Hip Hop and a style drawing on Dancehall, particularly the "Dem Bow" riddim.

children.name: Gaita zuliana
children.description: Emerged in the state of Zulia in the 1950s, merging Spanish Folk Music and Venezuelan Christmas carols.

children.name: Guarania
children.description: Slow and melancholic rhythms, primarily performed on the Paraguayan harp.

children.name: Hispanic American Folk Music
children.description: Encompasses many varieties of folk traditions from Hispanic America.

children.name: Bambuco
children.description: Follows a 6/8 or 3/4 time signature with non-percussive instrumentation, often melancholic in sound with bright guitars and a rich melodic base.

children.name: Bomba
children.description: Percussive style from Puerto Rico, generally considered to be derived from West Africa.

children.name: Candombe
children.description: Uruguayan popular music originating among Montevideo's Afro-Uruguayan population, based on three differently-sized drums.

children.name: Canto a lo poeta
children.description: Sung poetry traditional to Chile and transmitted orally from one generation to another.

children.name: Carranga
children.description: Colombian folk music that originated in Boyacá province, best known for its wordplay and humorous lyrics.

children.name: Chacarera
children.description: Originated in northwest Argentina and southern Bolivia around 1850, typically in 6/8 and traditionally performed with instruments like the guitar, bombo legüero (traditional drum), and violin.

children.name: Chamamé
children.description: Mixes native Guaraní music with Polka paraguaya and European schottische music.

children.name: Chamarrita rioplatense
children.description: Traditional genre and dance featuring similar rhythms to Milonga and typically performed with the guitar and accordion.

children.name: Cueca
children.description: Popular in Chile, Argentina, and Bolivia, accompanied by a 6/8 or 3/4 time signature and usually structured into 14 verses.

children.name: Jibaro
children.description: Traditions of the mountain-dwelling jibaro people that live primarily in Puerto Rico.

children.name: Joropo
children.description: Incorporates elements of Creole music and the Venezuelan waltz.

children.name: Malagueña venezolana
children.description: Traditional musical accompaniment to the Venezuelan 'velorios de cruz de mayo' celebrations, played with the mandolin (as lead instrument), cuatro and guitar.

children.name: Mexican Folk Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of the Mexican people.

children.name: Canto cardenche
children.description: Overtly dramatic, and melancholic A cappella performed in the Comarca Lagunera region in northeast Mexico.

children.name: Son calentano
children.description: Usually dominated by violin with accompaniment mainly provided by guitars and tamboras, occasionally dancers will stomp over a platform.

children.name: Son huasteco
children.description: Bold rhythmic structure, lively violin playing, and extensive use of falsetto.

children.name: Son istmeño
children.description: Developed in the Isthmus of Tehuantepec, traditionally played by guitar, requinto, marimba, and bajoquinto, usually played in 3/4 time.

children.name: Son jarocho
children.description: Mexican Folk Music from the Gulf Coast Mexican state of Veracruz, with both Spanish and indigenous influences.

children.name: Trova yucateca
children.description: Heavily influenced by Cuban Music, freely embracing Bolero, clave and Bambuco.

children.name: Milonga
children.description: Characterized by a slow rhythm usually performed on a guitar; generally considered a precursor to Tango.

children.name: Muliza
children.description: Mestizo folk genre popular in the central Peruvian Andes, characterized by a pronounced, though sedate, rhythm; traces of Andean melody; and octosyllabic verses.

children.name: Música criolla peruana
children.description: Combination of African, Spanish, and Andean influences that originated after the time of the arrival of Spanish colonists and African slaves to Peru.

children.name: Marinera
children.description: Component of the coastal dance of the same name, often considered the national dance of Peru.

children.name: Tondero
children.description: Backing to the fast-paced dance that originated in northern Peru in the region of Piura of the same name; bands consist of a singer, a small chorus, two guitarists, along with the cajón and sometimes a spoon player.

children.name: Vals criollo
children.description: Originally characterized by its 3/4 time, heavy reliance on strongly plucked phrase on upper strings, and its guitar solo; often accompanied by a duet or a solo singer, normally singing about patriotic themes or social dilemmas.

children.name: Plena
children.description: Folk genre from Puerto Rico played with hand drums called panderetas.

children.name: Saya
children.description: Fast-paced, percussive traditional genre created by the Afro-Bolivian people.

children.name: Tamborito
children.description: Folk music and dance from Panama dating back to the 17th century.

children.name: Taquirari
children.description: Developed by the indigenous peoples of eastern Bolivia, bringing in some elements of Hispanic Music, and featuring a syncopated rhythm.

children.name: Tonada chilena
children.description: Traditional folk from the Chilean countryside distinguished by its prominent melody.

children.name: Yaraví
children.description: Peruvian criollo-mestizo songs with recurring themes of sadness and unrequited love, usually in 6/8 meter.

children.name: Zamacueca
children.description: Traditional genre and dance of 19th century Peru, sung in the minor mode and accompanied by a varying combination of guitar, vihuela, harp and cajón.

children.name: Zamba
children.description: Folk dance that evolved out of Peruvian Zamacueca during the 19th century.

children.name: Huayno
children.description: Andean dance music that incorporates both pre-Hispanic and Western musical elements.

children.name: Bolivian Huayño
children.description: One of the most popular genres of Andean music in Bolivia, particularly present in the departments of Cochabamba, Chuquisaca, La Paz, Oruro and Potosí.

children.name: Carnavalito
children.description: Fast and lively; mostly played in northwestern Argentina in the provinces of Jujuy, Salta, and Tucumán.

children.name: Latin Alternative
children.description: Incorporates common elements from Hispanic American Music like Cumbia, Tango or Mexican Music into Rock.

children.name: Latin American Classical Music
children.description: Western Classical Music with influences from Hispanic American Music.

children.name: Latin Disco
children.description: Disco that incorporates elements from Hispanic American Music styles.

children.name: Latin Electronic
children.description: Combines Electronic with Latin American influences; started at the end of the 1990s.

children.name: Changa tuki
children.description: Emerged in Caracas; highly influenced by 1990s Techno and Tribal House, featuring fast tempos, strident synthesizers, hard-thumping percussion lines, and plenty of breakbeats.

children.name: Digital Cumbia
children.description: Mixes an Electronic sound into traditional Cumbia through influences from House, Dancehall, Hyphy, and Dubstep.

children.name: Electro latino
children.description: Mixes elements of Merengue and Reggaetón with polished production from mainstream House subgenres; often shares traits with Latin Pop, having anthemic melodies and verse-chorus structures.

children.name: Electrotango
children.description: Combines Tango rhythms and melodies with Electronic music.

children.name: Nortec
children.description: Samples and synthesizes Mexican styles like Banda sinaloense and Norteño into a sound related to IDM and House.

children.name: Tribal Guarachero
children.description: Features percussion from Cumbia and Mexican Folk Music with upbeat Electro House-derived production and fast, triplet-oriented rhythmic patterns.

children.name: Latin Funk
children.description: Funk combined with Hispanic American Music styles.

children.name: Latin Jazz
children.description: Used originally for Afro-Cuban Jazz but, due to its evolution, is now used for the fusion of jazz with Latin American rhythms, especially genres with African origin.

children.name: Afro-Cuban Jazz
children.description: Combines Jazz with the rhythm of Afro-Cuban music like Habanera.

children.name: Latin Pop
children.description: Characterized by its usage of Latino clichés and frequently influenced by traditional Latin American styles, commonly borrowing from their instrumentation.

children.name: Cumbia pop
children.description: Developed in the Río de la Plata region in the mid-2010s, featuring Latin Pop influences and lyrics related to romance, youth, and fun.

children.name: Tropipop
children.description: Subgenre of Colombian origin fusing Vallenato instrumentation into a Latin Pop context.

children.name: Latin Rock
children.description: Fusion of Rock, often Psychedelic Rock, with Latin American rhythms, especially Afro-Latin genres.

children.name: Latin Soul
children.description: Soul combined with Hispanic American Music, such as Salsa and Mambo.

children.name: Merengue
children.description: Dominican Republic dance genre that had a commercial boom at the end of the 1980s.

children.name: Mambo urbano
children.description: Rhythmically simpler and more eclectic style, absorbing influences from Hip Hop, Reggaetón, and other modern genres, particularly in regards to vocals.

children.name: Merecumbé
children.description: Colombian genre which combines Cumbia with Merengue.

children.name: Merengue típico
children.description: Earliest, most stripped-down form of Merengue.

children.name: Merenhouse
children.description: Popularized by Dominican-American artists of the 1990s, blending modern Merengue with electronic instrumentation and the combination of rapping/singing vocals.

children.name: Tecnomerengue
children.description: Fuses basic Merengue rhythms with influences from Cumbia and Lambada, being largely synthesized, with live instruments usually limited to percussion and brass.

children.name: Mexican Music
children.description: Music of Mexico and those deeply rooted in Mexican traditions.

children.name: Bandas de viento de México
children.description: Mexican ensemble with many regional variations dating back to the 1860s and 1870s, when locals attempted to imitate the military bands that were present in the country.

children.name: Banda sinaloense
children.description: Performed with militaristic-type arrangements of traditional Bandas de viento de México, with prominence on the tuba/sousaphone backing and tenor tuned horns.

children.name: Movimiento alterado
children.description: Arose from Sinaloa in the late 2000s; radicalizes some of the characteristics of Banda sinaloense and Norteño.

children.name: Tecnobanda
children.description: Emerged in the mid-1980s from the Banda sinaloense tradition, replacing certain instruments with synthesizers and electric instruments, allowing for faster tempos.

children.name: Chilena
children.description: Developed when music from the Costa Chica of Guerrero and Oaxaca in Mexico mixed with Cueca brought by Chilean sailors to the region in the 19th century.

children.name: Corrido
children.description: Narrative ballad which arose in the late 18th century and flourished after the Mexican Independence War, originally meant for folk singers to spread news throughout Mexico accompanied by a guitar.

children.name: Cumbia mexicana
children.description: Incorporation of Rock & Roll, Mexican popular music, and Cuban influences, often adopting electric instruments, brass ensembles, accordion, and Cuban timbales, while retaining a beat-driven sound and traditional Colombian features.

children.name: Cumbia sonidera
children.description: Cumbia mexicana from Mexico City that developed in the 1990s as discomóviles (analogous to DJs) experimented with slowing down original cumbia to fit the popular dance tempos.

children.name: Cumbiatón
children.description: Combining Reggaetón  with Cumbia mexicana, and less frequently with other forms of traditional Mexican Music.

children.name: Mariachi
children.description: Mexican style performed in unique costumes by ensembles known as mariachi bands, with a distinctive sound combining high, bright tones with low and rich voicings.

children.name: Mexican Folk Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of the Mexican people.

children.name: Canto cardenche
children.description: Overtly dramatic, and melancholic A cappella performed in the Comarca Lagunera region in northeast Mexico.

children.name: Son calentano
children.description: Usually dominated by violin with accompaniment mainly provided by guitars and tamboras, occasionally dancers will stomp over a platform.

children.name: Son huasteco
children.description: Bold rhythmic structure, lively violin playing, and extensive use of falsetto.

children.name: Son istmeño
children.description: Developed in the Isthmus of Tehuantepec, traditionally played by guitar, requinto, marimba, and bajoquinto, usually played in 3/4 time.

children.name: Son jarocho
children.description: Mexican Folk Music from the Gulf Coast Mexican state of Veracruz, with both Spanish and indigenous influences.

children.name: Trova yucateca
children.description: Heavily influenced by Cuban Music, freely embracing Bolero, clave and Bambuco.

children.name: Norteño
children.description: More traditional, rural version of Tejano Music whose name translates to "northern".

children.name: Cumbia norteña mexicana
children.description: Norteño heavily influenced by Cumbia.

children.name: Duranguense
children.description: Features aspects of banda music, sped up, with the addition of synthesizers.

children.name: Movimiento alterado
children.description: Arose from Sinaloa in the late 2000s; radicalizes some of the characteristics of Banda sinaloense and Norteño.

children.name: Sierreño
children.description: Norteño that is mainly played with guitars, as opposed to the traditional bajo sexto used in norteño.

children.name: Corrido tumbado
children.description: Modern take of regional Mexican music derived from Sierreño with heavy influence from the atmosphere of Trap music, while not engaging in that genre's characteristic sound.

children.name: Ranchera
children.description: A popular genre of Mexican music developed in the nationalist theater of the post-1910 revolution period in Mexico.

children.name: Tejano Music
children.description: Mexican-American style infusing the conjunto Norteño ensemble with European dances and American popular music.

children.name: Nueva canción latinoamericana
children.description: Politically-charged messages associated with the rise of leftist social movements; striving for a renewal of traditional Latin and Hispanic American Folk Music expressions.

children.name: Nueva canción chilena
children.description: Socially conscious style that sought to recover traditional Chilean folk music and fuse it with the broader musical trends of Latin America.

children.name: Nueva trova
children.description: Found inspiration in the 1950s Cuban Revolution and had the intention of introducing new musical ideas to the original Trova.

children.name: Nuevo Cancionero
children.description: Musical-literary movement in Argentina that aimed to reevaluate and reinvigorate "la música popular nativa" (native popular music) and to be the voice of poor and marginalized Argentines.

children.name: Onda nueva
children.description: Based on Joropo, it incorporates elements of Bossa nova and Jazz.

children.name: Pasillo
children.description: Traditional dance popular in Ecuador and Colombia; based on European Waltz and often performed with guitar and mandolin.

children.name: Peruvian Music
children.description: Music developed by the Peruvian people.

children.name: Cumbia peruana
children.description: Developed in Peru and diversified into various subgenres, each with its own regional influences.

children.name: Música criolla peruana
children.description: Combination of African, Spanish, and Andean influences that originated after the time of the arrival of Spanish colonists and African slaves to Peru.

children.name: Marinera
children.description: Component of the coastal dance of the same name, often considered the national dance of Peru.

children.name: Tondero
children.description: Backing to the fast-paced dance that originated in northern Peru in the region of Piura of the same name; bands consist of a singer, a small chorus, two guitarists, along with the cajón and sometimes a spoon player.

children.name: Vals criollo
children.description: Originally characterized by its 3/4 time, heavy reliance on strongly plucked phrase on upper strings, and its guitar solo; often accompanied by a duet or a solo singer, normally singing about patriotic themes or social dilemmas.

children.name: Polka paraguaya
children.description: Popular music originating in Paraguay and the Province of Corrientes (Argentina), derived from the Bohemian polka and traditional music of Hispanic-Jesuit origin.

children.name: Porro
children.description: Lively Hispanic American Music and dance style native to Colombia which gained popularity in the 1940s.

children.name: Reggaetón
children.description: Rooted in Dancehall and mainly characterized by its heavy emphasis on the "dembow" rhythm; developed in Puerto Rico in the early 1990s under heavy influence from Hip Hop.

children.name: Bachatón
children.description: Mixes Bachata melodies and instrumentation with Reggaetón rhythms, rapping, and DJing.

children.name: Cubaton
children.description: Vocal delivery is often heavily auto-tuned and layered with adlibs, rhythm is syncopated, and Caribbean and African instrumentation is incorporated.

children.name: Cumbiatón
children.description: Combining Reggaetón  with Cumbia mexicana, and less frequently with other forms of traditional Mexican Music.

children.name: Neoperreo
children.description: Heavy emphasis on rhythm, influence from global trends in club music, and generally progressive lyrics.

children.name: RKT
children.description: Emerged in the early 2010s, characterized by minimalistic, rhythm-centric production heavily influenced by Cumbia villera and other Cumbia argentina styles.

children.name: Rhumba
children.description: Commercial adaptation of various Latin American genres; developed during the 1930s as the so-called "rhumba craze" unfolded in the United States.

children.name: Rioplatense Music
children.description: Music developed by the people of the Rio de la Plata region.

children.name: Candombe
children.description: Uruguayan popular music originating among Montevideo's Afro-Uruguayan population, based on three differently-sized drums.

children.name: Candombe beat
children.description: Fusion of Uruguayan Candombe with elements of Rock music.

children.name: Chamarrita rioplatense
children.description: Traditional genre and dance featuring similar rhythms to Milonga and typically performed with the guitar and accordion.

children.name: Electrotango
children.description: Combines Tango rhythms and melodies with Electronic music.

children.name: Milonga
children.description: Characterized by a slow rhythm usually performed on a guitar; generally considered a precursor to Tango.

children.name: Murga uruguaya
children.description: Variant originated in Montevideo that stands out for its rhythms, nasal vocals and choral arrangements.

children.name: Tango
children.description: Melancholic sound generally led by a guitar or bandoneon, originating in Buenos Aires by the late 19th century and gaining worldwide popularity from the 1920s to the 1950s.

children.name: Finnish Tango
children.description: Melancholic style developed in Finland in the 1930s and 1940s, influenced by traditional minor-key Finnish Folk Music melodies and the rhythms of German marches.

children.name: Tango nuevo
children.description: Adds new elements into traditional Argentine Tango, most importantly the incorporation of Jazz and Western Classical Music.

children.name: Rock andino
children.description: Emerged in the Andean countries in the late 1960s and early 1970s, incorporating traditional instruments and harmonies from Indigenous Andean Music within a Rock format.

children.name: Salsa
children.description: Often incorporating congas, timbales and bongos as well as smaller instruments, such as maracas, clave and güiro.

children.name: Salsa choke
children.description: Colombian style that takes heavy influence from Reggaetón, House, Hip Hop, and various Afro-Colombian and Colombian Pacific styles.

children.name: Salsa dura
children.description: Form of earlier Salsa, usually less rigid in structure allowing for extended jam sessions; lyrical themes follow around the "barrio" way of life and Latin American traditions.

children.name: Salsa romántica
children.description: Salsa following a stronger influence from Pop, typically sharing shorter, conventional structures and romantic lyricism.

children.name: Timba
children.description: Combines Salsa with other genres such as Hip Hop, Disco, Funk, Jazz and Rock.

children.name: Tamborera
children.description: Venezuelan-Panamanian popular genre which mixes local Tamborito with Cuban Music rhythms featuring the tambora as the main percussion instrument.

children.name: Tropicanibalismo
children.description: Colombian scene born in the early 2000s with the intention of reinventing Colombian coastal music, from a more current and experimental approach.

children.name: Vallenato
children.description: Accordion-led style of folk and popular music originating in Colombia's Caribbean region.

children.name: Xuc
children.description: Danceable style from El Salvador developed in the 1940s.

children.name: Murga
children.description: Popular carnival music traditional in some cities of Spain and Hispanic America.

children.name: Murga uruguaya
children.description: Variant originated in Montevideo that stands out for its rhythms, nasal vocals and choral arrangements.

children.name: Nueva canción
children.description: Latin American (Nueva canción latinoamericana) and Spanish (Nueva canción española) movement during the 1960s and 1970s.

children.name: Nueva canción española
children.description: Arose in Spain in the 1960s, inspired in part by Nova cançó's reclaiming of Catalan regional identity, that spread across the country in regional variations.

children.name: Nueva canción latinoamericana
children.description: Politically-charged messages associated with the rise of leftist social movements; striving for a renewal of traditional Latin and Hispanic American Folk Music expressions.

children.name: Nueva canción chilena
children.description: Socially conscious style that sought to recover traditional Chilean folk music and fuse it with the broader musical trends of Latin America.

children.name: Nueva trova
children.description: Found inspiration in the 1950s Cuban Revolution and had the intention of introducing new musical ideas to the original Trova.

children.name: Nuevo Cancionero
children.description: Musical-literary movement in Argentina that aimed to reevaluate and reinvigorate "la música popular nativa" (native popular music) and to be the voice of poor and marginalized Argentines.

children.name: Spanish Music
children.description: Music of Spain.

children.name: Bolero español
children.description: Spanish genre originating in the 18th century, based around moderate tempos in a 3/4 time signature accompanied by a dance of the same name.

children.name: Flamenco
children.description: Often accompanying the dance of the same name, this traditional Spanish style is based around fiery acoustic guitar rhythms, emotional vocals, and accompaniment from traditional percussion.

children.name: Bulería
children.description: Fast flamenco made up of a 12 beat cycle characterized by its vibrant, spontaneous and festive style.

children.name: Flamenco nuevo
children.description: Contemporary style of Flamenco which departs from tradition by incorporating influences from other genres like Jazz, Blues, and Rock.

children.name: Flamenco Jazz
