children.description: Combination of Jazz with Flamenco nuevo, the contemporary style of Flamenco, which was pioneered in the late 1960s.

children.name: Rumba flamenca
children.description: Flamenco subgenre, derived from the exchange of influences between Spain and Latin America.

children.name: Flamenco Pop
children.description: Originally developed in the mid 1960s, incorporated palos flamencos (Flamenco subgenres) and Copla into the format of feisty and lively Pop (particularly, Yé-yé).

children.name: Nueva canción española
children.description: Arose in Spain in the 1960s, inspired in part by Nova cançó's reclaiming of Catalan regional identity, that spread across the country in regional variations.

children.name: Rock andaluz
children.description: Emerged during the mid-1970s in Spain; primarily utilizes Flamenco and often Symphonic Prog elements.

children.name: Rumba catalana
children.description: Cheerful Catalan genre that takes influences from Rumba cubana, Andalusian Rumba flamenca, and Pop.

children.name: Spanish Classical Music
children.description: Incorporation of Spanish Music within the context of Western Classical Music, particularly characterized by the use of the classical guitar.

children.name: Canto mozárabe
children.description: Iberian form of plainchant that flourished roughly 550-1085 AD.

children.name: Zarzuela
children.description: Spanish dramatic genre where spoken scenes are mixed with passages sung in operatic or popular styles.

children.name: Género chico
children.description: Light, small-scale musical comedy with mild social commentary, populist themes, and catchy melodies.

children.name: Zarzuela barroca
children.description: Earliest form that draws from a broad range of artistic sources, including theater, operatic singing, instrumental music, dance, popular music, poetry, and comedy.

children.name: Zarzuela grande
children.description: Romantic musical comedy akin to Operetta developed during the mid-19th century.

children.name: Spanish Folk Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of Spain, widely diverse due to the distinct culture and traditions of the country's different regions.

children.name: Andalusian Folk Music
children.description: Flamenco of Andalusia in southern Spain, rooted in traditional music and dances and developed mostly after the 18th century by the Romani people of Andalusia (known locally as gitanos).

children.name: Saeta
children.description: Traditional religious praise song that originated in Andalusia, Spain towards the end of the late Middle Ages.

children.name: Sevillanas
children.description: Named after the city of Seville in Spain, typically rhythmic with a 3/4 beat and guitar accompaniment.

children.name: Aragonese Folk Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of the Aragonese people.

children.name: Asturian Folk Music
children.description: Traditions of the Spanish province of Asturias.

children.name: Canarian Folk Music
children.description: Traditional folk of the Canary Islands.

children.name: Chotis madrileño
children.description: Spanish variant of schottisch, a slow version of German Polka which developed through the incorporation of regional folk influences and an association with the local castizo culture in Madrid, the capital of Spain.

children.name: Copla
children.description: Evolved from Spanish theatrical styles like Cuplé and has strong links to Flamenco.

children.name: Cuplé
children.description: Originally developed in the 19th century as a blend of old theatre Spanish styles based in short monologues (jácara and tonadilla) and French Couplet.

children.name: Galician Folk Music
children.description: Traditional music of the Galician people.

children.name: Pasodoble
children.description: Mainly instrumental Spanish style primarily associated with bullfighting and popular celebrations, believed to originate from a double-time military march from France in the 18th century.

children.name: Tecnorumba
children.description: Blend of the themes and singing style of Rumba flamenca with the most commercial forms of House, Techno, and Makina.

name: Indigenous American Music
description: Diverse styles and genres developed by the indigenous peoples of the Americas.

children.name: Indigenous American Traditional Music
children.description: Meta-genre encompassing traditions attributed to the indigenous peoples of the Americas.

children.name: Athabaskan Fiddling
children.description: Fiddle playing of the Dene or "Athabaskan" people of modern-day Alaska, Yukon and the Northwest Territories.

children.name: Inuit Vocal Games
children.description: Practiced by the Inuit of Canada, two vocalists face each other decimeters away and try to outlast each other with intense and unusual vocal techniques.

children.name: James Bay Fiddling
children.description: Fiddle playing of the James Bay Cree people, characterised by a fusion of Scottish style with Cree rhythms.

children.name: Mapuche Folk Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of the Mapuche people of Chile and Argentina.

children.name: Powwow Music
children.description: Drum-based traditional music of Plains region Native American tribes, traditionally played at Pow-wows.

children.name: Tonada potosina
children.description: Traditional folk sung in Quechua, played on charangos and guitarillas, with a catchy, lively rhythm.

children.name: Unakesa
children.description: Lay song and dance of the Fulni-ô people.

children.name: Indigenous Andean Music
children.description: Diverse styles and genres developed by the indigenous peoples of the Andes.

children.name: Harawi
children.description: Repeating phrases of sung poetry dealing with emotional topics.

children.name: Huayno
children.description: Andean dance music that incorporates both pre-Hispanic and Western musical elements.

children.name: Bolivian Huayño
children.description: One of the most popular genres of Andean music in Bolivia, particularly present in the departments of Cochabamba, Chuquisaca, La Paz, Oruro and Potosí.

children.name: Carnavalito
children.description: Fast and lively; mostly played in northwestern Argentina in the provinces of Jujuy, Salta, and Tucumán.

children.name: Morenada
children.description: Vibrant and culturally significant music originating in Bolivia and characterized by the sound of the matraca and a marked and rigid duple meter with a slow march-like tempo.

children.name: Tonada potosina
children.description: Traditional folk sung in Quechua, played on charangos and guitarillas, with a catchy, lively rhythm.

children.name: Indigenous North American Music
children.description: Diverse styles and genres developed by the indigenous peoples of present-day Canada, the United States and northwestern Mexico.

children.name: Athabaskan Fiddling
children.description: Fiddle playing of the Dene or "Athabaskan" people of modern-day Alaska, Yukon and the Northwest Territories.

children.name: Inuit Music
children.description: Traditions of the Inuit people, the aboriginal peoples inhabiting the Arctic regions of Canada, Alaska, and Greenland.

children.name: Inuit Vocal Games
children.description: Practiced by the Inuit of Canada, two vocalists face each other decimeters away and try to outlast each other with intense and unusual vocal techniques.

children.name: James Bay Fiddling
children.description: Fiddle playing of the James Bay Cree people, characterised by a fusion of Scottish style with Cree rhythms.

children.name: Métis Music
children.description: Music of the indigenous Métis people of Canada and the United States.

children.name: Powwow Music
children.description: Drum-based traditional music of Plains region Native American tribes, traditionally played at Pow-wows.

children.name: Mesoamerican Music
children.description: Diverse styles and genres developed by the Indigenous peoples of Mesoamerica, a cultural region extending from central and southern Mexico through parts of Central America.

name: Islamic Modal Music
description: Common lineage for traditional classical music stretching from Morocco to Central Asia.

children.name: Arabic Classical Music
children.description: Arabic Classical Music tradition, whose guidelines for modulation, rhythm, and tuning were set down in treatises in the 8th and 9th centuries, based around Islamic Modal Music.

children.name: Andalusian Classical Music
children.description: Found primarily in the Andalusia region in southern Spain, generally thought to have beginnings in the Emirate of Cordoba during the period of Muslim control of the region in the 9th century.

children.name: Iraqi Maqam
children.description: Highly structured but semi-improvised and rhythmically complex compositions built around set structures which consist of specific maqam modes.

children.name: Sawt
children.description: Poetic vocal form with complex rhythms, emotive singing, and distinctive lute-backed melodies commonly found in the Gulf region and based on a maqam system.

children.name: Azerbaijani Mugham
children.description: Highly improvisational form of modal music characterized by the singing style and the themes of Azerbaijan’s history.

children.name: Persian Classical Music
children.description: Traditional art music of the Persian civilization.

children.name: Shashmaqam
children.description: Modal suite that brings together lyrical and instrumental songs, poetry, and dance shared by Tajik Music and Uzbek Music.

children.name: Sufiana kalam
children.description: Classical music of the Kashmir region, the northernmost part of the Indian subcontinent.

children.name: Turkish Classical Music
children.description: Classical music of Turkey, which uses the makam modal system, with the primary emphasis often being on the singers, who are accompanied by small ensembles.

children.name: Turkish Mevlevi Music
children.description: Traditional music performed among Turkish practitioners of the Mevlevi order of Sufism.

name: Islamic Religious Music & Recitation
description: Music and melodic recitation involved in the Islamic faith, such as the reading of the Qur'an with its melodic component (qira'ah), the adhan call to prayer, and the elements often used in the practice of dhikr (particularly in Sufism).

children.name: Ginan
children.description: Form of musical recitation sacred to Nizari Ismaili Muslims.

children.name: Maddahi
children.description: Singing for Shia Muslims to mourn in religious death anniversaries.

children.name: Nasheed
children.description: Vocal songs popular throughout the Islamic world, mostly performed A cappella though sometimes featuring light instrumentation.

children.name: Rapai dabõih
children.description: Religious music meant to accompany the dabõih ceremony of the Acehnese people.

children.name: Turkish Mevlevi Music
children.description: Traditional music performed among Turkish practitioners of the Mevlevi order of Sufism.

name: Jewish Music
description: Different Jewish forms coming from different regions of the world, influenced by local cultures.

children.name: Ashkenazi Music
children.description: Encompasses the various traditions and genres of the Ashkenazi Jews, an ethnoreligious group that was prominent and influential in Europe throughout most of the Middle Ages and the modern period.

children.name: Klezmer
children.description: Secular Ashkenazi Music traditionally used in ceremonies such as weddings and bar and bat mitzvahs.

children.name: Yiddish Folksong
children.description: Traditional folk developed in Ashkenazi Jewish communities, particularly those of Yiddish-speaking Eastern and Central Europe.

children.name: Hasidic Music
children.description: Covers the music of Hasidic Jews, primarily characterized by spiritual, intense, and devotional, singing and melodies.

children.name: Nigun
children.description: Form of spiritual, repetitive and immersive tunes that developed in Hasidic Jewish communities, typically vocal-led.

children.name: Jewish Liturgical Music
children.description: Employed for different purposes in the practices of Jewish religion, such as the Kriyat haTorah of biblical verses during synagogue services.

children.name: Ancient Levitical Music
children.description: Reconstruction of Jerusalem temple music.

children.name: Chazzanut
children.description: Traditions used by the Jewish cantor, the chazzan when reciting and chanting different parts of the Jewish prayer in Jewish Liturgical Music.

children.name: Kriyat haTorah
children.description: Practice of ritual liturgical chanting of the Masoretic text of the Tanakh, often done during synagogue services.

children.name: Piyyut
children.description: Liturgical Jewish poems that are chanted or recited during religious occasions such as daily prayers and holidays.

children.name: Muzika mizrahit
children.description: Middle Eastern-flavored Israeli popular music, usually performed by Mizrahi Jews, and combining aspects of the music of the North African, Middle Eastern, and Central Asian countries from which they descended.

children.name: Muzika yehudit mekorit
children.description: Rooted in traditional Jewish Music, especially Hasidic Music; incorporates modern influences, typically written on subjects of devotion and religion.

children.name: Oriental Jewish Music
children.description: Comprises the many traditions and styles of the various groups of Jews from the cultural East, loosely covering the Jewish groups of the Middle East, North Africa, and Central Asia.

children.name: Orthodox Pop
children.description: Combines Orthodox Jewish themes and prayer with Pop songwriting, usually sung in Hebrew.

children.name: Sephardic Music
children.description: Encompasses the various musical traditions of Sephardi Jews.

children.name: Ladino Folksong
children.description: Ladino-language Traditional Folk Music tunes that were written and preserved by Sephardic Jews.

children.name: Maftirim
children.description: Paraliturgical songs of Sephardi Jews who lived in Ottoman Empire.

name: Northern American Music
description: Regional styles with roots in Northern America, typically drawing from European folk and classical music as well as West African and indigenous American influences.

children.name: Ambient Americana
children.description: Ambient music made using traditional Americana and Country instrumentation.

children.name: Americana
children.description: Incorporates a broad swath of American Folk Music and Contemporary Folk influences, evolving alongside Alt-Country.

children.name: Red Dirt
children.description: Oklahoman and Texan acts descended from the Stillwater, Oklahoma independent Country scene of the 1980s.

children.name: American Folk Music
children.description: Traces back through the history of European and West African settlement and migration to North America, including parts of northern Mexico and Canada in addition to the United States.

children.name: Appalachian Folk Music
children.description: Folk of the Appalachian Mountains in the Eastern United States.

children.name: Old-Time
children.description: Pre-Bluegrass North American string band styles, particularly those rooted in Appalachian Folk Music.

children.name: Country Blues
children.description: Various styles of Blues originating in the rural US South, typically relying on expressive vocal delivery and featuring simple, usually acoustic instrumentation.

children.name: Acoustic Texas Blues
children.description: Laid-back swing rhythms and guitar ornamentation, including solos.

children.name: Delta Blues
children.description: One of the earliest forms of Blues, named for the Mississippi Delta region of the United States where it developed, with a highly rhythmic style and a typical 12-bar structure.

children.name: Hill Country Blues
children.description: Emphasizes a steady hypnotic groove, sparse percussive and highly energetic guitar riffs, and often features meandering structures with unconventional and usually fewer chord changes compared to Delta Blues.

children.name: Piedmont Blues
children.description: Developed in the early 20th century in the southern Appalachian foothills and characterized by a syncopated but melodic Ragtime-based finger-picking acoustic guitar style.

children.name: Field Hollers
children.description: Work song created by African-American slaves working on cotton plantations, which features an expressive vocal style to no strict rhythm.

children.name: Fife and Drum Blues
children.description: Rooted in martial Fife and Drum Corps music, originated among Afro-American communities in Mississippi.

children.name: Jug Band
children.description: Usually features a jug as the bass instrument as well as other homemade (or easily affordable) instruments, such as kazoos and washboards.

children.name: Ring Shout
children.description: Ritual practiced by African-Americans in the US South, characterized by shouting, chanting and people dancing in a circle while praying and clapping.

children.name: Sacred Harp Music
children.description: Predominantly 19th-century English hymns with tunes derived from old folk melodies.

children.name: Spirituals
children.description: Predecessor to Gospel that began as unaccompanied singing by American slaves; shares some of the characteristics of Work Songs.

children.name: Talking Blues
children.description: American Folk Music with spoken or nearly spoken vocals.

children.name: Traditional Black Gospel
children.description: Born out of Spirituals in the early 20th century with influence from Southern Gospel and Blues, often featuring passionate or energetic vocal performances, motifs of salvation, and testaments of hardship.

children.name: Traditional Cajun Music
children.description: Earliest and most "pure" form of Cajun Music, employing basic rhythms and frequent fiddle double stops.

children.name: Traditional Country
children.description: Closely aligned with American Folk Music and Blues roots, from country's inception in Appalachia and the American South until the popularity of Honky Tonk and Country Pop in the 1950s.

children.name: Close Harmony
children.description: Traditional two-part harmony singing performed mostly by brothers.

children.name: Country Gospel
children.description: Traditional Country that heavily incorporates Gospel.

children.name: Bluegrass Gospel
children.description: Incorporates the religious topics and harmony vocals found in Country Gospel.

children.name: Country Yodeling
children.description: Vocal technique of Yodeling, brought to the United States by German settlers, sung over the instrumentation of Traditional Country.

children.name: American Primitivism
children.description: Blends avant-garde and neo-classical compositions with traditional Country Blues fingerpicking techniques.

children.name: Barbershop
children.description: Harmonized singing consisting of four vocal elements: the 'lead' (2nd tenor), the 1st tenor, the baritone, and the bass.

children.name: Jubilee
children.description: Rooted in African-American culture, characterized by complex rhythms and call-and-response vocals.

children.name: Boogie Woogie
children.description: Early, uptempo Blues featuring the piano as the main instrument, with soloing and improvisation played over the top of a repetitive eight note bassline.

children.name: Canadian Folk Music
children.description: Traditional folk of the European settlers who arrived in Canada.

children.name: Canadian Maritime Folk
children.description: Traditional folk of Canada's Maritimes (Nova Scotia, Prince Edward Island, and New Brunswick).

children.name: Cape Breton Folk Music
children.description: Celtic Folk Music that emerged in Cape Breton, an island at the eastern shore of Nova Scotia, through immigrants from Scotland and Ireland.

children.name: Cape Breton Fiddling
children.description: Distinctive Celtic fiddling originating from the Scottish immigrants who settled in Canada on Cape Breton Island.

children.name: French-Canadian Folk Music
children.description: Brought by French colonists to their Nouvelle-France settlements, primarily based around French Folk Music with influences from English Folk Music and Celtic Folk Music, typically played during gatherings and holidays.

children.name: Newfoundland Folk Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of Newfoundland and Labrador, Canada's easternmost province.

children.name: Coon Song
children.description: Lyrical trend popular in the United States from around 1880 to 1920 that presents a racist and highly stereotyped image of African Americans connected with the subject matter and style of minstrel shows, though these songs could be in practically any style.

children.name: Country
children.description: American genre derived from Southern and Appalachian forms of American Folk Music and later Rock and Pop influences, with a focus on the life and culture of rural America.

children.name: Alt-Country
children.description: Arose in the 1980s and 1990s, performed by artists with roots in Alternative Rock and Indie Rock who were disconnected from the mainstream Country industry.

children.name: Gothic Country
children.description: Evokes the Southern Gothic literary genre through morbid lyrical themes and melancholic sounds that emphasize its American Folk Music and Post-Punk influences.

children.name: Bluegrass
children.description: Born in the Appalachian region of the United States during the late 1930s, characterized by fingerpicked banjo along with other traditional instruments.

children.name: Bluegrass Gospel
children.description: Incorporates the religious topics and harmony vocals found in Country Gospel.

children.name: Progressive Bluegrass
children.description: Mixing the sound and aesthetics of pure Bluegrass with a variety of influences outside of its Appalachian origins, including Jazz, Folk, Rock, and other forms of Country.

children.name: Jamgrass
children.description: Emphasizes instrumental jamming and extended performances with many outside influences.

children.name: Contemporary Country
children.description: Incorporates both heavily Pop-influenced styles, and the more pop-averse movement of Neo-Traditionalist Country.

children.name: Neo-Traditionalist Country
children.description: Emerged in the late 1980s as a reaction to the increased dominance of Country Pop, moving instead towards a Honky Tonk-rooted sound that centered the Singer-Songwriter.

children.name: Country & Irish
children.description: Developed in Ireland; combines North American Country with Irish Folk Music influences, often in the form of traditional Irish songs that have been adapted into country numbers.

children.name: Country Boogie
children.description: Uptempo style built around the Boogie Woogie rhythm, with strong beats and prominent electric guitar leads, made popular in the 1940s.

children.name: Country Pop
children.description: Combination of Country with Pop to appeal to a larger audience.

children.name: Bro-Country
children.description: Originated in the 21st century and takes its cues from Hip Hop, Pop and Contemporary Country.

children.name: Countrypolitan
children.description: Emphasizes Pop-oriented orchestration and songwriting while reducing the role of Country instrumentation and rhythms; often featuring lush string arrangements and group backing vocals.

children.name: Urban Cowboy
children.description: Melds country and Pop (best described as 70s L.A. soft pop), and sometimes leans towards Disco.

children.name: Honky Tonk
children.description: Upbeat style that retains much of the common instrumentation of Traditional Country, as well as featuring prominent guitars (especially the steel guitar), strong backbeats and lyrics commonly about the working-class life.

children.name: Bakersfield Sound
children.description: Country based heavily on electric instrumentation and a defined backbeat.

children.name: Truck Driving Country
children.description: Derived from Honky Tonk, Country Rock and Bakersfield Sound; aimed at the truck driving community.

children.name: Nashville Sound
children.description: Production style characterized by smooth vocals over a relaxed ensemble of guitars and rhythm section, and variously incorporating elements from other styles of Country and Pop.

children.name: Countrypolitan
children.description: Emphasizes Pop-oriented orchestration and songwriting while reducing the role of Country instrumentation and rhythms; often featuring lush string arrangements and group backing vocals.

children.name: Progressive Country
children.description: Blend of traditionalist Country styles with elements of Rock, Contemporary Folk, and other countercultural genres; characterized by realistic, self-reflective lyrics and non-traditional songwriting and production elements.

children.name: Outlaw Country
children.description: Rock-influenced reaction to mainstream Country Pop trends, featuring rebellious personas, darker lyrics, and Western-inspired outlaw imagery.

children.name: Red Dirt
children.description: Oklahoman and Texan acts descended from the Stillwater, Oklahoma independent Country scene of the 1980s.

children.name: Traditional Country
children.description: Closely aligned with American Folk Music and Blues roots, from country's inception in Appalachia and the American South until the popularity of Honky Tonk and Country Pop in the 1950s.

children.name: Close Harmony
children.description: Traditional two-part harmony singing performed mostly by brothers.

children.name: Country Gospel
children.description: Traditional Country that heavily incorporates Gospel.

children.name: Bluegrass Gospel
children.description: Incorporates the religious topics and harmony vocals found in Country Gospel.

children.name: Country Yodeling
children.description: Vocal technique of Yodeling, brought to the United States by German settlers, sung over the instrumentation of Traditional Country.

children.name: Western
children.description: Reflects and portrays the lifestyles of cowboys and other settlers of the Western United States through both Traditional Folk Music and popular song.

children.name: Western Swing
children.description: Blend of Traditional Country string instrumentation with the driving rhythms of Jazz and regional dance traditions, often prominently featuring fiddle and steel guitar.

children.name: Country Rock
children.description: Combination of contemporary Rock with more traditional American Country.

children.name: Cowboy Poetry
children.description: Descended from the oral traditions of cowboys and ranchers, written with traditional use of rhyme and meter, using humor and slang, and primarily concerning the cowboy profession, lifestyle, and legacy.

children.name: Greenlandic Music
children.description: Majorly from Inuit ethnic groups in Greenland, a large island between the Atlantic and Arctic Oceans.

children.name: Kalattut
children.description: Distinctive Folk tradition shaped by European cultural exchanges and indigenous Greenlandic heritage.

children.name: Vaigat
children.description: Contemporary popular music shaped by American cultural exchanges and indigenous Greenlandic heritage.

children.name: Hapa haole
children.description: Hawaiian musical traditions adapted to popular American Jazz and Pop styles.

children.name: Indigenous North American Music
children.description: Diverse styles and genres developed by the indigenous peoples of present-day Canada, the United States and northwestern Mexico.

children.name: Athabaskan Fiddling
children.description: Fiddle playing of the Dene or "Athabaskan" people of modern-day Alaska, Yukon and the Northwest Territories.

children.name: Inuit Music
children.description: Traditions of the Inuit people, the aboriginal peoples inhabiting the Arctic regions of Canada, Alaska, and Greenland.

children.name: Inuit Vocal Games
children.description: Practiced by the Inuit of Canada, two vocalists face each other decimeters away and try to outlast each other with intense and unusual vocal techniques.

children.name: James Bay Fiddling
children.description: Fiddle playing of the James Bay Cree people, characterised by a fusion of Scottish style with Cree rhythms.

children.name: Métis Music
children.description: Music of the indigenous Métis people of Canada and the United States.

children.name: Powwow Music
children.description: Drum-based traditional music of Plains region Native American tribes, traditionally played at Pow-wows.

children.name: Louisiana Music
children.description: Regional Music from the US state of Louisiana.

children.name: Cajun Music
children.description: Associated with the Cajun people of Louisiana where the genre was born, commonly regarded as an uptempo, accordion-driven style with a harsh, infectious beat.

children.name: Traditional Cajun Music
children.description: Earliest and most "pure" form of Cajun Music, employing basic rhythms and frequent fiddle double stops.

children.name: New Orleans Blues
children.description: Diverse scene in New Orleans since the beginning of the 20th century, commonly associated with a sound led by rollicking pianos with syncopated beats and backed by horns.

children.name: New Orleans Brass Band
children.description: New Orleans' unique combination of European-styled military bands with African folklore.

children.name: New Orleans R&B
children.description: Increased rhythmic complexity with added focus on piano and horns.

children.name: Swamp Blues
children.description: Originated in Baton Rouge, Louisiana in the 1950s, with a laid-back and relaxed sound that takes influence from Zydeco and Cajun Music.

children.name: Swamp Pop
children.description: Uniquely Cajun style of Rhythm & Blues distinguished by tripleted pianos and a slow Blues structure.

children.name: Zydeco
children.description: Uptempo accordion-led dance style mixing Creole and Cajun folk with African American popular music influences.

children.name: Nouveau zydeco
children.description: Adds new elements into contemporary Zydeco, most importantly the incorporation of Funk, Contemporary R&B and Hip Hop characteristics.

children.name: Minstrelsy
children.description: Popular song and entertainment tradition from the U.S. engendered in variety shows employing racist caricature and blackface.

children.name: Pep Band
children.description: Performs at athletic events, and typically performs modified versions of Pop songs.

children.name: Ragtime
children.description: Emerged in the 1890s; piano-led and characterized by a heavily syncopated rhythm.

children.name: Cakewalk
children.description: Developed alongside Ragtime, typically in 2/4 with a distinctive oompah rhythm, named for a dance created by enslaved black Americans as a mockery of the social dances of white slaveholders.

children.name: Honky-Tonk Piano
children.description: Nostalgic revival popularised in the 1950s which is more upbeat and whimsical, with a bright and detuned piano sound.

children.name: Novelty Piano
children.description: Popular in the 1920s; originated in Chicago and took influence from Jazz.

children.name: Stride
children.description: Early form of Ragtime-derived Jazz with improvisational tendencies; named for the performers' left hand "striding" across the piano keyboard.

children.name: Roots Rock
children.description: Consciously and predominantly incorporates elements of its predecessors and original roots such as Country, Blues, Rhythm & Blues, Rock & Roll, and American Folk Music, but also many other American traditions.

children.name: Swamp Rock
children.description: Intermixture of Zydeco, Cajun Music, New Orleans Blues, and Pop under the roof of Rock.

children.name: Tex-Mex
children.description: Mixes Rock & Roll, Blues, Country, and several types of Hispanic American Music, particularly Tejano Music.

children.name: Sacred Steel
children.description: Focused on instrumentals and played on the steel guitar.

children.name: Shaker Music
children.description: Created by the United Society of Believers in Christ's Second Appearing, better known as Shakers, for worship.

children.name: Southern Gospel
children.description: Initially sung A cappella by a Vocal Group quartet, sometimes with a pianist or guitar as accompaniment, with lyrics and messages primarily revolving around the teachings found within Christianity.

children.name: Tejano Music
children.description: Mexican-American style infusing the conjunto Norteño ensemble with European dances and American popular music.

children.name: Tin Pan Alley
children.description: Early era of popular song in the USA, broadly from the 1890s-1930s; influences include Ragtime, Vaudeville and parlour music.

children.name: Vaudeville
children.description: Performed in American musical theaters typically as part of a lowbrow, often comedic variety performance.

children.name: Vaudeville Blues
children.description: Vaudeville incorporating heavy Blues elements.

name: Oceanian Music
description: Rooted in the traditions of the geographic region of Oceania.

children.name: Australian Folk Music
children.description: Folk traditions of the European colonists and convicts in Australia.

children.name: Indigenous Australian Traditional Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of Aboriginal Australians and Torres Strait Islanders, collectively known as Indigenous Australians.

children.name: Djanba
children.description: Sung and composed in the Murrinh-Patha language and consisting of a mixed group of men and women accompanied by bilma and handclaps, typically without didgeridoo.

children.name: Melanesian Music
children.description: Music of the Oceanian region of Melanesia.

children.name: Fijian Music
children.description: Music of the Fijian people.

children.name: Vude
children.description: Blends traditional local music with elements of Disco, Country and Rock.

children.name: Kaneka
children.description: New Caledonian style of popular music that draws influence from traditional Melanesian music.

children.name: Lokal musik
children.description: Created by local, rural artists from Papua New Guinea that incorporate some elements of Papuan Folk Music into Pop.

children.name: Papuan Folk Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of the Papuan people of New Guinea.

children.name: Tolai Rock
children.description: Fuses the music of the Tolai people of Papua New Guinea with Rock.

children.name: Micronesian Music
children.description: Music of the Micronesian peoples.

children.name: Kantan Chamorrita
children.description: Improvised verse singing performed in the Chamorro language, traditional of the Marianas islands.

children.name: Pacific Reggae
children.description: Developed in Pacific island communities, incorporating elements from local Oceanian Music styles.

children.name: Polynesian Music
children.description: Music of Polynesia.

children.name: Fijian Music
children.description: Music of the Fijian people.

children.name: Vude
children.description: Blends traditional local music with elements of Disco, Country and Rock.

children.name: Hawaiian Music
children.description: Includes a variety of syncopated rhythms, percussion and vocal styles, including chanting (mele) and falsetto.

children.name: Hapa haole
children.description: Hawaiian musical traditions adapted to popular American Jazz and Pop styles.

children.name: Slack-Key Guitar
children.description: Originated in Hawaii and typically played with one's thumb in an alternating-bass pattern on the lower two or three strings.

children.name: Himene tarava
children.description: Protestant choral songs in Tahiti and other southern Polynesian islands (Cook Is., Society Is., etc.)

children.name: Māori Music
children.description: Music of the indigenous Māori people of New Zealand.

children.name: Samoan Music
children.description: Music of the Samoan people.

children.name: Tahitian Music
children.description: Music of the Tahitian people.

name: Polyphonic Chant
description: Chanting that combines two or more melodic lines that are harmonically cohesive but differ in rhythm and utilize non-parallel motion.

children.name: Ars nova
children.description: Period (around 1310-1380) that succeeded Ars antiqua, mixing the sacred with the secular.

children.name: Ars subtilior
children.description: Emerged in the final period of late medieval music (around 1380-1420) and continued to use the technique of isorhythms but with added complexity.

children.name: Cante alentejano
children.description: Traditional Portuguese Music based on vocal music from the Alentejo region.

children.name: Cantu a tenore
children.description: Secular Polyphonic Chant from the Mediterranean island of Sardinia.

children.name: Ganga
children.description: Dissonant form of polyphonic singing from the regions of Herzegovina and Dalmatia.

children.name: Himene tarava
children.description: Protestant choral songs in Tahiti and other southern Polynesian islands (Cook Is., Society Is., etc.)

children.name: Izvorna bosanska muzika
children.description: Polyphonic vocal music that developed in Bosnia in the 20th century, bearing connections to traditional Bosnian genres.

children.name: Lab Polyphony
children.description: One of several genres of iso-polyphonic music performed in southern Albania, with "iso" referring to the distinctive drone voice used.

children.name: Madrigal
children.description: Secular polyphonic music based around poetry and generally performed by unaccompanied vocal ensembles of two to eight persons.

children.name: Paghjella
children.description: Traditional Polyphonic Chant from Corsica consisting of three registers of vocalists singing in a semicircle.

children.name: Seto leelo
children.description: Style of polyphonic singing of the Seto people.

children.name: Sutartinės
children.description: Highly unique form of polyphonic vocal folk music originating from a small area of Northeastern Lithuania.

children.name: Tosk Polyphony
children.description: Polyphonic singing in the Toskëri region of southern Albania.

children.name: Trallalero
children.description: Polyphonic Traditional Folk Music originating in the Ligurian region of Genoa, in northern Italy.

name: Prehistoric Music
description: Styles from the first cultural periods of the human species (Homo sapiens, as well as certain Homo neanderthalis), particularly the Paleolithic and Neolithic eras, from its birth to the Ancient Music era beginning around 2000-3000 BC.

name: South American Music
description: Rooted in the traditions of South America.

children.name: Argentine Music
children.description: Music developed by the Argentine people.

children.name: Cuarteto
children.description: Originated in the Argentinian province of Córdoba, usually with an upbeat rhythm and originally performed with a four-piece band.

children.name: Cumbia argentina
children.description: Almost always features synthesizer keyboards and electronic percussion with an upbeat rhythm.

children.name: Cumbia santafesina
children.description: Originated in the Argentinian province of Santa Fe, particularly in its capital city Santa Fe de la Vera Cruz, with lyrics that tend to be romantic and relatively clean compared to later Cumbia argentina.

children.name: Cumbia turra
children.description: Cumbia argentina heavily influenced by Reggaetón and characterized by hard-hitting bass and heavy use of samples and Auto-Tune.

children.name: Cumbia villera
children.description: Developed in the villa miserias (shanty towns) by the lower classes of Argentina in the early 2000s, featuring basic rhythms and low budget productions combined with lyrics that can be openly sexual or touch on sociopolitical issues.

children.name: Nuevo Cancionero
children.description: Musical-literary movement in Argentina that aimed to reevaluate and reinvigorate "la música popular nativa" (native popular music) and to be the voice of poor and marginalized Argentines.

children.name: Avanzada
children.description: Fusion of Polka paraguaya and Guarania with elements of Bossa nova and MPB.

children.name: Bailecito
children.description: Agile and lively dance derived from Zamacueca, typical of the western and central region of Bolivia.

children.name: Baithak gana
children.description: Indo-Caribbean genre from Suriname, consisting of Bhojpuri Folk Music with local Caribbean influence.

children.name: Bambuco
children.description: Follows a 6/8 or 3/4 time signature with non-percussive instrumentation, often melancholic in sound with bright guitars and a rich melodic base.

children.name: Brazilian Music
children.description: All forms of music with roots in Brazil.

children.name: Bandinha
children.description: Popular style of music from the Southern region of Brazil. Borrows elements from German Folk Music, Sertanejo romântico and Brega.

children.name: Bossa nova
children.description: Conceived as a new style to perform original Samba, with major American Jazz influences.

children.name: Brazilian Classical Music
children.description: Originated in the late 19th century, taking the European music that had been brought to the country by colonists and brought in parts of Brazilian Music.

children.name: Valsa brasileira
children.description: Brazillian Waltz characterized by its slow rhythms and romantic sound.

children.name: Brazilian Folk Music
children.description: Comprises the various traditions of folk music found in Brazil, often resulting from the interplay of Indigenous, African and European music.

children.name: Aboio
children.description: Cattle-herding songs originating in rural Northeastern Brazil.

children.name: Aboio cantado
children.description: Aboio that features rhyming verses.

children.name: Banda de pífano
children.description: Lively music played by bands consisting of two fifes and percussion.

children.name: Candomblé Music
children.description: Music of the Afro-Brazilian Candomblé religion that influenced the secular Afoxé.

children.name: Cantoria
children.description: Sung poetry of itinerant cantadores from Northeastern Brazil.

children.name: Repente
children.description: Contest of fully improvised poetry sung in different stanza formats.

children.name: Capoeira Music
children.description: Afro-Brazilian style that accompanies and sets the rhythm and energy of the capoeira martial art, originating in the 19th century with the relocation of African slaves to the states of Bahia and Rio de Janeiro.

children.name: Fandango caiçara
children.description: Style of fandango born in coastal Southern Brazil amidst the Caiçara people.

children.name: Jongo
children.description: Afro-Brazilian cultural manifestation involving music and dance; composed of percussion instruments and chants.

children.name: Ponto de umbanda
children.description: Afro-Brazilian religious ritualistic praise sung by priests to evoke entities; typically accompanied by claps and traditional drums known as atabaque.

children.name: Lundu
children.description: Afro-Brazilian musical genre that emerged in the 18th century with influences from African drumming with European Fandango.

children.name: Maracatu
children.description: Afro-Brazilian genre which accompanies the cultural manifestation of the same name, hailing from the northeastern state of Pernambuco.

children.name: Modinha
children.description: Popular during the 18th and 19th centuries in Brazil; characterized by sentimental works with amorous themes, poetic lyrics, acoustic instrumentation and operatic vocals.

children.name: Rasqueado
children.description: Regional dance and its accompanying music from the Brazilian midwest, predominantly the state of Mato Grosso.

children.name: Samba de roda
children.description: Mixed Portuguese culture with African slave traditions, as well as sharing roots and similarities with Batuque and Jongo.

children.name: Sertanejo de raiz
children.description: Earliest form of Sertanejo, emerging in pre-World War II rural Brazil during the late 1920s; quickly strummed acoustic guitars, most commonly the 10-string viola caipira and classical guitar, and a highly emotive vocal style.

children.name: Moda de viola
children.description: Style of Sertanejo de raiz predominant in southeast, south, and west-central Brazil.

children.name: Toada de Boi
children.description: Slow, heavy-percussed tunes celebrating the folkloric Ox, originally from Bumba-meu-boi June parties in Northeastern Brazil.

children.name: Brega
children.description: Overstated, dramatic music with a romantic singing style.

children.name: Arrocha
children.description: Influenced by Brega's romantic style, with further influence from Axé and Forró, giving it a more sensual and euphoric feel.

children.name: Arrochadeira
children.description: Developed in the mid-2000s in Bahia by Dan Ventura, merges the electronic keyboards of Arrocha with Pagodão rhythms.

children.name: Bregadeira
children.description: Fuses contemporary rhythms from the Brazilian Northeast such as Arrocha, Pagodão and Piseiro, with the electronic beats of Funk brasileiro and its subgenres.

children.name: Brega calypso
children.description: Romantic vocals and lyrics, bubbly and sensual melodies and rhythms, horn sections and lush Caribbean-like guitar riffs over fast tempos.

children.name: Brega funk
children.description: Rooted in Tecnobrega, features glossy syncopated MIDI pianos and synths, distinct pitched metallic snares and vocal chops over a wonky kick rhythm.

children.name: Batidão romântico
children.description: Slower and romantic Kizomba-fused beats.

children.name: Tecnobrega
children.description: Fast and electronic-based style that evolved from Brega calypso, particularly associated with peripheral areas of the city of Belém.

children.name: Tecnofunk
children.description: Raw and vulgar Tecnobrega and Funk brasileiro fusion developed in the late 2010s by DJs in Belém do Pará.

children.name: Choro
children.description: Brazilian urban genre named after the crying-like harmony generated by the very particular group of instruments used to play it: seven-string acoustic guitar, mandolin, flute, cavaquinho, and pandeiro.

children.name: Samba-choro
children.description: Emerged in the 1930s as the result of a fusion of rhythmic elements and combining Samba with Choro.

children.name: Dobrado
children.description: Brazilian musical genre, played by military bands with wooden, brass and also percussive instruments.

children.name: Funk brasileiro
children.description: Hip Hop-influenced dance style originating from the favelas of Rio de Janeiro, originally rooted in Electro and Miami Bass and known primarily as "funk" in Brazil.

children.name: Arrocha funk
children.description: Slow and gritty Reggaetón-like drums with an emphasis on brass sections influenced by Arrocha.

children.name: Brega funk
children.description: Rooted in Tecnobrega, features glossy syncopated MIDI pianos and synths, distinct pitched metallic snares and vocal chops over a wonky kick rhythm.

children.name: Batidão romântico
children.description: Slower and romantic Kizomba-fused beats.

children.name: Funk 150 bpm
children.description: Fast tempos, typically reaching 150 bpm and sometimes beyond it, heightened energy and typically faster flows as well.

children.name: Funk carioca
children.description: Early scene of Funk brasileiro that began in Rio de Janeiro, developed from a local take on American Miami Bass.

children.name: Funk de BH
children.description: Atmospheric, mellow and minimalistic production with sparse percussion, often featuring sound effects or filtered samples.

children.name: Funk mandelão
children.description: Simple lyricism, raw and minimalistic production, and distinct drops with bursting bass.

children.name: Beat bruxaria
children.description: São Paulo-originated Funk brasileiro with aggressive, distorted and high-pitched beats featuring minimalistic percussion and diversified sampling.

children.name: Funk melody
children.description: Derivative of Funk brasileiro in a Dance-Pop direction, originating in Rio de Janeiro.

children.name: Funk ostentação
children.description: Began in the late 2000s in the São Paulo metro area and the Baixada Santista region in São Paulo state, featuring stronger influence from Pop Rap that gives it a more accessible sound.

children.name: Funk proibidão
children.description: Raw, aggressive style that developed in the favelas of Rio de Janeiro in the 1990s, with a name translating to "prohibited funk" that hints at its gang origin.

children.name: Mega funk
children.description: Blends funk vocal performances with production derived from mainstage 2010s house genres like Brazilian Bass and Slap House.

children.name: Rasteirinha
children.description: Slow-paced, highly rhythmic with instrumentation derived from Samba and Axé, and Reggaetón-inspired grooves.

children.name: Tamborzão
children.description: Adds Afro-Brazilian elements such as the atabaque sound into the Miami Bass kick drums.

children.name: Tecnofunk
children.description: Raw and vulgar Tecnobrega and Funk brasileiro fusion developed in the late 2010s by DJs in Belém do Pará.

children.name: Maxixe
children.description: Appeared in Rio de Janeiro at the end of the 19th century, compared with and influenced by Tango.

children.name: MPB
children.description: Short for música popular brasileira; formed in the mid-1960s as a modernized version of Bossa nova and Samba-canção.

children.name: Tropicália
children.description: Brazilian counterculture art movement started in 1967 blending Psychedelic Rock, Psychedelic Pop, and Experimental production with contemporary Brazilian pop, with the lyrics being left wing-tinted abstract poetry.

children.name: Música gaúcha
children.description: Popular music style of southern Brazil, based on the traditional polka and other European rhythms.

children.name: Vanera
children.description: Typical dance style music from Rio Grande do Sul in Brazil, and very present in the states of Paraná and Santa Catarina.

children.name: Northeastern Brazilian Music
children.description: Regional styles that combines elements of indigenous, African and European traditions, historically with a focus on life of the northeastern people, such as drought, migration, the struggle for survival, love and nostalgia, and often danced in intense and accelerated movements.

children.name: Aboio
children.description: Cattle-herding songs originating in rural Northeastern Brazil.

children.name: Aboio cantado
children.description: Aboio that features rhyming verses.

children.name: Afoxé
children.description: Afro-Brazilian genre originating in the states of Pernambuco and Bahia, characterized by the ijexá rhythm invented by the Yoruba people.

children.name: Arrocha
children.description: Influenced by Brega's romantic style, with further influence from Axé and Forró, giving it a more sensual and euphoric feel.

children.name: Arrochadeira
children.description: Developed in the mid-2000s in Bahia by Dan Ventura, merges the electronic keyboards of Arrocha with Pagodão rhythms.

children.name: Bregadeira
children.description: Fuses contemporary rhythms from the Brazilian Northeast such as Arrocha, Pagodão and Piseiro, with the electronic beats of Funk brasileiro and its subgenres.

children.name: Axé
children.description: Developed from a fusion of Frevo, Maracatu, Forró, Reggae and Calypso with roots in the Salvador de Bahia carnival.

children.name: Pagodão
children.description: Predominance of guitar riffs, atabaques, pandeiros and drums.

children.name: Arrochadeira
children.description: Developed in the mid-2000s in Bahia by Dan Ventura, merges the electronic keyboards of Arrocha with Pagodão rhythms.

children.name: Samba-reggae
children.description: Percussion-focused style from Bahia, Brazil, originating in the 1980s and 1990s in the Bahian carnival's afro-blocos.

children.name: Baião
children.description: Commonly performed with accordions and violas caipiras, and often accompanied by agogô and triangle.

children.name: Banda de pífano
children.description: Lively music played by bands consisting of two fifes and percussion.

children.name: Brega funk
children.description: Rooted in Tecnobrega, features glossy syncopated MIDI pianos and synths, distinct pitched metallic snares and vocal chops over a wonky kick rhythm.

children.name: Batidão romântico
children.description: Slower and romantic Kizomba-fused beats.

children.name: Cantoria
children.description: Sung poetry of itinerant cantadores from Northeastern Brazil.

children.name: Repente
children.description: Contest of fully improvised poetry sung in different stanza formats.

children.name: Coco
children.description: Performers usually gather in a circle which rounds the dancers, clapping and spinning according to the rhythm; influenced by cultures originating from Africa, conceived in Northeastern Brazil.

children.name: Ciranda
children.description: Employs a metrical scheme of quatrains, long verses, and slow pace, with lyrical themes generally limited to love.

children.name: Embolada
children.description: Focuses on the prosody of singers, who speak-sing improvised or written stanzas in fast tempos in 2/4 time, accompanied by sparse percussion.

children.name: Forró
children.description: Developed from Baião and the dance rhythms quadrilha and xaxado, along with influences of European Folk Music like chula and schottische (Xote).

children.name: Forró eletrônico
children.description: Uses electronic elements through the inclusion of keyboards, bass, and electric guitar.

children.name: Piseiro
children.description: Originated in the interior of northeast Brazil in the 2000s, characterized by the combination of electronic keyboards with vocal harmonization; typically considered a homemade style of Forró eletrônico.

children.name: Forró universitário
children.description: Originated in the 1990s by university students in the Brazilian state of São Paulo; blends the original style with influences from genres like Rock, Reggae, and Funk.

children.name: Frevo
children.description: Played in a very fast, binary tempo; originated in 1910 on the streets of the northeastern Brazilian city of Recife.

children.name: Manguebeat
children.description: Counterculture fusion of traditional Northeastern Brazilian Music genres with modern Rock and Hip Hop.

children.name: Maracatu
children.description: Afro-Brazilian genre which accompanies the cultural manifestation of the same name, hailing from the northeastern state of Pernambuco.

children.name: Samba de roda
children.description: Mixed Portuguese culture with African slave traditions, as well as sharing roots and similarities with Batuque and Jongo.

children.name: Unakesa
children.description: Lay song and dance of the Fulni-ô people.

children.name: Northern Brazilian Music
children.description: Regional styles rooted in Northern Brazil, often influenced by Caribbean rhythms and instrumentations, usually with focus on romance, celebrations, the relationship between the man and the Amazon rainforest, and danced in fast and sensual movements.

children.name: Brega calypso
children.description: Romantic vocals and lyrics, bubbly and sensual melodies and rhythms, horn sections and lush Caribbean-like guitar riffs over fast tempos.

children.name: Carimbó
children.description: Originated in rural areas in the state of Pará, danced frenetically to the beat of syncopated drums, with international recognition after its modernization.

children.name: Lambada
children.description: Carimbó, Cumbia and Forró rhythm structures composed the overall form, with Maxixe and Merengue as dance influences.

children.name: Guitarrada
children.description: Melodic and usually instrumental approach, centered around the electric guitar.

children.name: Tecnobrega
children.description: Fast and electronic-based style that evolved from Brega calypso, particularly associated with peripheral areas of the city of Belém.

children.name: Tecnofunk
children.description: Raw and vulgar Tecnobrega and Funk brasileiro fusion developed in the late 2010s by DJs in Belém do Pará.

children.name: Rock rural
children.description: Brazilian Folk Rock that emerged in the 1970s, incorporating elements of Sertanejo, Country Rock, and MPB.

children.name: Samba
children.description: Originated in the 19th century from a blend of various rhythmic styles of African Music, forming a new sound, structure, and a dance of the same name.

children.name: Batucada
children.description: Heavily percussive and polyrhythmic Samba.

children.name: Marchinha
children.description: Originating from Portuguese popular street marches (marchas populares), featuring simple, joyful melodies and sometimes malicious lyrics.

children.name: Pagode
children.description: Used for samba groups whose music was performed in the suburban Cariocas parties, with romantic lyrical content and improvisation.

children.name: Pagodão
children.description: Predominance of guitar riffs, atabaques, pandeiros and drums.

children.name: Arrochadeira
children.description: Developed in the mid-2000s in Bahia by Dan Ventura, merges the electronic keyboards of Arrocha with Pagodão rhythms.

children.name: Pagode romântico
children.description: Overly romantic lyrics and Pop overtones, with the addition of mainstream instruments like the prominent employment of bass, synths and drumkit alongside the traditional tantã, repique de mão and banjo.

children.name: Partido alto
children.description: Originating from the early roots of Samba primarily in Rio de Janeiro in the beginning of the 20th century, initially as a more danceable style with little or no vocals.

children.name: Samba-canção
children.description: Romantic, commercial form of Samba that was popular in Brazil between the 1930s and the 1950s.

children.name: Samba-choro
children.description: Emerged in the 1930s as the result of a fusion of rhythmic elements and combining Samba with Choro.

children.name: Samba de breque
children.description: Development of Samba-choro characterized by sudden pauses in its syncopated rhythms.

children.name: Samba de gafieira
children.description: Emerged in the 1930s, with the influence of Choro, Maxixe, Lundu, and Big Band from the the United States.

children.name: Samba de roda
children.description: Mixed Portuguese culture with African slave traditions, as well as sharing roots and similarities with Batuque and Jongo.

children.name: Samba de terreiro
children.description: Urban Samba from the samba schools of Rio de Janeiro, with short songs about everyday topics and love.

children.name: Samba-enredo
children.description: Developed in the 1930s in Brazilian samba schools (escola de samba) to be presented and performed at carnivals.

children.name: Samba-exaltação
children.description: Developed in the early forties, with lyrics mainly exalting the culture of Brazil.

children.name: Samba-joia
children.description: Emerged in the 1970s, featuring a strong influence from Bolero along with overly romantic lyrics.

children.name: Sambalanço
children.description: Popular genre in Brazil during the 1950s and 1960s, with influence of Samba and Jazz.

children.name: Samba-rock
children.description: Blends the rhythmic sound of Samba with Rock, as well as additional influences from Jazz and Soul.

children.name: Samba Soul
children.description: Brazilian genre developed in late 1960s and very successful in early 1970s with the popularization of Soul and Funk in Brazil plus a mixing of Samba-rock elements.

children.name: Samba-jazz
children.description: Jazz genre from Brazil that incorporates Samba and/or Bossa nova elements.

children.name: Sertanejo
children.description: Acoustic guitar-based and originated from the rural parts of Brazilian Center-South region.

children.name: Rasqueado
children.description: Regional dance and its accompanying music from the Brazilian midwest, predominantly the state of Mato Grosso.

children.name: Sertanejo de raiz
children.description: Earliest form of Sertanejo, emerging in pre-World War II rural Brazil during the late 1920s; quickly strummed acoustic guitars, most commonly the 10-string viola caipira and classical guitar, and a highly emotive vocal style.

children.name: Moda de viola
children.description: Style of Sertanejo de raiz predominant in southeast, south, and west-central Brazil.

children.name: Sertanejo romântico
children.description: Hybrid of Brazilian Sertanejo with Pop production and aesthetics, made popular nationwide during the mid-to-late 1980s.

children.name: Sertanejo universitário
children.description: Third evolution of Sertanejo, sharing close sensibilities with national Brazilian Pop music and other regional styles.

children.name: Arrocha sertanejo
children.description: Merged the Arrocha style with the younger audience creating a more energetic and more danceable rhythm.

children.name: Funknejo
children.description: Incorporates the rhythms, production, and idioms of Funk brasileiro into the universitário genre.

children.name: Vanguarda paulista
children.description: Brazilian cultural movement that began in the city of São Paulo and lasted from 1979 to 1985; united a variety of artists who had no access to major labels due to their experimental, avant-garde approach.

children.name: Xote
children.description: Slow and danceable Brazilian rhythm.

children.name: Bullerengue
children.description: Afro-Colombian popular genre which features a strong emphasis on rhythm and improvisation and a call-and-response format.

children.name: Calipso venezolano
children.description: Derived from Trinidadian Calypso, popular in the eastern region of Venezuela and associated with Carnival.

children.name: Caporal
children.description: Bolivian neofolkloric dance music characterized by a double beat bass drum pattern that emerged in the latter half of the twentieth century.

children.name: Carnaval cruceño
children.description: Danceable genre, similar to the Polka, from the city of Santa Cruz, Bolivia, characteristic of the area’s Carnival celebrations and generally composed for brass band musicians.

children.name: Carranga
children.description: Colombian folk music that originated in Boyacá province, best known for its wordplay and humorous lyrics.

children.name: Chacarera
children.description: Originated in northwest Argentina and southern Bolivia around 1850, typically in 6/8 and traditionally performed with instruments like the guitar, bombo legüero (traditional drum), and violin.

children.name: Chamamé
children.description: Mixes native Guaraní music with Polka paraguaya and European schottische music.

children.name: Champeta
children.description: Colombian genre heavily influenced by the traditional music of San Basilio de Palenque as well as modern Caribbean and African sensibilities.

children.name: Chilean Music
children.description: Music developed by the Chilean people.

children.name: Canto a lo poeta
children.description: Sung poetry traditional to Chile and transmitted orally from one generation to another.

children.name: Chilote Music
children.description: Music of the Chiloé Archipelago.

children.name: Cumbia chilena
children.description: Incorporates Chilean Music into the traditional sound of Cumbia.

children.name: Nueva cumbia chilena
children.description: Incorporating various instruments and rhythmic components from diverse genres such as Ska, Salsa, Indigenous Andean Music, Reggae, and Bolero.

children.name: Jazz guachaca
children.description: Encompasses Jazz influences with Hispanic American Music styles such as Cueca, Bolero, Tango and Corrido.

children.name: Mambo chileno
children.description: Emerged in the early 2010s in Chile, characterized by upbeat rhythms and rapping, usually on topics of parties, dancing, and urban life.

children.name: Música cebolla
children.description: Chilean offshoot of Canción melódica that expresses a much more melancholic or nostalgic side.

children.name: Música típica chilena
children.description: Incorporation of rural folklore music to urban fields, adding vocal groups accompanied mainly by guitar and a "huaso" symbolism.

children.name: Neofolklore
children.description: Short-lived movement that reincorporated traditional Chilean folklore into modern production and styling inspired by foreign musicians.

children.name: Nueva canción chilena
children.description: Socially conscious style that sought to recover traditional Chilean folk music and fuse it with the broader musical trends of Latin America.

children.name: Tonada chilena
children.description: Traditional folk from the Chilean countryside distinguished by its prominent melody.

children.name: Chuntunqui romántico
children.description: Vibrant Bolivian genre set in 6/8 meter featuring choral refrains, harmonic progressions, and lyrics exploring the subject of romantic love.

children.name: Conjunto andino
children.description: Urban folk ensembles using musical instruments of Andean Indigenous origin or association; despite frequent association with Indigenous villages, they bear little resemblance to the Indigenous expressions of the Southern Andes.

children.name: Cueca
children.description: Popular in Chile, Argentina, and Bolivia, accompanied by a 6/8 or 3/4 time signature and usually structured into 14 verses.

children.name: Cumbia colombiana
children.description: Style that incorporates elements of Colombian traditional music, which includes and keeps influences from Spanish, African, and Indigenous cultures.

children.name: Cumbia pop
children.description: Developed in the Río de la Plata region in the mid-2010s, featuring Latin Pop influences and lyrics related to romance, youth, and fun.

children.name: Currulao
children.description: Pacific coast Afro-Colombian music and folk dance performed by a marimba/percussion ensemble with heavy use of call-and-response vocals.

children.name: Gaita zuliana
children.description: Emerged in the state of Zulia in the 1950s, merging Spanish Folk Music and Venezuelan Christmas carols.

children.name: Guarania
children.description: Slow and melancholic rhythms, primarily performed on the Paraguayan harp.

children.name: Indigenous Andean Music
children.description: Diverse styles and genres developed by the indigenous peoples of the Andes.

children.name: Harawi
children.description: Repeating phrases of sung poetry dealing with emotional topics.

children.name: Huayno
children.description: Andean dance music that incorporates both pre-Hispanic and Western musical elements.

children.name: Bolivian Huayño
children.description: One of the most popular genres of Andean music in Bolivia, particularly present in the departments of Cochabamba, Chuquisaca, La Paz, Oruro and Potosí.

children.name: Carnavalito
children.description: Fast and lively; mostly played in northwestern Argentina in the provinces of Jujuy, Salta, and Tucumán.

children.name: Morenada
children.description: Vibrant and culturally significant music originating in Bolivia and characterized by the sound of the matraca and a marked and rigid duple meter with a slow march-like tempo.

children.name: Tonada potosina
children.description: Traditional folk sung in Quechua, played on charangos and guitarillas, with a catchy, lively rhythm.

children.name: Joropo
children.description: Incorporates elements of Creole music and the Venezuelan waltz.

children.name: Kaseko
children.description: Surinamese popular music with roots in Surinamese Creole music, which was influenced by folk traditions of Africa, Europe, and the Americas.

children.name: Malagueña venezolana
children.description: Traditional musical accompaniment to the Venezuelan 'velorios de cruz de mayo' celebrations, played with the mandolin (as lead instrument), cuatro and guitar.

children.name: Mapuche Folk Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of the Mapuche people of Chile and Argentina.

children.name: Muliza
children.description: Mestizo folk genre popular in the central Peruvian Andes, characterized by a pronounced, though sedate, rhythm; traces of Andean melody; and octosyllabic verses.

children.name: Onda nueva
children.description: Based on Joropo, it incorporates elements of Bossa nova and Jazz.

children.name: Pasillo
children.description: Traditional dance popular in Ecuador and Colombia; based on European Waltz and often performed with guitar and mandolin.

children.name: Payada
children.description: Improvised poetry accompanied by a guitar that is tied to gaucho culture, usually performed in duo as a verse duel.

children.name: Peruvian Music
children.description: Music developed by the Peruvian people.

children.name: Cumbia peruana
children.description: Developed in Peru and diversified into various subgenres, each with its own regional influences.

children.name: Música criolla peruana
children.description: Combination of African, Spanish, and Andean influences that originated after the time of the arrival of Spanish colonists and African slaves to Peru.

children.name: Marinera
children.description: Component of the coastal dance of the same name, often considered the national dance of Peru.

children.name: Tondero
children.description: Backing to the fast-paced dance that originated in northern Peru in the region of Piura of the same name; bands consist of a singer, a small chorus, two guitarists, along with the cajón and sometimes a spoon player.

children.name: Vals criollo
children.description: Originally characterized by its 3/4 time, heavy reliance on strongly plucked phrase on upper strings, and its guitar solo; often accompanied by a duet or a solo singer, normally singing about patriotic themes or social dilemmas.

children.name: Polka paraguaya
children.description: Popular music originating in Paraguay and the Province of Corrientes (Argentina), derived from the Bohemian polka and traditional music of Hispanic-Jesuit origin.

children.name: Porro
children.description: Lively Hispanic American Music and dance style native to Colombia which gained popularity in the 1940s.

children.name: Rioplatense Music
children.description: Music developed by the people of the Rio de la Plata region.

children.name: Candombe
children.description: Uruguayan popular music originating among Montevideo's Afro-Uruguayan population, based on three differently-sized drums.

children.name: Candombe beat
children.description: Fusion of Uruguayan Candombe with elements of Rock music.

children.name: Chamarrita rioplatense
children.description: Traditional genre and dance featuring similar rhythms to Milonga and typically performed with the guitar and accordion.

children.name: Electrotango
children.description: Combines Tango rhythms and melodies with Electronic music.

children.name: Milonga
children.description: Characterized by a slow rhythm usually performed on a guitar; generally considered a precursor to Tango.

children.name: Murga uruguaya
children.description: Variant originated in Montevideo that stands out for its rhythms, nasal vocals and choral arrangements.

children.name: Tango
children.description: Melancholic sound generally led by a guitar or bandoneon, originating in Buenos Aires by the late 19th century and gaining worldwide popularity from the 1920s to the 1950s.

children.name: Finnish Tango
children.description: Melancholic style developed in Finland in the 1930s and 1940s, influenced by traditional minor-key Finnish Folk Music melodies and the rhythms of German marches.

children.name: Tango nuevo
children.description: Adds new elements into traditional Argentine Tango, most importantly the incorporation of Jazz and Western Classical Music.

children.name: RKT
children.description: Emerged in the early 2010s, characterized by minimalistic, rhythm-centric production heavily influenced by Cumbia villera and other Cumbia argentina styles.

children.name: Rock andino
children.description: Emerged in the Andean countries in the late 1960s and early 1970s, incorporating traditional instruments and harmonies from Indigenous Andean Music within a Rock format.

children.name: Salsa choke
children.description: Colombian style that takes heavy influence from Reggaetón, House, Hip Hop, and various Afro-Colombian and Colombian Pacific styles.

children.name: Saya
children.description: Fast-paced, percussive traditional genre created by the Afro-Bolivian people.

children.name: Taquirari
children.description: Developed by the indigenous peoples of eastern Bolivia, bringing in some elements of Hispanic Music, and featuring a syncopated rhythm.

children.name: Tecnomerengue
children.description: Fuses basic Merengue rhythms with influences from Cumbia and Lambada, being largely synthesized, with live instruments usually limited to percussion and brass.

children.name: Vallenato
children.description: Accordion-led style of folk and popular music originating in Colombia's Caribbean region.

children.name: Yaraví
children.description: Peruvian criollo-mestizo songs with recurring themes of sadness and unrequited love, usually in 6/8 meter.

children.name: Zamacueca
children.description: Traditional genre and dance of 19th century Peru, sung in the minor mode and accompanied by a varying combination of guitar, vihuela, harp and cajón.

children.name: Zamba
children.description: Folk dance that evolved out of Peruvian Zamacueca during the 19th century.

name: Sufi Music
description: Covering the various musical traditions of Sufis.

children.name: Kafi
children.description: Sufi vocal style popular in Pakistan, differentiated from Qawwali by its small ensemble size and simple arrangements.

children.name: Manzuma
children.description: Melodic, devotional music performed by Sufi Islami communities in Ethiopia and neighboring countries

children.name: Qawwali
children.description: Sufi Music in India and Pakistan using the raga and tala templates of Hindustani Classical Music.

children.name: Rapai dabõih
children.description: Religious music meant to accompany the dabõih ceremony of the Acehnese people.

children.name: Sufiana kalam
children.description: Classical music of the Kashmir region, the northernmost part of the Indian subcontinent.

children.name: Sufi Rock
children.description: Pakistani subgenre rooted in Sufi tradition, featuring South Asian instruments like the dhol, tabla, and sitar within a Rock band format with lyrics and imagery inspired by traditional Sufi poets.

children.name: Turkish Mevlevi Music
children.description: Traditional music performed among Turkish practitioners of the Mevlevi order of Sufism.

name: Traditional Folk Music
description: Informed by a long history of tradition in a specific culture or region, mostly associated with the peasantry and non-aristocratic public.

children.name: African Folk Music
children.description: Indigenous music of Africa that is passed down orally from generation to generation, the authors of the songs are usually unknown.

children.name: Ambasse bey
children.description: African Folk Music developed by the Yabassi people of Cameroon.

children.name: Apala
children.description: Yoruba Music developed by Muslims during the late 1930s and early 1940s in the Ijebu region of Yorubaland, the current Ogun state.

children.name: Batuque
children.description: Tradition from Cape Verde, unusual among the islands' music due to its lack of polyphonic singing and its usage of polyrhythms.

children.name: Dagomba Music
children.description: Music of the Dagomba people of northern Ghana.

children.name: Gnawa
children.description: Mixture of Sub-Saharan African, Arabic, and Amazigh Music, created by the Gnawa, an ethnic minority group in North Africa, mainly Morocco.

children.name: Kabye Folk Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of the Kabye people of northern Togo, including some of the most singular styles that can be found in West Africa.

children.name: Kilapanga
children.description: Tradition of the Bakongo people from Angola and Congo that has influenced contemporary styles such as Kuduro.

children.name: Malagasy Folk Music
children.description: Melodic, chordophone-dominated sound; based on the Austronesian Traditional Music of the first settlers that arrived on the island from Borneo.

children.name: Mbenga-Mbuti Music
children.description: Music of the Mbenga and Mbuti people, Pygmy ethnic groups in Central Africa.

children.name: Moutya
children.description: Tradition that originated in Seychelles among Creole slaves, similar to Séga, although rawer and played only on large flat drums made from goatskin.

children.name: Ngoma
children.description: Played in Swahili-speaking African countries; primarily focused on rhythm.

children.name: Unyago
children.description: Traditional music from Zanzibar, traditionally played at women's initiation rituals and weddings.

children.name: Semba
children.description: Style from Angola featuring danceable percussion, lyrics often taking the form of a story, and sometimes accompaniment from a guitar.

children.name: Southern African Folk Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of southern Africa.

children.name: Afrikaner Folk Music
children.description: Musical traditions developed by the Afrikaner community in southern Africa.

children.name: Khoisan Folk Music
children.description: Encompasses traditions of the Khoisan ethnic family groups.

children.name: Nguni Folk Music
children.description: Traditions of the Nguni ethnic family groups, a southern Bantu ethnicity.

children.name: Shona Mbira Music
children.description: Traditional style of the Shona people from Zimbabwe, based on a simple melodic pattern played on the mbira, from which long instrumental parts are improvised.

children.name: Sotho-Tswana Folk Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of the Sotho-Tswana ethnic family groups from southern Africa.

children.name: Tchinkoumé
children.description: Tradition from the central region of Benin around Savalou, played with water percussion.

children.name: Traditional Maloya
children.description: Derived from Traditional Séga, this is the original dance music of La Réunion.

children.name: Traditional Séga
children.description: Séga dance music born in the 18th century, before its later adoption of Western pop elements.

children.name: Zinli
children.description: Traditional rhythmic chanting and percussion adapted to multiple West African contexts in the 20th century.

children.name: American Folk Music
children.description: Traces back through the history of European and West African settlement and migration to North America, including parts of northern Mexico and Canada in addition to the United States.

children.name: Appalachian Folk Music
children.description: Folk of the Appalachian Mountains in the Eastern United States.

children.name: Old-Time
children.description: Pre-Bluegrass North American string band styles, particularly those rooted in Appalachian Folk Music.

children.name: Country Blues
children.description: Various styles of Blues originating in the rural US South, typically relying on expressive vocal delivery and featuring simple, usually acoustic instrumentation.

children.name: Acoustic Texas Blues
children.description: Laid-back swing rhythms and guitar ornamentation, including solos.

children.name: Delta Blues
children.description: One of the earliest forms of Blues, named for the Mississippi Delta region of the United States where it developed, with a highly rhythmic style and a typical 12-bar structure.

children.name: Hill Country Blues
