children.description: Emphasizes a steady hypnotic groove, sparse percussive and highly energetic guitar riffs, and often features meandering structures with unconventional and usually fewer chord changes compared to Delta Blues.

children.name: Piedmont Blues
children.description: Developed in the early 20th century in the southern Appalachian foothills and characterized by a syncopated but melodic Ragtime-based finger-picking acoustic guitar style.

children.name: Field Hollers
children.description: Work song created by African-American slaves working on cotton plantations, which features an expressive vocal style to no strict rhythm.

children.name: Fife and Drum Blues
children.description: Rooted in martial Fife and Drum Corps music, originated among Afro-American communities in Mississippi.

children.name: Jug Band
children.description: Usually features a jug as the bass instrument as well as other homemade (or easily affordable) instruments, such as kazoos and washboards.

children.name: Ring Shout
children.description: Ritual practiced by African-Americans in the US South, characterized by shouting, chanting and people dancing in a circle while praying and clapping.

children.name: Sacred Harp Music
children.description: Predominantly 19th-century English hymns with tunes derived from old folk melodies.

children.name: Spirituals
children.description: Predecessor to Gospel that began as unaccompanied singing by American slaves; shares some of the characteristics of Work Songs.

children.name: Talking Blues
children.description: American Folk Music with spoken or nearly spoken vocals.

children.name: Traditional Black Gospel
children.description: Born out of Spirituals in the early 20th century with influence from Southern Gospel and Blues, often featuring passionate or energetic vocal performances, motifs of salvation, and testaments of hardship.

children.name: Traditional Cajun Music
children.description: Earliest and most "pure" form of Cajun Music, employing basic rhythms and frequent fiddle double stops.

children.name: Traditional Country
children.description: Closely aligned with American Folk Music and Blues roots, from country's inception in Appalachia and the American South until the popularity of Honky Tonk and Country Pop in the 1950s.

children.name: Close Harmony
children.description: Traditional two-part harmony singing performed mostly by brothers.

children.name: Country Gospel
children.description: Traditional Country that heavily incorporates Gospel.

children.name: Bluegrass Gospel
children.description: Incorporates the religious topics and harmony vocals found in Country Gospel.

children.name: Country Yodeling
children.description: Vocal technique of Yodeling, brought to the United States by German settlers, sung over the instrumentation of Traditional Country.

children.name: Arabic Folk Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of the Arabic people.

children.name: Aita
children.description: Arabic Folk Music from rural Morocco with piercing singing, scratchy viola, and rollicking hand drums.

children.name: Arabic Bellydance Music
children.description: Accompaniment to traditional belly dances.

children.name: Fijiri
children.description: Deeply rooted in the Persian Gulf pearl diving culture, and sung during weekly gatherings combining solo and choral sections with minimal percussion.

children.name: Australian Folk Music
children.description: Folk traditions of the European colonists and convicts in Australia.

children.name: Austronesian Traditional Music
children.description: Traditional styles of music developed by Austronesian nations prior to arrival of foreign influence.

children.name: Gondang
children.description: Traditional ensemble in Bataknese traditional music of North Sumatra, taking its name from its leading instrument - a unique set of toned drums.

children.name: Indigenous Taiwanese Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of the various Austronesian people groups that make up the indigenous population of the island of Taiwan.

children.name: Pakacaping Music
children.description: Traditional genres of music found among the ethnicities of Indonesian archipelago, particularly on South Sulawesi, Borneo and North Sumatra.

children.name: Brazilian Folk Music
children.description: Comprises the various traditions of folk music found in Brazil, often resulting from the interplay of Indigenous, African and European music.

children.name: Aboio
children.description: Cattle-herding songs originating in rural Northeastern Brazil.

children.name: Aboio cantado
children.description: Aboio that features rhyming verses.

children.name: Banda de pífano
children.description: Lively music played by bands consisting of two fifes and percussion.

children.name: Candomblé Music
children.description: Music of the Afro-Brazilian Candomblé religion that influenced the secular Afoxé.

children.name: Cantoria
children.description: Sung poetry of itinerant cantadores from Northeastern Brazil.

children.name: Repente
children.description: Contest of fully improvised poetry sung in different stanza formats.

children.name: Capoeira Music
children.description: Afro-Brazilian style that accompanies and sets the rhythm and energy of the capoeira martial art, originating in the 19th century with the relocation of African slaves to the states of Bahia and Rio de Janeiro.

children.name: Fandango caiçara
children.description: Style of fandango born in coastal Southern Brazil amidst the Caiçara people.

children.name: Jongo
children.description: Afro-Brazilian cultural manifestation involving music and dance; composed of percussion instruments and chants.

children.name: Ponto de umbanda
children.description: Afro-Brazilian religious ritualistic praise sung by priests to evoke entities; typically accompanied by claps and traditional drums known as atabaque.

children.name: Lundu
children.description: Afro-Brazilian musical genre that emerged in the 18th century with influences from African drumming with European Fandango.

children.name: Maracatu
children.description: Afro-Brazilian genre which accompanies the cultural manifestation of the same name, hailing from the northeastern state of Pernambuco.

children.name: Modinha
children.description: Popular during the 18th and 19th centuries in Brazil; characterized by sentimental works with amorous themes, poetic lyrics, acoustic instrumentation and operatic vocals.

children.name: Rasqueado
children.description: Regional dance and its accompanying music from the Brazilian midwest, predominantly the state of Mato Grosso.

children.name: Samba de roda
children.description: Mixed Portuguese culture with African slave traditions, as well as sharing roots and similarities with Batuque and Jongo.

children.name: Sertanejo de raiz
children.description: Earliest form of Sertanejo, emerging in pre-World War II rural Brazil during the late 1920s; quickly strummed acoustic guitars, most commonly the 10-string viola caipira and classical guitar, and a highly emotive vocal style.

children.name: Moda de viola
children.description: Style of Sertanejo de raiz predominant in southeast, south, and west-central Brazil.

children.name: Toada de Boi
children.description: Slow, heavy-percussed tunes celebrating the folkloric Ox, originally from Bumba-meu-boi June parties in Northeastern Brazil.

children.name: Buryat Folk Music
children.description: Traditional music of the Buryat people, a Mongolic ethnic group inhabiting the Republic of Buryatia, a federal subject of the Russian Far East region.

children.name: Canadian Folk Music
children.description: Traditional folk of the European settlers who arrived in Canada.

children.name: Canadian Maritime Folk
children.description: Traditional folk of Canada's Maritimes (Nova Scotia, Prince Edward Island, and New Brunswick).

children.name: Cape Breton Folk Music
children.description: Celtic Folk Music that emerged in Cape Breton, an island at the eastern shore of Nova Scotia, through immigrants from Scotland and Ireland.

children.name: Cape Breton Fiddling
children.description: Distinctive Celtic fiddling originating from the Scottish immigrants who settled in Canada on Cape Breton Island.

children.name: French-Canadian Folk Music
children.description: Brought by French colonists to their Nouvelle-France settlements, primarily based around French Folk Music with influences from English Folk Music and Celtic Folk Music, typically played during gatherings and holidays.

children.name: Newfoundland Folk Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of Newfoundland and Labrador, Canada's easternmost province.

children.name: Caribbean Folk Music
children.description: Meta-genre that covers the different forms of Traditional Folk Music from the Caribbean.

children.name: Bele
children.description: Drum-based folkdance with a strong Afro-influence, conducted by duos of dancers and accompanied by call-and-response singing, particularly popular in Martinique, Dominica and Trinidad and Tobago.

children.name: Benna
children.description: Traditional music of Antigua & Barbuda, using call-and-response and bawdy lyrics.

children.name: Bomba
children.description: Percussive style from Puerto Rico, generally considered to be derived from West Africa.

children.name: Fungi
children.description: Traditional Folk Music native to the Virgin Islands, named after a local dish which features a "mixed-up" flavor that can be compared to the style that combines Western instruments with local ones.

children.name: Garifuna Folk Music
children.description: Folk of Garifunas, Caribbean people born from escaped African slaves and local Caribbean natives.

children.name: Haitian Vodou Drumming
children.description: Form of rhythmic performance by Haitian Vodou practitioners, played at associated ceremonies.

children.name: Jibaro
children.description: Traditions of the mountain-dwelling jibaro people that live primarily in Puerto Rico.

children.name: Kitchen Dance Music
children.description: Cayman Islands music played during kitchen dance parties, centered around fiddle and percussion (handmade or kitchen grater) playing.

children.name: Mento
children.description: Jamaican folk originating in the late 19th century which brought together African and European elements, going on to influence the rhythm in Reggae.

children.name: Méringue
children.description: Haitian genre that dates back to the early 19th century; the roots of Compas.

children.name: Plena
children.description: Folk genre from Puerto Rico played with hand drums called panderetas.

children.name: Ripsaw
children.description: Indigenous style of the Turks and Caicos Islands, featuring a handsaw as the primary instrument.

children.name: Trinidadian Cariso
children.description: Trinidadian folk considered to be the precursor of Calypso, led by (mostly female) singers called chantwells, who sing derogatory lyrics to the sound of drums and guitars in a call-and-response manner in order to rebel against slaveowners.

children.name: Tumba
children.description: African-style percussion alongside Latin influences and often explicit lyrics.

children.name: Virgin Islander Cariso
children.description: Folk of the Virgin Islands, sung exclusively by women to the beat of one or two drums.

children.name: Caucasian Folk Music
children.description: Folk of the Caucasus region, a mountainous area that connects Eastern Europe to Asia.

children.name: Abkhazian Folk Music
children.description: Traditions of the Republic of Abkhazia, a disputed territory on the Black Sea in northwestern Georgia.

children.name: Chechen Folk Music
children.description: Folk of the Chechens, a Northeast Caucasian ethnic group predominantly living in the Republic of Chechnya, a federal subject of Russia.

children.name: Circassian Folk Music
children.description: Folk of the native Circassian peoples of Northern Caucasus, residing in the Republics of Adygea, Karachay-Cherkessia, and Kabardino-Balkaria respectively, which are federal subjects of the Russian Federation, as well as the territories of the former Ottoman Empire, with a significant diaspora population in modern Turkey.

children.name: Dagestani Folk Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of the Dagestani people.

children.name: Avar Folk Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of the Avar people.

children.name: Georgian Folk Music
children.description: Traditions of the Georgian people, who mostly live in Georgia.

children.name: Ossetian Folk Music
children.description: Folk music of Ossetians, an ethnic group that mainly inhabits a region located on both sides of the Greater Caucasus Mountains.

children.name: Chukchi Folk Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of the Chukchi people.

children.name: East Asian Folk Music
children.description: All the forms of Traditional Folk Music from East Asia, including Japanese Folk Music, Chinese Folk Music, and Korean Folk Music.

children.name: Chinese Folk Music
children.description: Traditional folk of the Chinese people.

children.name: Han Folk Music
children.description: Chinese folk form often played at weddings and funerals, using the Suona (a form of oboe) and Chuigushou (a specific type of percussive ensemble), together with heterophony.

children.name: Jiangnan sizhu
children.description: Played by a varying ensemble of several different types of stringed instruments, flutes, small percussion instruments, and mouth organs.

children.name: Shan’ge
children.description: Work Songs sung by Chinese agricultural workers.

children.name: Indigenous Taiwanese Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of the various Austronesian people groups that make up the indigenous population of the island of Taiwan.

children.name: Japanese Folk Music
children.description: Folk traditions of Japan.

children.name: Amami shimauta
children.description: Tradition from the Amami Islands, located in southern Japan.

children.name: Heikyoku
children.description: Semi-classical bardic tradition in Japan analogous to the troubadour music of medieval Europe.

children.name: Kagura
children.description: Performed at Shinto shrines for ceremonies and rituals.

children.name: Kouta
children.description: Kouta, which literally means "little" or "short" song, is one type of the many varieties of Japanese folk songs that is distinguished by its briefness and wittiness.

children.name: Min'yō
children.description: Form of Japanese Folk Music which literally translates to "folk song".

children.name: Ondō
children.description: Originally referred to the type of call-and-response form of Gagaku, but later became to be known for and distinguished by a swung 2/2 rhythm and storytelling.

children.name: Rōkyoku
children.description: Storytelling usually accompanied by a shamisen.

children.name: Taiko
children.description: Modern style of ensemble drumming, sometimes called kumi-daiko.

children.name: Tsugaru shamisen
children.description: Shamisen playing originating in the Tsugaru Peninsula of Aomori prefecture, recognizable in its percussive quality and special, slightly larger instrument.

children.name: Korean Folk Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of the Korean people.

children.name: Pansori
children.description: Korean style of storytelling characterized by over-the-top, passionate singing from a solo vocalist accompanied by minimal drumming.

children.name: Pungmul
children.description: Consists of drumming, dancing, and singing, and is a tradition deeply ingrained in South Korean culture.

children.name: Sanjo
children.description: Traditional instrumental Korean Folk Music that focuses on a wide variety of rhythmic changes with many different classical Korean instruments.

children.name: Sinawi
children.description: Improvisational genre traditionally serving as an accompaniment to Korean shamanic rituals.

children.name: Vietnamese Folk Music

children.name: Bambuco
children.description: Follows a 6/8 or 3/4 time signature with non-percussive instrumentation, often melancholic in sound with bright guitars and a rich melodic base.

children.name: Bomba

children.name: Chamamé

children.name: Chamarrita rioplatense
children.description: Traditional genre and dance featuring similar rhythms to Milonga and typically performed with the guitar and accordion.

children.name: Cueca
children.description: Popular in Chile, Argentina, and Bolivia, accompanied by a 6/8 or 3/4 time signature and usually structured into 14 verses.

children.name: Jibaro
children.description: Traditions of the mountain-dwelling jibaro people that live primarily in Puerto Rico.

children.name: Joropo

children.name: Malagueña venezolana

children.name: Canto cardenche

children.name: Son calentano
children.description: Usually dominated by violin with accompaniment mainly provided by guitars and tamboras, occasionally dancers will stomp over a platform.

children.name: Son huasteco
children.description: Bold rhythmic structure, lively violin playing, and extensive use of falsetto.

children.name: Son istmeño
children.description: Developed in the Isthmus of Tehuantepec, traditionally played by guitar, requinto, marimba, and bajoquinto, usually played in 3/4 time.

children.name: Son jarocho
children.description: Mexican Folk Music from the Gulf Coast Mexican state of Veracruz, with both Spanish and indigenous influences.

children.name: Trova yucateca
children.description: Heavily influenced by Cuban Music, freely embracing Bolero, clave and Bambuco.

children.name: Milonga

children.name: Muliza

children.name: Música criolla peruana

children.name: Marinera
children.description: Component of the coastal dance of the same name, often considered the national dance of Peru.

children.name: Vals criollo
children.description: Originally characterized by its 3/4 time, heavy reliance on strongly plucked phrase on upper strings, and its guitar solo; often accompanied by a duet or a solo singer, normally singing about patriotic themes or social dilemmas.

children.name: Plena
children.description: Folk genre from Puerto Rico played with hand drums called panderetas.

children.name: Saya
children.description: Fast-paced, percussive traditional genre created by the Afro-Bolivian people.

children.name: Tamborito
children.description: Folk music and dance from Panama dating back to the 17th century.

children.name: Taquirari
children.description: Developed by the indigenous peoples of eastern Bolivia, bringing in some elements of Hispanic Music, and featuring a syncopated rhythm.

children.name: Tonada chilena
children.description: Traditional folk from the Chilean countryside distinguished by its prominent melody.

children.name: Yaraví
children.description: Peruvian criollo-mestizo songs with recurring themes of sadness and unrequited love, usually in 6/8 meter.

children.name: Zamacueca
children.description: Traditional genre and dance of 19th century Peru, sung in the minor mode and accompanied by a varying combination of guitar, vihuela, harp and cajón.

children.name: Zamba
children.description: Folk dance that evolved out of Peruvian Zamacueca during the 19th century.

children.name: Indigenous American Traditional Music
children.description: Meta-genre encompassing traditions attributed to the indigenous peoples of the Americas.

children.name: Athabaskan Fiddling
children.description: Fiddle playing of the Dene or "Athabaskan" people of modern-day Alaska, Yukon and the Northwest Territories.

children.name: Inuit Vocal Games
children.description: Practiced by the Inuit of Canada, two vocalists face each other decimeters away and try to outlast each other with intense and unusual vocal techniques.

children.name: James Bay Fiddling
children.description: Fiddle playing of the James Bay Cree people, characterised by a fusion of Scottish style with Cree rhythms.

children.name: Mapuche Folk Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of the Mapuche people of Chile and Argentina.

children.name: Powwow Music
children.description: Drum-based traditional music of Plains region Native American tribes, traditionally played at Pow-wows.

children.name: Tonada potosina
children.description: Traditional folk sung in Quechua, played on charangos and guitarillas, with a catchy, lively rhythm.

children.name: Unakesa
children.description: Lay song and dance of the Fulni-ô people.

children.name: Ladino Folksong
children.description: Ladino-language Traditional Folk Music tunes that were written and preserved by Sephardic Jews.

children.name: Ob-Ugric Folk Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of the Ob-Ugric people of West Siberia Plain.

children.name: Payada
children.description: Improvised poetry accompanied by a guitar that is tied to gaucho culture, usually performed in duo as a verse duel.

children.name: Romani Folk Music
children.description: Folk of the Romani people, an ethnic group with origins in Northern India, but who have since the Middle Ages settled around Europe, principally Romania, Bulgaria, and Spain, and many other places.

children.name: Samoyedic Folk Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of the Samoyedic peoples.

children.name: South Asian Folk Music
children.description: Meta-genre which covers all the Traditional Folk Music forms from South Asia.

children.name: Assamese Folk Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of the Assamese people, a people group mostly from the Northeastern Indian state of Assam.

children.name: Bengali Folk Music
children.description: Traditions of the Bengali people found mainly in the Indian state of West Bengal and the country of Bangladesh.

children.name: Baul gaan
children.description: Songs performed by the Bauls, a movement of mystic entertainers influenced by diverse spiritual traditions.

children.name: Bhojpuri Folk Music
children.description: Traditions of the Bhojpuri people of India, originally from the states of Bihar and Uttar Pradesh.

children.name: Biraha
children.description: Call-and-response style of folk music developed from the Ahir and neighboring castes of the Bhojpuri people.

children.name: Boduberu
children.description: Traditional, percussion-based form of music popular in the Maldives, usually following a crescendo structure.

children.name: Burushaski Folk Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of the Burusho people of northern Pakistan.

children.name: Gujarati Folk Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of the Gujarati people, who primarily live in the western Indian state of Gujarat.

children.name: Kannada Folk Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of the Kannada people, a large ethnolinguistic group who mainly inhabit the state of Karnataka in southwestern India.

children.name: Kirtan
children.description: Call-and-response chanting that involves the singing of devotional mantras and hymns in a bhakti devotional style, occasionally accompanied with traditional folk instrumentation.

children.name: Shabad kirtan
children.description: Religious Sikh Hymns backed by specially selected ragas and taal.

children.name: Malayali Folk Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of Kerala, India primarily sung in the Malayalam language and known for its drumming and percussion.

children.name: Marathi Folk Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of the Marathi people, a large ethnic group who mainly inhabit the state of Maharashtra in western India.

children.name: Newa Folk Music
children.description: Traditions of the Newa people, who live in Nepal, performed with mostly percussive instruments and some wind instruments.

children.name: Odia Folk Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of the Odia, a large ethnic group who mainly inhabit the state of Odisha in eastern India.

children.name: Pashto Folk Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of the Pashtun people of southern Afghanistan and north-western Pakistan.

children.name: Punjabi Folk Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of the Punjabi people, mostly from the Punjab regions of India and Pakistan, covering diverse styles often played with traditional instruments.

children.name: Rajasthani Folk Music
children.description: Traditions of the Rajasthani people of Western India - who now mostly live in the eponymous Rajasthan state - originated across the various castes that inhabit the region.

children.name: Sinhalese Folk Music
children.description: Folk of the Sinhalese people, the majority ethnic group of Sri Lanka.

children.name: Sarala gee
children.description: Blend of Hindustani Classical Music with Sinhalese Folk Music.

children.name: Tamil Folk Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of the Tamil people.

children.name: Urumi melam
children.description: Percussive ensemble native to the Tamil Nadu region, taking its name from the urumi drum.

children.name: Telugu Folk Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of the Telugu people, one of the largest ethnolinguistic groups of India, mainly living in the states of Andhra Pradesh and Telangana.

children.name: Southeast Asian Folk Music
children.description: Meta-genre covering all folk forms from Southeast Asia, like Gondang, Hmong, Iban, Karen, Keroncong, Khmer, Lao, Lun Bawang, Molam, and Orang Ulu.

children.name: Balitaw
children.description: Folk originating in the Visayas islands of the Philippines; dialogue or debate in which a man and a woman compete at improvising romantic verses.

children.name: Bamar Folk Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of the majority ethnic group of Myanmar.

children.name: Filipino Rondalla
children.description: Folk music composed by an ensemble of various pluck-stringed instruments typically played for traditional Filipino folk dances.

children.name: Gondang
children.description: Traditional ensemble in Bataknese traditional music of North Sumatra, taking its name from its leading instrument - a unique set of toned drums.

children.name: Hill Tribe Music
children.description: Traditions of the various tribal ethnic groups residing in the hills of Mainland Southeast Asia and Southwest China, also known as the region of Zomia.

children.name: Hmong Folk Music
children.description: Folk traditions of the Hmong people, an ethnic group localized in Laos, Vietnam, China, and Thailand.

children.name: Khmer Folk Music
children.description: Folk of the Khmer people, who mainly reside in Cambodia.

children.name: Kuda kepang
children.description: Accompanies a traditional Javanese dance of the same name, featuring a stripped-back version of a Gamelan ensemble that removes softer instruments.

children.name: Kundiman
children.description: Traditional Filipino love songs usually sung in Tagalog.

children.name: Lao Folk Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of the Lao people.

children.name: Malay Folk Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of the Malay people, who are native to Malaysia, Singapore, Brunei, northern Indonesia, and southern Thailand.

children.name: Thai Folk Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of the Thai people.

children.name: Fon leb
children.description: Traditional performance music originating in northern Thailand consist of an ensemble with Piphat instruments and a pair of female choreographers.

children.name: West Asian Folk Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of West Asia, a region that covers much of what is commonly known in English as the Middle East (alternatively Southwestern Asia), includes the distinct but interconnected traditions of numerous ethnic groups.

children.name: Alevi Folk Music
children.description: Anatolian folk pioneered by Turkish poets and bards, connected to the Alevist heterodox Islamic tradition.

children.name: Armenian Folk Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of the Armenians, which is attested in historic Armenia since antiquity, with unique regional dialects unified by general melodic structure.

children.name: Kef Music
children.description: Dance-oriented Armenian American music with prominent presence of Anatolian instruments and folkloric melodies (often in the 10/8 meter) paired with novel lyrics relating to a variety of topics.

children.name: Assyrian Folk Music
children.description: Folk of the Assyrian or Syriac people, who are indigenous to the Upper Mesopotamian region roughly corresponding to ancient Assyria (which includes modern-day northern Iraq, northwestern Iran, northeastern Syria, and southeastern Turkey).

children.name: Fijiri
children.description: Deeply rooted in the Persian Gulf pearl diving culture, and sung during weekly gatherings combining solo and choral sections with minimal percussion.

children.name: Israeli Folk Music
children.description: Folk of the Jewish settlers of Eretz Yisra'el.

children.name: Kurdish Folk Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of the Kurds, an Iranian people who traditionally inhabit the mountainous region of the Middle East comprising southeastern Turkey, northern Iraq, northwestern Iran, and northeastern Syria.

children.name: Luri Folk Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of the Luri people of southwestern Iran.

children.name: Meyxana
children.description: Azerbaijani folk recitative genre.

children.name: Persian Folk Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of the Persian people.

children.name: Turkish Folk Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of Turkish people combines the distinct cultural heritages and traditions of Anatolian civilisations and former Ottoman territories.

children.name: Turkish Black Sea Region Folk Music
children.description: Folk of the Turkish people who inhabit the northern region by the Black Sea.

children.name: Uzun Hava
children.description: Semi-improvisational melodic structure in Turkish Folk Music.

children.name: Zeybek
children.description: Turkish Folk Music music and dance that originated with the Zeybek people during the Ottoman Empire period, with slow and asymmetrical rhythms.

children.name: Work Songs
children.description: Sung by laborers and prisoners while working in factories and fields.

children.name: Aboio
children.description: Cattle-herding songs originating in rural Northeastern Brazil.

children.name: Aboio cantado
children.description: Aboio that features rhyming verses.

children.name: Field Hollers
children.description: Work song created by African-American slaves working on cotton plantations, which features an expressive vocal style to no strict rhythm.

children.name: Òrain luaidh
children.description: Rhythmic call-and-response style song form that traditionally accompanied the production of tweed cloth through beating the material by hand to soften it after it came off the loom.

children.name: Sea Shanty
children.description: Songs originally sung by sailors to coordinate work on ships.

children.name: Shan’ge
children.description: Work Songs sung by Chinese agricultural workers.

children.name: Yodeling
children.description: Vocal technique that arose in many cultures around the world as a form of calling and communication.

children.name: Country Yodeling
children.description: Vocal technique of Yodeling, brought to the United States by German settlers, sung over the instrumentation of Traditional Country.

children.name: Naturjodel
children.description: Originated in Toggenburg and Appenzell in Switzerland; deep vocal range, relaxed voice, free tempo, polyphony, elongated notes, improvisation, glissando, and use of syllabic sounds.

name: Turkic-Mongolic Traditional Music
description: Group of related traditions which originated among nomadic people of the Central Asian steppes (speakers of Altaic, i.e. Turkic, Mongolic, and Tungusic languages).

children.name: Altai Traditional Music
children.description: Traditions of the Altai people, an ethnic group who live in central Russia near the border of Mongolia and Kazakhstan.

children.name: Bashkir Folk Music
children.description: Traditional folk of the Bashkir people, a Turkic ethnic group inhabiting the Republic of Bashkortostan (Bashkiria), a federal subject of the Russian Federation, and its neighboring areas on both sides of the Ural mountains.

children.name: Buryat Folk Music
children.description: Traditional music of the Buryat people, a Mongolic ethnic group inhabiting the Republic of Buryatia, a federal subject of the Russian Far East region.

children.name: Central Asian Throat Singing
children.description: Shared polyphonic vocal tradition of Mongolia and southern Siberia characterised by complex manipulation of harmonics.

children.name: Mongolian Throat Singing
children.description: Traditional music from Mongolia characterized by many throat singing techniques.

children.name: Tuvan Throat Singing
children.description: Traditional style of singing found in Tuva, an autonomous region of the Russian Federation situated in southern Siberia.

children.name: Karakalpak Traditional Music
children.description: Traditions of the Karakalpak people, located in northwestern Uzbekistan.

children.name: Khakas Traditional Music
children.description: Traditions of the Khakas Republic (part of the Russian Federation), a form of Turkic music related to the musics of neighboring Tuva, Altai and Mongolia.

children.name: Kyrgyz Traditional Music
children.description: Traditions of Kyrgyzstan, a mountainous nation in Central Asia.

children.name: Sakha Traditional Music
children.description: Traditional music of Sakha (a.k.a. Yakut) people, mostly living in their homeland - Republic of Sakha (Yakutia) (part of Russian Federation).
